contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: 1. Time for a vacation: Book a ticket to Geneva.

or Miami.

Or both, and celebrate cars as art. Both are worth the trip.
2. Vote today: Pick the best idea to trick out a Ford Transit Connect. Voting ends December 12. Not to influence you, but my favorite is the Hunter Gatherer.
3. Here is the perfect gift for the Bridezilla who loves cars.

4. Raise your hand if you remember all the boys in fourth grade drawing cars when they were supposed to be learning about decimals. Well, Car Body Design has gathered up a carload of information to help budding car designers take it to the next level.

5. This is a great time of year to donate a car. Great for taxes, great for the recipient, and great for humanity. Cars4Christmas is working hard to get cars to people in need. There is a spot on their website that individuals can apply to be considered for a vehicle.
6. Want to see what the world’s great auto museums look like from the outside?

7. Home Depot has teamed up with Uber car service to deliver Christmas trees to Uber’s members in ten cities on December 5. The deal: a seven-to-eight-foot tree delivered to your door, an Uber scarf, and the gift of time that the service saves you. This is only for select cities. Now we need to know how much to set it up, and then come back in three weeks and take it away.
8. Is this the modern equivalent of stealing bread, Les Misérables style?

9. Pinterest perfection of the proverbial passion for fashion and cars.

And the modern update, certainly not as classy but still worth checking out.

10. Need a little extra cash for the holidays? Dig out your old Hot Wheels cars and sell them. But first, you need to photograph them. Here are some sweet tips.

Or do what this Alaska collector or this California ten-year-old are doing, and give them away as a random act of kindness.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: At the L.A. Auto Show, Kia design chief Peter Schreyer walked me around the company's rear-wheel-drive flagship, the 2015 Kia K900, which is expected to be priced starting above $50,000 when it goes on sale next spring. Automobile Magazine named Schreyer our 2012 Man of the Year because of his impact on the Korean company's product lineup. As automotive design editor Robert Cumberford wrote:

"Six years ago, Kia cars were nondescript tin boxes of no particular consequence in the grand scheme of things, sold on price and certainly not as world-class desirable objects. Today's Kia range is admired, respected, even envied. Its cars are well-made, good performers, and—above all—good-looking. That quality can essentially be attributed to one man, Peter Schreyer, chief design officer for Kia and our unanimously chosen Man of the Year."

He goes quietly from strength to strength, supremely confident in his craft and genuinely self-effacing in demeanor. A standup guy who always has something interesting to say. Kia won the lottery when he signed on board. It is now the company to watch.

metaTitle: My Ford C-Max Energi Challenge - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: I challenged myself to a week without resorting to gasoline. Hey, I'm in the Plug-In Generation. Find out how it came out on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
2013 Ford C-Max Energi Plug-In Hybrid

Price: $37,820 (including destination charge)
Engine: 2.0-liter Atkinson-cycle four-cylinder, 141 horsepower (188 total system horsepower)
Transmission: Continuously variable automatic (e-CVT)
Fuel economy: 44 mpg city/41 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Leather-trimmed seats and steering wheel
Option I can’t live without: Panoramic sunroof ($1,195)
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Volt, Honda Accord Plug-In Hybrid, Toyota Prius Plug-In Hybrid

No matter what your feelings are about electric or hybrid vehicles, pretty much everyone agrees that carmakers are going to have to do something in coming years to increase fuel economy. But will the car of the future be one with a big battery pack and a plug? Maybe, maybe not. I was curious to see what the future might look like to a person driving a plug-in hybrid, so I made a 2013 Ford C-Max Energi my commuter car for a work week in November to see how I liked it.

I was looking forward to a week with the C-Max Energi because, even though I normally prefer sportier cars, I’ve thought for some time now that my lifestyle would be perfect for plug-in hybrid ownership. My weekday routine should allow me to drive the C-Max Energi every day without using a drop of gasoline, saving the internal-combustion engine for the few times a month when I need to go more than twenty miles between charges. During my week with the Energi, I decided to see if I could do just that: use as little gas as possible—and, I hoped, none.

On paper, the C-Max Energi was perfectly suited to this task. It’s a plug-in hybrid vehicle with a battery pack that can give it up to twenty-one miles of electric range when fully charged, a little more than I’d need on an average day. Once you’ve discharged the battery, the C-Max acts like a regular hybrid, using the electric motor at low speeds and when coasting but relying mainly on the gasoline  engine. Its electric battery is rated to earn 100 mpg-e, while the car’s gasoline engine is rated at 43 mpg combined.

My C-Max arrived at the office on one of the first really cold days of Michigan autumn. In a "normal" car, this wouldn’t matter. Hop in, blast the heat for a few minutes, and you’ll be cozy and warm. Electric vehicles, though, see their range significantly diminish in cold temperatures, and using accessory functions like climate control and seat heaters further drains the battery.
The C-Max charges in 2.5 hours with a 240-volt plug. I plugged mine in when I arrived at the office each day, and it was ready to go by lunchtime.

In near-freezing temperatures, the C-Max Energi showed a fully charged battery but just sixteen miles of range as I pulled away from the office on the first day of my experiment. I put the C-Max in EV mode (it also has EV Later mode, which saves electric charge for later in the drive, and Hybrid mode, in which it operates like a conventional hybrid) and drove very sedately to the gym, making the most of regenerative braking and accelerating as gently as possible. When I arrived, I had traveled 4.9 miles and had recouped more than a mile’s worth of energy from regenerative braking. I had thirteen miles of range left.

After a pit stop at Starbucks for a salted caramel hot chocolate, a jaunt downtown for dinner, and back home for the night, I had just a few miles of range left for the morning’s trip to work. The EV range estimator, conveniently located on the C-Max’s digital dashboard, showed less than half a mile of juice left when I pulled up to the office charging port. The C-Max charges in seven hours with a 120-volt plug and 2.5 hours with a 240-volt plug. I plugged mine in when I arrived at the office each day, and it was ready to go by lunchtime.

The rest of the week passed in much the same fashion. I had just enough range to cover my travels on electricity alone. Still, I never had range anxiety—and no C-Max driver ever should—because the electric range is just the beginning for this car. The C-Max Energi is rated to go more than 600 miles on a tank of gasoline, and it automatically switches to gasoline power when the battery is depleted or the electric motor is overtaxed (under heavy acceleration, for instance) so there’s no need to worry about getting stranded.

I took a break from my electric-only project to see how Ford’s plug-in felt in hybrid mode, and found the C-Max as responsive and pleasant to drive as any other hybrid I’ve been in. It has a 2.0-liter, four-cylinder Atkinson cycle engine – the same engine that’s in the C-Max hybrid. It has 188 total system horsepower, so there’s plenty of juice for highway passing. The switch between gasoline and electric power isn’t quite seamless, but it’s close enough that you might not notice it if you’re not paying attention.

I succeeded in making it through my four-day turn with the C-Max without using any gasoline (except to test drive the gasoline engine). Senior editor Molly Jean took the C-Max for the weekend and drove it in Hybrid mode all weekend after the battery’s charge was depleted. In her 135 miles of driving, the C-Max Energi averaged 37.4 mpg, falling far short of its 43-mpg estimate. That could easily be chalked up to driving style and other factors, but it serves as a reminder that Ford had to revise the C-Max’s original fuel economy estimate of 47 mpg combined after drivers complained that the cars were underperforming.
There’s no reason—aside from a stubborn desire to prove yourself right—that you can’t drive the C-Max exactly the way you would drive a normal car.

Driving the car in EV mode in the winter required sacrifices that not all drivers would be willing to make; I never turned the heat above 65 degrees and didn’t use seat heaters, especially after I saw the quick dive my range estimate took as soon as those amenities were engaged. But the good news about the C-Max Energi is that you don’t have to live without creature comforts. There’s no reason—aside from a stubborn desire to prove yourself right—that you can’t drive the C-Max exactly the way you would drive a normal car. It’s a toe in the pool of electrified driving, but more like dating than marriage. And that’s exactly what many electric-curious shoppers are looking for.

Vital Stats

Base price: $24,650 (includes destination)
This car’s price: $24,945 (includes destination)
EPA fuel economy: 22 mpg city/34 mpg highway
Engine: 2.5-liter four-cylinder, 175 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Safety features: Side curtain airbags, electronic stability control, reverse sensing ($295)
Tech features: Sync with MyFord, SiriusXM radio
Chief competitors: Chevrolet Malibu, Honda Accord, Mazda 6, Nissan Altima, Toyota Camry
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/wDmboaa7CzU?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

I was missing Anthony Prozzi. I really hadn’t seen him since his big debut of the 2009 Ford Flex interior in New York City. I had arranged a project vehicle for Automobile Magazine to build for the SEMA show, and I had chosen the Flex as the perfect canvas for street artist Lee Quiñones, who became famous at the age of sixteen for being the first spray paint Michelangelo to tag an entire subway car. The New York PD called him Enemy No. 1. From those countercultural beginnings, he has risen to be commissioned to do entire buildings, and his artwork hangs in celebrity homes. The vehicle he did for SEMA celebrated the vibrancy of his New York: bridges, cabs, stockbrokers, and the music and garment industries.

During the course of that build, I enjoyed a lot of time with Prozzi in New York talking about his past in the fashion industry and really came to love his articulate expression of the materials and forms that shape an interior of a car. It was so different than anything I had ever heard from a classically trained automotive designer. Of course he was the one who did the Fusion interior, I thought when I found out. It was my opportunity to get back together and have a great day with him.

At the end of our day, we came up with this wonderful designer "sit-around" video, and then I discovered he lived in downtown Detroit, so he’ll be making an appearance in a future episode of My Detroit. I know you’re going to like him as much as I do.

title: 50 States of Online Shopping Part 2
promoTeaserSmall: Beauty, taste, tradition, and the frankly tacky from all over the U.S.A. Part 2: The other 25.
promoTeaser: Beauty, taste, tradition, and the frankly tacky from all over the U.S.A. Part 2: The other 25.
metaTitle: 50 States of Online Shopping Part 2 - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 50 States of Online Shopping, Part 2: Don't get into a state over holiday shopping. Here's a guide to fun things from all over the country. See it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: There's a reason USA Today has a summary of the daily news headlines from every state: people move around, and they want to catch a glimpse of places they used to call home. That's the rationale behind this guide. What's the most interesting stuff you can get from various parts of the country without actually going there? Here are a few things we dug up that would make good gifts for the Indiana expatriate or regretful ex-Wyomingite on your list. The other twenty-five states are back in Part 1.

Alabama:

Alabama's civil rights app will help you take a trip through a historic time for this state. Points for trying to overcome the past. Likewise, check out this Road Trips website to plan an exploring trip of the beautiful state of Alabama. If you're looking for dishes or bakers, how about Earthborn Pottery's, made from Alabama clay?

Indiana:

This central state has a centralized website guide to things Made in Indiana with links to a number of sources.

Maine:

Find all kinds of Maine stuff, not all of which is made of driftwood, at the Maine Made site. As for food, there’s no shortage of mail-order lobster companies. The Hancock Gourmet Lobster company sells to Saks and has been name-checked on the Food Network, plus: it's headquartered in a charmingly small village, Cundys Harbor.

Maryland:

The DNR has a Forest Fire Truck ($50) and a selection of seafood cookbooks, or if your gift recipient lives in Maryland, you can order trees to be planted in a public space in their home county, and they get a certificate to commemorate the gift. $40 a tree, and if you order ten for $400, you can choose the public location of their planting.

Massachusetts:

The Kennedy obsession continues, and at the JFK Library, you can buy everything from the secret White House recordings of JFK’s conversations, on CDs ($40) to reproductions of presidential china from a dozen administrations. Plus, books and memorabilia for Robert, Teddy, and others in the dynasty.

Michigan:

Michigan does a state tourism slogan better than anybody, from the old Say Yes to Michigan! to the current “Pure Michigan” campaign. Get Pure Michigan stuff here.

Minnesota:

The Minnesota Historical Society is where you can skip the state’s Mall of America and get gifts centered around Fraser fir scents, cedar, and loons. Or how about a cribbage set ($46.95) in the shape of the state?

Missouri:

The governor launched a “100 Missouri Miles” initiative back in June, challenging everyone to do 100 miles’ worth of outdoor activity during the year, inviting them to get it done in the vaunted state parks system of trails. The state parks gift shop sells related clothes and badges. People of Missouri have logged 1,084,498 miles to date. Not a bad idea no matter what state you're in. The shop also has Lewis & Clark merchandise and other Missouri-themed goods.

Montana:

The Montana State Government store sells items such as Christmastime in Montana ($15.95), a paperback history book with “reminiscences of early prospectors, ranchers, and homesteaders,” among other stories. Scenic calendars and cookbooks (which are heavy on meat-cooking recipes) are also on display. Any of these items could get someone thinking about going off the grid in high country.

Nevada:

This state does “official tourism shop” right, with a Nevada Historical Society online shop that sells “Nevada passports” and finger puppets of Nevada animals but also serious literature and memorabilia related to Reno history, the Donner party, and native Americans. A Pony Express route map is only $5.

New Jersey:

Just say no to Jersey Shore trashy garments by visiting Jetty, a South Jersey “surf/skate/lifestyle” brand. Beach-themed, but tasteful, clothes and gear, plus browsing new musical artists and surf stars on the site. Women’s “Raglan Fish” hoodies are $47. Be Of the Shore, not a Shore fashion victim.

New Mexico:

The Land of Enchantment boasts three museum stores with one central online shop: wood art, turquoise jewelry, and posters of art by New Mexico artists.

New York:

Let’s just skip over the copious numbers of I Love New York souvenir shops you can find online and go over to the delightfully hyphenated New-York Historical Society or upstate to the Adirondacks, which have an online museum shop.

North Carolina:

The Carolina Travel Planner lists things to do and places to shop in the winter. Or have an Outer Banks Christmas with a wide variety of those ubiquitous OBX items, books, and art from the rustic, beautiful, storm-prone edge of the East Coast.

Oklahoma:

The official Cherokee Nation Gift Shop has perhaps the coolest license plate out there, a Cherokee Nation plate ($6.95) written in Cherokee. Plus the expected textiles, pottery, and Cherokee Nation seal items.

Pennsylvania:

Customized road trips courtesy of the state of Pennsylvania at Visit PA; on one of them, you might run across some Civil War re-enactors. If not, here’s the Civil War 150th anniversary store.

Rhode Island:

Newport Style has architecture books that let you ogle grand mansions from the comfort of your own coffee table. Or check out the quirky arts and crafts online shop Craftland, which has a Constellations over Rhode Island print that would look great on an office wall ($22).

South Carolina:

Here’s where to buy Certified SC Products online, including praline pecans in a Hilton Head Lighthouse tin ($16).

Tennessee

Regional food is not dead. That’s if you call Moon Pies “food.” Whether you are interested ironically or because they’re good, here’s the official Moon Pie online shop. Or buy music or poster prints from the Country Music Hall of Fame.

Utah

The Utah Store has the maps and guidebooks you need to visit the state, plus the Utah Official Scenic Calendar ($12.95), and when they say “scenic,” they are not joking around. Or try the gift shop for Utah’s Bonneville Salt Flats, where the World Land Speed Record is contested. Tiny boxes of mints with Land Speed Record vehicle images on top ($6) would make nice stocking stuffers.

Vermont

Vermont’s reputation as a hippie haven means it has great crafts to buy. The Vermont Crafts Council will get you to the felted wool garments and the woodblock prints.

Washington

Discover Northwest is a Seattle-based nonprofit dedicated to preserving public lands. Its maps, trail guides, and historic poster prints would make great dream material for future trip planning.

West Virginia

A lot of simple yet elegant crafts, and mountain music on CDs, come out of West Virginia, and here’s where to buy it online. Allegheny Mountain Radio is the place for CDs and books about mountain music, including the late Sen. Robert Byrd’s Mountain Fiddler recording.

Wyoming

Continental Divide gifts (such as an aluminum water bottle with Continental Divide Trail logo for $11), plus resources that will make you want to get in the car and take a driving trip, at the Continental Divide Trail Store online.

contributors.bio: Liane Yvkoff dipped her toe in the pool of automotive writing five years ago and fell directly into the deep end. Since then, she has written about cars for CNET.com, AutoUSA.com, Babble.com, and, oddly enough, Hustler. Residing in the Seattle area, she obviously drives a Subaru Outback.

pages.metaTitle: My iPhone is my co-pilot: 4 mapping apps better than in-dash navigation systems
pages.name: index

pageElements.text: The steering wheel is my car’s only factory-installed navigation system, and NPR is as close as my aging Subaru Outback comes to offering “infotainment.” But that doesn’t mean that I don’t have state-of-the-art software routing me around traffic backups or helping me find that trendy new pop-up restaurant. Smartphones, with their sophisticated mapping applications, have filled the gap for vehicles not equipped with navigation systems. In many cases, mobile navigation apps provide an easier-to-use interface with more accurate data, making in-dash navigation systems about as cutting edge as a toaster oven. If you’re wondering how to get turn-by-turn directions in your old car without buying a new one, consider these options:

1. Apple/Google Maps/Bing Maps

Your mobile phone is equipped as standard with one of the best navigation systems on the market, and the best part is that it’s free. These days, native maps apps offer turn-by-turn directions that can stream through some vehicle stereo systems. Instead of memorizing a slow, complex menu tree, drivers can easily dial up directions using spoken, natural language voice commands and search intuitively within the map for nearby addresses.  Another upside is that map information is up to date, and you don’t have to pay to upgrade. The downside is that if you don’t have great cell phone reception, well, you had best hope there’s an open gas station nearby.

Apple Maps
Google Maps for Apple at App Store
Google Maps on Google Play
Bing Maps 3D for Windows Phone

2. Inrix Traffic Maps, Routes, and Alerts

This traffic-centric app the leading choice for commuters with tight drop-off schedules because it offers the most detailed en route traffic reports. Inrix uses current and historical data to predict travel time for a list of saved destinations, and advises the best time to depart to get there. Setting apart Inrix from other apps are real-time fuel prices (for premium customers), live traffic cams, and push notifications alerting you of police radars in the area. Plus, it's free.

Inrix App for Apple at App Store
Inrix App on Google Play
Inrix App for BlackBerry
Inrix App for Windows Phone
Inrix App for Windows

3. TomTom

Since TomTom licensed its maps data to power Apple’s Maps, it’s hard to justify buying or subscribing to this spendy app. But unlike the free product, TomTom stores the map data on your mobile device, so you don’t need a data connection to get where you’re going, which is ideal for drivers in remote locations. Another feature available only with TomTom: the ability to purchase voices for the navigation prompts.

TomTom U.S.A. for Apple on the App Store ($49)
TomTom Places on Google Play ($45.99)

4. Waze

Powering the free Waze app is a dedicated community of road warriors committed to letting others know when streets close, when accidents happen, and when traffic just generally sucks. Community-supported mapping means that Waze offers a level of detail, such as known speed traps or red light cameras, and up-to-the-minute accuracy other apps miss. Further separating it from the competition is the ability to connect with other Waze-using friends on Facebook so you can know where and when everyone will arrive. The downside is that if you don’t live in a area with a lot of Waze users, you may experience stale content.

Waze Social GPS for Apple on the App Store
Waze Social GPS on Google Play
Waze Social GPS for Windows Phone

title: A Rolls-Royce Kitchen Make-Over
subTitle: The Rolls-Royce Wraith's bespoke designer reimagines my New York City kitchen.
promoTeaserSmall: The Rolls-Royce Wraith's bespoke designer reimagines my New York City kitchen.
promoTeaser: The Rolls-Royce Wraith's bespoke designer reimagines my New York City kitchen.
metaDescription: A Rolls-Royce Kitchen Make-Over: Rolls Bespoke designer Alex Innes helped me dream up the Rolls of kitchen remodels. See what we came up with on JeanKnowsCars.com..

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text: When I get around to renovating my eighty-four-square-foot NYC kitchen, I want to adapt the best features from a well-designed car. After years of being in the automotive business, I am constantly awed by the innovative ways that vehicles are engineered to be more streamlined, more efficient, more technologically advanced, and ultimately more sustainable.  With that in mind, I went straight to the top for advice.

At the recent reveal of the 2014 Rolls-Royce Wraith in Scottsdale, Arizona, I sat down with Alex Innes, bespoke designer for Rolls-Royce. Bespoke, in brief, means custom made. As in, you can have your Wraith coupe painted in a favorite shade of red nail polish, have your initials woven into the leather seats, or use a tree from your personal forest to outfit the interior. For any of your automotive whims or desires having to do with outfitting your Rolls-Royce, Innes is the go-to man.
After showing Innes my Pinterest folder of images of my non-bespoke (and rather cluttered and tiny) New York City kitchen, I asked him a few questions.
Holly Reich: Do you think you can do anything to help me streamline my small kitchen, taking cues from the Rolls-Royce Wraith?
Alex Innes: On the interior of the Rolls-Royce Wraith, our interior design philosophy is not to bombard the customer with a lot of choices. A kitchen should be clean and quiet.
HR: I’ll go with that. So, what is one of your favorite parts of the Wraith’s interior?

AI: I like the Canadel paneling in the cabin. [Canadel, an open-grain wood imported from Asia, has a light satin finish and is meant to suggest the feel of a super-luxury yacht.]

The Canadel would also be incredibly practical to use in your kitchen because it has a sealed polyester backer. The wood grain in the Wraith is matched up [the grains are at the same angle] throughout the interior; the same could be done in your kitchen.

From there I knew I had Innes's attention. I presented him with a sheet of white printer paper, and we both started sketching. By the way, I wasn’t so far off base. He told me that this is exactly the way he works with a bespoke Rolls-Royce client.
HR: Let’s start with the splash back behind the oven and sink.

AI: I can imagine using a strip of piano black paneling with Canadel wood above it. I would install a single strip of frosted glass—a glowing bar like the ones we have behind our door handles—between the two surfaces. As for the sideboard, I would use satin chrome.  We could hide the sink area with a hood. One would press a button to flip it up and expose the sink and drying board. And the tap would also rise as the hood sinks.
Inside the cupboard, we’d have something like self-ejecting parts. Like the butler is offering you the plate you want to use; you wouldn’t have to reach to get it.
HR: What about the cabinets?

AI: Our doors are hinged to open and close quietly, as would the cabinet doors in your kitchen. One would press a button to open and close them. Inside the cupboard, we’d have something like self-ejecting parts. Like the butler is offering you the plate you want to use; you wouldn’t have to reach to get it. It would be an offering device, like the umbrellas we have in the Wraith [an umbrella is stowed inside the driver’s door]. You would simply push a button, and whatever you need would pop out.
HR: Do you mean that the pots, pans, plates, and glasses could fold out?
AI: Yes. For instance, the plates would fan out on tiers. It’s the perfect mechanical solution.
HR: What should we line the cabinets with?
AI: They would be Canadel veneer on the bottom; the rest would be satin steel. And the angles of the wood would line up with the wood above the sink and the wood floor.
HR: Do you have any suggestions for the appliances?

AI: We would get the Rolls-Royce of refrigerators and appliances. [He suggested the stylish products of Smeg USA.] The refrigerator would have a glass front, to mimic the panoramic roofs on some of our vehicles.
HR: I would love to use that gorgeous aquamarine-colored glass you have in your vehicles for my lighting.
Oh, yes, that Lalique-like frosted look in our cars. We could use it as soft ambient boulevard lighting under the cabinets.

AI: Oh, yes, that Lalique-like frosted look in our cars. We could use it as soft ambient boulevard lighting under the cabinets. The spots would come from underneath the cabinets and light up the satin surface of the sideboards. We could also use the starlight headliner as pulsing overhead lights in the ceiling. [The starlight headliner on the Wraith features thousands of tiny fiber-optic lamps hand woven by craftspeople into the roof lining.]
HR: May I keep my blackboard?
AI: The key thing is that it’s a living space, so you want to enjoy it. I guess you could keep the blackboard. [I think he wasn’t too keen on it…]
HR: Any last touches?

AI: We have a guy in Goodwood who paints a narrow pinstripe by hand all the way around the top shoulder of the Wraith. You could have a hand-painted line on front of the cupboards in any color you choose.
HR: I think I’ll do a Salamanca blue, the color of the Rolls-Royce Wraith that I drove today.
Endnote: As driven, the Wraith I tested came in at $359,150, including destination charge. To outfit my Rolls-Royce kitchen would come in at around $75,000.

title: 2014 Kia Forte
promoTeaserSmall: This compact sedan was surprisingly drivable and undemanding. Should you buy one? Here's what I think.
promoTeaser: This compact sedan was surprisingly drivable and undemanding. Should you buy one? Here's what I think.
metaDescription: 2014 Kia Forte: Should you buy one? This compact sedan was surprisingly drivable. Read my review on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
2014 Kia Forte EX

Price: $20,315 as tested, including destination
Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 173 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 24 mpg city/36 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Cooling glove box
Option I can’t live without: Carpeted floor mats ($115) are the only option our test car came with
You might also be considering: Honda Civic, Mazda 3, Toyota Corolla

What I Think:

The 2014 Kia Forte is all new for 2014 and offers a host of upgrades from 2013’s model. The car is longer, lower, and wider than previous models, creating a more spacious interior. The new Forte also sports Kia’s Uvo infotainment suite, standard in our EX model, available heated seats, and a standard cooling glove box. The Forte is also eminently affordable. Our top trim level model cost just over $20,000 after destination, which makes it one of a relatively small group of cars that are genuinely affordable for first-time car buyers.

Despite all this, when I took hold of the keys to the Forte I wasn’t expecting to be won over. That’s because, for whatever reason, the Kia brand has never been particularly high on my list. Yes, they’ve got a bunch of interesting, attractive cars. And those hamster commercials are undeniably hilarious. But when I think of cars I’d like to own, I don’t think of Kia.

Still, I kept an open mind as I stepped up to the Forte for the first time. The redesigned exterior features a more aggressive grille and headlight design, as well as some sculpting on the body panels. It’s no supermodel, but these touches are a big improvement over last year’s model. The interior isn’t exactly what you’d call stunning, either; our model featured cloth seats that were already starting to look worn and ratty after just a few thousand miles in the press fleet.

Luckily, leather seat trim is available in the Forte’s Premium package. That package adds a hefty $2,600 to the price of the car, but I’d happily pay extra for the heated leather seating, power sunroof, and push-button start (the Premium package also adds ambient lighting, a six-way adjustable driver’s seat, and an auto-dimming rearview mirror). The Forte’s Technology package also costs $2,600. It adds navigation with HD radio, LED taillights, projector beam headlights, a color LCD driver information display in the dash, and automatic dual-zone climate control.

I was surprised to see that our Forte came standard with Kia’s Uvo infotainment suite. This system gives drivers a small 4.2-inch display with SiriusXM radio capability, a rearview camera, and optional navigation services. The system wasn’t as extensive as those offered by some other automakers, but it was simple and effective and a very good value. Infotainment suites are increasingly common, but it’s still impressive to see one in a car that’s priced below $20,000 before destination.

Driving the Forte felt pretty much like driving any other compact sedan. It’s not exciting, but it’s also not demanding. You can turn the key, point the car toward home, and forget you’re even driving. That’s not what I usually look for in a car, but for someone who just needs four wheels to get them to work and back, the Forte will be exactly right. The 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine makes 173 horsepower, plenty for normal driving. The EPA rates this engine at 36 mpg on the highway and 24 mpg in the city. That’s about middle of the pack (or even a little lower) compared with the Forte’s competition. A 1.8-liter, 148-horsepower four-cylinder, offered on the Forte’s lower LX trim, gets one extra city mile per gallon when outfitted with an automatic transmission.

The Verdict:

I wasn’t expecting to be impressed by or interested in the Forte, but Kia surprised me. This vehicle does a good job of providing drivability, technology, and style in an affordable package. It’s exactly the combination of features that young people buying their first car are looking for. But the Forte’s got a lot of competition. Would I choose a Kia Forte over a Mazda 3 or a Volkswagen Jetta? Probably not. For my money, both of those vehicles are more stylish and more fun to drive. That’s enough to make me cough up for their larger price tags. But there are people out there who will choose the Forte, and they’re not wrong.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly Jean: The Kia Forte looks great, and at $20,315, it makes sense for the pocketbook, too. The price alone may be enough to entice buyers to make the leap from the Volkswagen Jetta or the Honda Civic, which both cost several thousand more. The Forte's modern design beats both of them hands down, and it has a much younger, sportier vibe. I wasn't thrilled with the seats, though; the material seemed cheap, and I couldn't get comfortable.

title: I Met Rosie at the Willow Run Plant
promoTitle: I Met Rosie at the Willow Run Plant
promoTeaserSmall: I paid a final visit to Rosie the Riveter's old workplace and met some people who hope to save it.
promoTeaser: I paid a final visit to Rosie the Riveter's old workplace and met some people who hope to save it.
metaTitle: I Met Rosie at the Willow Run Plant - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: I Met Rosie at the Willow Run Plant: I paid a final visit to Rosie the Riveter's old workplace and met some people who hope to save it. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Sheer serendipity.  That’s how I became a contributor to Jean Knows Cars.  Well into a lovely dinner party, I received a most unlikely suggestion:  “You should write about cars from your perspective – a 4’11” single mother with a ten-year-old minivan who drives around three overactive children and a Bernese Mountain Dog.  Theatre, swimming, hockey, lacrosse, figure skating, field hockey… You love to tell stories. Tell them about cars.”  I suggested that my background possibly lacked necessary expertise – B.A. from Duke in art history and medieval/Renaissance studies; Fellow of the American Academy in Rome; Ph.D. from the University of Michigan in medieval architecture --  nothing about cars there!  My friend persisted, “You may be an art historian, but you are also a hockey mother who can whistle like a trucker, a runner, and a lover of good food, wine and the written word.”

I pondered.  The auto industry and I did have a long, if tangential, history.  I did a stint as an executive secretary to the president of a car dealership and spent fifteen years negotiating a dual identity as an academic and as auto company spouse.  I have always suffered from car envy, particularly acutely when I lived in Europe.  (As envy and lust are amongst the seven deadly sins, I’m in trouble.) Automobiles, functional objects that often shape image, are fundamental elements of today’s society.  This would be another mode of cultural analysis and critique.  Couched in that light, it made perfect sense!

(And, I really can whistle like a trucker, but louder. I may be an art historian, but don’t sit next to me at a hockey rink.)

pageElements.text: As I walked into the Arsenal of Democracy/Willow Run Conference, marking the closing of the Willow Run Bomber Plant near Ypsilanti, Michigan, and saw that the path to the conference room was lined with guides dressed up as “Rosie the Riveter,” I felt a little out of place.

When I hear the word "conference," I move into academic mode and expect talks of remote history, often laced with vocabulary drawn from impenetrable theoretical texts that only make sense when discussed over a bottle or two of wine.

No “Rosie the Riveters” generally line the halls, and the audience certainly isn’t filled with men in bomber jackets sporting baseball caps (and I don’t mean of the “swag” kind).  This, I quickly realized, was a distinctly manufacturing crowd, one present because of personal histories and intimate associations with the Willow Run Bomber Plant.

As an architectural historian, I am used to thinking about history and space.  The buildings I normally study, however, have few personal narratives attached to them. Short of a séance, I don’t have access to any twelfth-century citizens of Rome gathering together to tell me about their connection to their parish church.  So the most compelling, and perhaps the most important, element of this story of Willow Run is its human factor.  Those Rosies weren’t just there for a costume party.

Its interior space no longer of use to the new owners, Willow Run is slated for destruction. The Save the Bomber Plant Campaign hopes to preserve a small part of the building for a new Yankee Air Museum, a site dedicated to America’s aviation history and Detroit’s contribution to World War II. The campaign has until May 1, 2014, to raise $8 million.

As I listened to the history of the plant and then to the narratives of those in the audience, I began to see the significance of the Riveters and the larger importance of the campaign.  This story touches on the issues that drive urban history: the conflict between oblivion and preservation. Looking at it this way takes the conversation about the preservation of Willow Run from a story of local interest to one of more universal signifcance.

The Back Story

Willow Run is more than an exit off I-94 between Ann Arbor and Detroit. The bomber plant’s history is inextricably linked to the Detroit auto industry and its response to World War II. In 1940, the United States government, recognizing an urgent need to massively expand American production of military arsenal—everything from tanks to anti-aircraft guns to munitions to planes—turned to the auto industry, as only its mechanized processes of mass production could answer the need for such high volume at such a short period of time. It was a time of unprecedented cooperation among automakers; indeed, they agreed to suspend the 1943 model year to allow tool-and-die makers to work for the war effort.

Willow Run Bomber Plant, built by Henry Ford on his private land, came to represent the auto industry’s involvement in the war effort and in the country’s creation of an Arsenal of Democracy.  Ford had originally been commissioned to mass produce subassemblies for the B-24 and B-29 bombers, which were to be manufactured at Consolidated Aircraft. A team from Ford visited Consolidated’s California facility, noticed its lack of standardized modes of production, went home, and asked for (and received) total production of the B-24. So it was that on April 18, 1941, the ground was broken for the building of Willow Run.

Architecture by Albert Kahn

While the story of the plant’s significant contribution to the war effort surprised me, I was also struck by the fact that the factory was designed as a purpose-built site for airplane manufacture by the architect Albert Kahn. In its state today, the site looks unremarkable and unworthy of preservation. Yet Kahn, too, is inextricably linked to the auto industry in Detroit, and his firm singlehandedly transformed the landscape of southeastern Michigan in the first decades of the twentieth century. He was responsible for numerous factories, the Fisher Building in Detroit, and Hill Auditorium and Angell Hall at the University of Michigan. His challenge, to create an efficient industrial space, was shared by many architects in the first half of the century. Immediately, I thought of Frank Lloyd Wright’s Larkin Building, an iconic response to industry’s architectural needs.

Built in 1904 to house the corporate headquarters of the Larkin Soap Company, a national mail-order company, the structure answered the new demands of industry in a new century, with the executive offices rimming the perimeter while the center spaces housed the employees responsible for the company’s workings.  Kahn’s Willow Run answered different demands: his space had to account for the assemblage of airplanes with a wing span of 110 feet by what peaked at 42,000 workers.
The result was a streamlined factory, the largest in the United States, over a mile long and housing 3.5 million square feet of space, with doors on the receiving end that were 144 feet wide.

A Turning Point

The factory’s L-shape plan highlights the personality of its patron, Henry Ford, who demanded that the factory space stay within Washtenaw County and not cross the county line, lest he have to deal with Democratic Party forces in neighboring Wayne County. The factory space represents the progression of assembly, beginning with the clustered areas of parts assembly and ending with the open spaces for the fully built airplane. That disposition of the space of the factory has been lost since the day the last plane rolled out, but a sense of the unity of the factory design remains in Kahn’s one hallmark, the beautiful aesthetic of the lights that line his industrial spaces with, well, military precision.

Willow Run Bomber Plant represents a watershed moment in American labor practices. Before the war, women represented only eight percent of the automotive work force, but the demands of production at sites of the Arsenal of Democracy could not be met solely by men. At its peak, Willow Run was producing one B-24 bomber per hour. Such rates of production required the labor force of 42,000 workers, 40 percent of whom were women. Many of these women drew inspiration from the national propaganda campaign featuring Rosie the Riveter, an idealized strong, beautiful, patriotic woman who selflessly leapt into the workforce to help produce the items needed for war. Willow Run Bomber Plant employee Rose Will Monroe, one of many who migrated to the Detroit area from Kentucky, came to embody the ethos of Rosie the Riveter. She served in promotional films and on posters for the campaign that shifted labor practices in the twentieth century. And that's how, largely because of the Rosie campaign, this plant is identified with the somewhat inadvertent launching of a feminist movement.

The deepest historical significance of Willow Run is found in the people who worked there. Mike Schroder of Northville, Michigan, came to the conference because his mother had been a “Rosie.” He was carrying a picture of the plant from the 1940s of his mother and two other women on break. Schroder’s parents actually met at Willow Run. His father had been an aeronautical engineer from Ford, and his mother, like the real Rosie, had migrated from Kentucky. He was the product of love from the factory floor, as were many others in the audience. Jane Vass, the head “Rosie” at the event, became involved with the Save Willow Run campaign because her parents were Holocaust survivors, and she feels that were it not for the Arsenal of Democracy and the sacrifice of “Rosies,” her family line would not have survived.

The elegantly attired Margaret Strickland of Bloomfield Village, Michigan, had been a “Rosie” herself, not as a riveter, but as a worker in the blueprint department.  An Ann Arbor native attending the University of Michigan during the war years, Mrs. Strickland felt compelled to work at Willow Run in the summer of 1942 to do her part for the war effort.  She still has one of the drawings from her time at the plant: a beautiful section rendering of a B-24.  She says she admired it so much that one day she simply folded it up, stuck it in her coat, and snuck it out of the plant. Preserving a beautiful drawing?  She’s my kind of “Rosie.”

Willow Run Bomber Plant embodies a particular moment in United States history, when the automotive industry turned to industrial production for the Arsenal of Democracy, when the landscape of Michigan was changed, and when women entered the workforce in unprecedented numbers, unwittingly opening doors for women of future generations. For the week after the conference, I couldn’t stop thinking of the fate of Frank Lloyd Wright ’s Larkin building. Demolished in 1950, that iconic monument of industrial production was condemned to oblivion over the protests of historians. The complete destruction of Willow Run would be more than the destruction of an old building.  It would be to condemn a space, and therefore its history, to oblivion.
Let’s hear it for those “Rosies” and their determination to preserve an important piece of Detroit’s—and America’s—history.

metaDescription: First Woman CEO!  General Motors names Mary Barra to the top job. We're popping the champagne corks. Read the story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: Pop the champagne corks! There is a momentous news flash today. General Motors has named Mary Barra, 51, its next chief executive officer.
The announcement came from chairman and CEO Dan Akerson, and Barra will take the title of CEO when Akerson steps down at the first of the year.
If anyone wants to know how far General Motors has come since the Troubles? Mary Barra becomes the first female CEO of a car company in history.

Mary Barra has been quickly gaining gravitas. She came out of HR to be named head of global product development, and then earlier this year added global head of product purchasing. I know her, and I've always liked her. Her persona is best older sister. Her personality is calm in the eye of a storm. She is passionate about General Motors and passionate about the people who work there, and she has teenagers. In fact, she recently blew out the stodgy GM dress code and was quoted in Businessweek saying, “So you’re telling me I can have you responsible for tens of millions of dollars, but I can’t trust you to dress appropriately?”

The only other candidate for this job in our eyes was Mark Reuss, who is president of General Motors North America. He is a consummate product guy, which is really what this business is about: great product. But it makes sense to keep your product guy in a position where he won't be burdened by the compromises that frequently have to be made in big business. 
As enthusiasts, we were pulling for him, but the argument against putting your product guy at the top was in fact, his own father, a great product guy, who took a fall as a scapegoat for the problems of General Motors. When Lloyd Reuss lost his position on the board, General Motors and all its customers lost a great product guy.

In my estimation, Mary Barra only has to do a couple of things. The cars can't break; she has to manage production so the cars aren't overproduced; and she has to make GM manage incentives so they don't take over and ruin the gains that have been made in the past few years.
More important is that she has to count on Mark Reuss, who has highly refined product sensibilities, and Ed Welburn, who has done a masterful job bringing General Motors design out of the darkness.
It's an incredible team. And the fact that it is going to be run by a woman is one of the most amazing feelings I have had in a really, really long time.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: My husband and I were invited by Jaguar to go to the contemporary-art event known as Art Basel in Miami and South Beach, which I've always wanted to do. It was the art world equivalent of going to Pebble Beach. When you get there, you discover there are numerous events spread across a wide area that take a car to get to, only everyone else is also in their cars, so it's a constant massive traffic jam. It's an offshoot of the original event, which is in Basel, Switzerland.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/f0eBZx5llak" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
The real selling points were these. Miami: eighty-five degrees and sunny skies for the whole weekend.  Detroit: snow, single-digit temperatures, winds all weekend. Jaguar F-Type convertible.
This was an easy decision.

There were a lot of "lifestyle press" there: food writers, art people, a very eclectic group. Jaguar put us up at the Mondrian South Beach Hotel, another in an increasing number of avant-garde hotels in all the world's hot spots. L.A. and Miami are very similar places, with all these uber-hip hotels that are puzzling and disconcerting and inundated with techno versions of jazz, techno versions of folk, techno rock and roll, and techno techno. You can't escape it: it's in the pool, it's in the elevator, it's in the lobby, and it's crazy.
The decor of the room was intriguing. It had this blue Delft-like porcelain-tiled kitchen area, and upon closer inspection, the tiles were old beach scenes.

The room was vast, although there wasn't a lot of closet space. There were a lot of long horizontal shelves lining the room. In the bathroom, the shelf was like a long trough that ended under a faucet, so you put your stuff on the far left of the trough/shelf and wondered, when you turned on the faucet, if the water was going to run up and get your stuff wet, but it didn't. There was a chandelier in the shower surrounding the shower head, and when you woke up in the morning you were staring at an orange wall mirror on your left and a giant disembodied Barbie head with Miley Cyrus hair staring at you. These Barbie heads were also in the lobby on the walls. This was the beginning of me not understanding the art I was about to see, but at least it was eighty-five degrees.

Every space in the Mondrian was bigger than life. The portico had giant gold lampshade-shaped structures hanging over it, with chandeliers inside of them. You can't stop looking. The buildings were very white, and there was a lot of Moroccan-patterned grillework and wallpapers.

I was undoubtedly the least hip person staying there this weekend and the most normal person there, other than the fact that I did bring some hats. Frequently you'd get on the elevator next to an impossibly tall model, meaning 6'4", with a Russian accent.

The next morning, we met at 9:30 a.m. in the chandeliered portico, and there was a lineup of Jag F-Type convertibles, which was really why I was there. There were two garish F-Types done in the Union Jack motif with F-Type written on the doors. The head of PR told me, "This is one of the ones you're going to drive," and I started laughing, and he said,  "No, seriously," and I kept laughing. I have enough trouble with my driving record without driving one of these down to the Keys with the top down. Instead I was given an incredibly gorgeous orange F-Type that looked fantastic.

Once I slid behind the wheel of this 2014 Jaguar F-Type S V8 convertible in Firesand orange, the most hilarious thing to me was to listen to the description for the obviously non-automotive journalists around me about how to turn the car on and practice putting its automatic transmission shift lever in and out of gear. You can understand the very careful instruction by Jag. The car I was in had a total suggested retail price of $100,370 (including destination charge). Now you can imagine sliding some art critic from New York City behind the wheel of one of those cars. It was hilarious listening to them all around me under the portico revving the engine over and over again like they'd never enjoyed the noise of a big V-8 before.

What was even funnier was when, while one food critic from L.A. was revving and revving and obviously enjoying it, my husband slid into the seat next to him and pressed a button on the console, the one I call the Harmonic Maximizer, but which is actually called Active Sport Exhaust. It has the icon of an exhaust system, and it funnels more noise into the cabin. When my husband pressed it and suddenly the roar magnified, the guy lifted a foot off his seat in response to the gigantic blast of noise. He looked absolutely terrified and then burst out laughing. Exactly right, dude. The sound of the test drive at stoplights, at red lights, and in parking lots was the lifestyle press around me revving and revving and revving their engines like ten-year-olds. Like me, the first time I got my finger on that button.

The F-Type already starts out with a really great 495-horsepower 5.0-liter supercharged V-8. Not only that, it's one of the most beautiful convertibles on the planet, with a top that opens and/or closes in twelve seconds flat and looks sleek in either position.

What a great way to settle into the weekend. I wasn't sure where I was going or how to get there. I didn't quite understand the lay of the land. What I did understand was getting into this hot convertible, putting the top down, and blasting into the Florida Keys. The water is so beautiful. The sky was fantastic. Did I mention that it was eighty-five  degrees? Am I tan yet?

We went down to Isla Morada, stopped at the Cheeca Lodge and Resort, and had a spectacular lunch al fresco. The sugar sand stopped at the edge of the cement we were sitting on while we had lunch. I never wanted to leave. We probably stayed about thirty minutes too long, though, because, as we re-emerged from Key Largo, heading north to Miami, the traffic got thicker and thicker and the navigation system kept adjusting our arrival time until it was an hour later than it had started at Isla Morada.
Let's make no mistake and think that a drive down a straight road into the Florida Keys is going to exercise this car at all.

Even stop-and-go traffic is bearable when it's eighty-five degrees and you're in an equally hot car. A half-dozen times in the traffic jam, people who were slowly inching past shouted out, "I love your car!" I yelled back: "So do I, only it's not mine. I wish I owned it."

Let's make no mistake and think that a drive down a straight road into the Florida Keys is going to exercise this car at all. The only thing that got exercised was the Active Sport Exhaust button and the convertible top.
In the end, it was just a fine little road trip, said the girl from Michigan.

That evening, we hit the art scene at  an event called Wallpaper* Handmade with Jaguar in Miami. The premise was that everything in the exhibit was an object—luggage, an outdoor barbecue grill, a giant box of tools, an armagnac tasting cabinet with crystal decanters—made by artists, with manufacturing sponsorship. In the middle of it was the Jaguar C-X17 crossover. This is a handmade one-off concept car that was totally appropriate to the art exhibit.
We wandered through, then back out, off to dinner, and then to bed.

On Friday, I had to temporarily abandon Miami and fly in to Atlanta, joining the crowd of people pouring in for the Auburn-Alabama game. I was there to appear on CNN, which by the way was right next to the stadium, to talk about American car quality with the effervescent Poppy Harlow. It was forty-two degrees; who would think? I had left my coat in Miami, thinking I was down south. I got back to Miami in time to see Piston Head, an exhibit that our contributor Tamara Warren was totally tuned in to. She arranged for me to meet the curator, Adam Lindemann, who owns the gallery Venus Over Manhattan in New York City. The venue was an upper floor of an incredible parking structure, designed by the famous Swiss architecture firm Herzog & de Meuron of Basel, Switzerland. The guy who bought the space tore down the existing building and hired the Swiss firm to build the parking structure with a penthouse on the top floor.

Curator Lindemann loves cars, and he decided to find artists who also love cars. It took some time, wrangling, and a bit of corporate sponsorship from Ferrari to bring all of these cars to Miami Beach. The day couldn't have been more perfect to walk around high above the street with the breeze blowing and a great view of Miami and palms and blue sky backing the wild cars displayed around me. Yes, there were a few cars I didn't understand, but that's art for you. Below is a gallery of some of the photos I took during the weekend. You will also be able to see Tamara Warren's writing about Art Basel soon, here on JeanKnowsCars.com and in Automobile Magazine.

It was all perfect. Sadly, the weather at home this December is more like the weather we're supposed to get in January: howling winds, swirling snow, and single-digit temperatures. But I'm a Michigander, and the reality is, that's my home, and that's where I had to return. Sniff.

title: 2013 Toyota Avalon Limited
promoTeaserSmall: I think its new look is more like its glamorous Lexus cousins. But what does the Peanut Gallery say?
promoTeaser: I think its new look is more like its glamorous Lexus cousins. But what does the Peanut Gallery say?
metaDescription: 2013 Toyota Avalon Limited: The older sister of the glamorous Lexus is showing off its all-new look and feel. Like it? I do. See it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $42,449 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 268 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 21 mpg city/31 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Heated seats front and back
Option I can’t live without: Precollision braking system (part of Technology package, $1,750)
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Impala, Chrysler 300, Lincoln MKZ, Lexus ES, Nissan Maxima

See more specs on the Avalon in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

There may be no better evidence that Toyota is trying to move away from its stodgy image than the 2013 Avalon. Long considered the old-man car in the lineup, the Toyota flagship has changed a lot with its complete overhaul for 2013 and now looks every bit as upscale as the Lexus ES, its slightly pricier cousin. You would be forgiven if you walked up to this car, with its strikingly swoopy sides and low profile, and didn’t realize this was a Toyota. It’s downright sleek and modern, absolutely without a doubt the first Avalon that will turn heads.

It’s also turned into an all-American product. There’s that big grille that reminds me of the current Ford Fusion's, and there’s the fact that it was designed and developed at Calty Design Research in California and the Toyota Technical Center right here in Ann Arbor, and it's built in Kentucky.

The redesign does not extend to the engine: it has Toyota’s tried-and-true 3.5-liter V-6 with a six-speed automatic transmission, yielding 268 horsepower. There is also a hybrid Avalon with the merit of not costing a huge premium over the standard model, starting just over $35,000 and offering 40 mpg.

Consumer Reports, usually ready to approve of a Toyota, gave this completely redesigned Avalon a score of 85 out of 100 points and its top rating for predicted reliability. However, the publication criticized the ride feel as “stiffened too much.”

Now, maybe I am driving too many sporty cars—if there’s such a thing as too many—but this was far from the stiffest car I’ve driven in the past week, let alone unacceptably stiff. Toyota did want to add a little dash of sportiness to this new model, and in that sense it succeeded. The automaker described it as "reinventing Avalon's roadgoing character." In my view, that's a good thing. I wouldn't be surprised if those changes lose Toyota a few customers who liked a more traditionally soft ride, though.
You won't forget you're inside a Toyota because it's no-nonsense, but there's enough understated comfort to reward your decision to go a bit upmarket.

Over smooth roads or at moderate speeds, the car still has the buttery feel of a Lexus, and that’s no surprise, since they’re under the Toyota umbrella, too. What it doesn’t have is the high-cholesterol price of a Lexus: this extremely well-appointed full-size sedan cost $42,449 with everything on it. Compare that with the cost of a similarly equipped Lexus ES, its platform mate, which tops out at $46,420. Toyota hasn't raised the price of the Avalon for 2014, either.  Now, once you get into the $40,000-and-up shopping category, those few grand may not matter compared with the opportunity to drive a Lexus-badged car. But having the Lexus badge is not a selling point for everybody, including Toyota-brand loyalists and those looking for space and comfort more than status.

But setting aside all talk of driving excitement, check out the interior of the Avalon. I certainly did. The black, brown, and tan combination, and the smooth textures and curving lines, all definitely worked for me. The stitching on the leather seats was particularly nice. You won't forget you're inside a Toyota because it's no-nonsense, but there's enough understated comfort to reward your decision to go a bit upmarket. I love the dual-screen setup that lets you look at an analog clock, temperatures, and HVAC settings below while maintaining a separate screen of audio or navigation information above.

The Limited model, top of the Avalon line, comes with such higher-end features as a power tilting/sliding moonroof, HID headlights, rain-sensing wipers, and paddle shifters for the automatic transmission. Safety features included on the Limited include a blind spot monitor and rear cross-traffic alert. The Technology package ($1,750) adds automatic high-beam headlights, dynamic radar cruise control, and a precollision braking system. That latter item is one of my favorite technological advances. I'm looking forward to the day when nobody smashes into the back of anybody else ever again.
For 2014, Toyota makes the rearview camera a standard feature on all levels of Avalon, but otherwise, the made-over model has no substantive changes, including to the price.

The Verdict:

I was glad that modernizing the Avalon didn’t take away some of the old-school comforts that the car was known for before. The tri-tone interior, the classy analog clock and leather surfaces, and the general feeling of prosperous ease are all there, but there’s value added in the form of a more interesting ride. You don’t feel detached from the road in an old-person way. I’m guessing some people will miss that cushioned feeling, but it’s likely that even more people will appreciate the driving experience of the revised Avalon.

You might ask, why buy a $40,000 Toyota when you can move into a Lexus? Well, there are many people who would be more attracted to the flagship Toyota than the lower-end Lexus. Maybe they’re coming up from a Camry or over from another large car, and what they want is more luxury at less of a price increase. Those people are out there, and they deserve to be given as appealing a choice as this Avalon. If you’re one of them, or even if you don't think you are, try this car with an open mind.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly Jean: The Avalon is a sleeping giant: a premium large sedan for the buyer who wants luxury, but doesn't need to show off. The passenger space seems huge, as does the trunk. You could actually take this on a road trip with four adults and be comfortable. But the very best part is the price. The base model starts at $31,800.

Annie White: I was surprised by how much I liked driving this car. It is spacious and comfortable, and the V-6 engine felt capable and powerful. On the other hand, I fell far short of the 21-mpg city rating during my drives around town, and I wasn't a fan of the infotainment system's touch surfaces or the tri-tone interior treatment. Not quite right for me, but I can imagine this car making many other drivers very happy.
