contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
2013 Land Rover LR4

Price: $63,670 as tested (including destination)
Engine: 5.0-liter V-8, 375 horsepower, 375 pound-feet of torque
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 12 mpg city/17 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Seven-inch color touchscreen with USB and iPod connectivity
Option I can’t live without: Seven-seat LUX package ($9,225)
You might also be considering: BMW X5, Lexus GX, Acura MDX

Access to a fleet of brand-new press cars and company-funded gas cards are two of the best perks of my job. They’re also the reasons that I end up making plans like this one: one of my oldest friends, who recently moved to California, told me she would be in Connecticut at the annual Harvard-Yale rivalry football match on the afternoon of Saturday, November 23. Connecticut, I thought, is much closer to Michigan than San Francisco is. I’ve got a car that weekend. I’ve never been to Connecticut before. In those circumstances, a three-day, 1,400-mile round trip makes perfect sense.

My car for the weekend was a 2013 Land Rover LR4. To my way of thinking, this is a truly unattractive automobile with the off-road capability of a small tank and an interior swathed in luxury. It would be nearly perfect as a road trip vehicle if it weren’t for its prodigious appetite for premium gasoline. If I’d been paying for it myself, the weekend’s wanderings would have cost me more than $400 in fuel. At that point, you may as well fly.

It’s not only the fuel that’s expensive. Just getting into an LR4 requires a largish bank account. My test car came with more than $13,000 in options, tipping the scales at $63,670 after destination. Standard equipment on the LR4 includes a 5.0-liter V-8 engine making 375 horsepower, keyless entry with push-button start, a seven-inch color touchscreen infotainment system, and, of course, total off-road competence. My car’s options got us twenty-inch wheels with blackout rims, black lacquer accents on the interior and exterior, black leather interior trim and seats, a cooler box in the center console, and an 825-watt, seventeen-speaker Harman Kardon sound system. With all that and more, I figured the nine-hour drive would be a piece of cake.

And it was. I stocked the cooler box with drinks and a few snacks before taking off (although I was sad to find that the glass bottle of Coke that I’d bought on a whim was too tall to fit; it was enjoyed warm). The LR4 had more than enough oomph to get us up to highway speed, but I did feel a little like I was driving a barn down the road. Once I got used to its trucklike manners, though, I quite enjoyed my time behind the wheel of the LR4.

Unfortunately, that time was frequently interrupted by trips to the gas station. Although it was rated to earn 17 mpg on the highway, we were lucky to break 15. The LR4’s tank is nearly 23 gallons, which seems like a lot. But when you put those numbers together, you only get about 300 miles between fill-ups. The makers of diesel and hybrid vehicles are marketing range as the ultimate in luxury. Land Rover still needs some convincing.

It felt like a waste to drive this off-roading mobile on the smooth highways of New England, but Saturday morning’s drive to New Haven proved that I was hardly the only person in Connecticut wasting a Land Rover’s capabilities. Range Rovers were practically a dime a dozen, universally gleaming and spotless, looking like they’ve never been off the pavement in their lives.
It’s not quite the status symbol that the Range Rover is, but it still carries the benefits of the Land Rover badge, and for a relatively reasonable sum.

Our LR4 came equipped with an optional third row as part of the $9,225 Seven-seat LUX package. Those seats were tiny and hard and are best enjoyed when folded flat to create more room for luggage in the cargo area. The second-row seats, on the other hand, were comfortable and had plenty of legroom. I gave my friend a ride to the train station after Harvard’s 34-7 trouncing of Yale, and she stretched out in the back seat and fell asleep almost immediately, only waking for a few minutes to eat the chicken nuggets I bought her at the McDonald’s drive-through.

After a very comfortable and successful weekend in the LR4, I was almost looking forward to the long drive home. I’d hooked my up iPod to one of the two USB ports stashed in the center console and was listening to the fourth Harry Potter book on tape (if you can still call it that when it’s actually an MP3) and scarfed down a Wendy’s Baconator for dinner, my absolute favorite fast food meal. I hit a patch of near-whiteout weather in the mountains and confidently switched the LR4 into snow mode, thankful for the snow tires I’d noticed earlier in the week. I tested the brakes and detected not even a hint of trouble on deceleration. No sweat.

Sadly, my peaceful drive home was not to be. Somewhere in the middle of Pennsylvania, what I’d taken to be mild carsickness that afternoon turned into an emergency stop on the side of the freeway and me losing my dinner in the snow on the shoulder. I soldiered on for three more hours, slowly coming to think of the LR4 as a prison of misery. Half a state and several panic stops later, I threw in the towel and spent the night at a hotel outside Cleveland before limping home to Michigan the following afternoon.

I can no longer think of my time with the Land Rover LR4 without thinking of the worst nine-hour drive I’ve ever had. Before all the wretchedness, though, the LR4 proved itself a worthy choice for a cross-country outing. The luxurious interior was spacious and comfortable, the ride was smooth, and the car felt capable. It’s not quite the status symbol that the Range Rover is, but it still carries the benefits of the Land Rover badge, and for a relatively reasonable sum. I would have been sorry to see it go, if only I could have forgotten the amount of fuel the LR4 sucked down. I’m no tree hugger, but with every mile I thought of oil-soaked sea birds and smog-covered cities. If I ever own one of these, I’ll have to buy a Nissan Leaf as my second car for days when my conscience feels heavy.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: Often, when it comes to hotels that allow pets, you're settling for a place that is, shall we say, not as luxurious as you might otherwise choose.
Instead, you might want to have a look at the Affinia Hotels website, which specifically targets dog owners with its VIPaws Pet program.
Does this look like the kind of place you might imagine when you hear of a pet-friendly hotel?
I didn't think so. This is actually a pretty luxurious hotel chain, and it makes a point of inviting people to bring their pets.

What's the catch? The hotels are mainly in New York and Washington, D.C., but other than that, they seem to have the pet thing figured out. For an added $25 pet fee ($50 in a few top-end hotels), your pet gets "select" food and water bowls, an oversize pet bed from the upscale New York City shop Jax and Bones, and rope toys for dogs or other, unnamed toys for cats. Even dog stairs if your pet needs them, and a special door hanger that lets staff know there's a dog in your room. Discounts on local pet products and services, plus a map of dog-friendly destinations nearby—and a leash-mounted waste bag dispenser, so you can take your dog there on foot—complete the package. Last but not least, $10 of the fee is donated to the Humane Society.

If you're traveling farther afield, the website Pet Friendly Accommodations Worldwide lists only hotels that are rated at least three stars. Such cushy spots as the Fairmont in Chicago, the Eliot in Boston, and the Milestone in London (right) are represented, with details on surcharges (ranging from $25 to $75), pet size limitations, and whether there's a treat or welcome gift for your pet on arrival. It's good one-stop shopping if you are planning a trip somewhere with a pet and don't want to stoop to a questionable room at a low-end motel just because you've got your dog with you.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pages.metaDescription: What is the FXI, and what does it mean to car buyers and manufacturers?
pages.metaTitle: Honda and Mercedes hit a high note in customer satisfaction
pages.name: index

pageElements.text:
If you're the sort of person who doesn't pay much attention to surveys and analytics report, this one might change your mind: a new report by analytics company ForeSee ranks how people feel about brands, not individual products. As the company describes it, the report measures satisfaction at "the customer relationship level." The top two car brands this year: Mercedes-Benz and Honda, based on satisfaction levels of recent car buyers.

It's a little different from the better-known J.D. Power and Associates reports, which rank consumer experience with specific models. This is the first time the Ann Arbor, Michigan, company has issued The ForeSee Experience Index (FXI), which uses a set of complex data gathered from over 25,000 surveys across the top 100 brands in seven industries, including the automotive industry, as a way to quantify how customers feel about those brands.

ForeSee questioned panels of 200 to 250 recent auto buyers, grouped together by the vehicle brand they own. Larry S. Freed, President and CEO of ForeSee, explains, “We look at a model of customer satisfaction that includes price, product, and service: Is the cost fair? Does the product meet expectations? Is service at a high level, meaning, are companies keeping their promises?”

Mercedes and Honda scored highest in satisfaction with a rating of 85; Ford and Toyota followed with 83, while Hyundai, BMW, Chevrolet, and Audi each scored 82 points. Trailing a few points behind were Nissan and Volkswagen at 79 and Kia with a 78.

ForeSee also listed the top priorities for auto brands. For many manufacturers, price has the biggest impact on customer satisfaction: "the products provide value and are worth the price." Among those are top-scoring Honda, but also low-scoring Kia and Volkswagen. Service ("the company keeps its promises...the employees are friendly") had the biggest impact on satisfaction at BMW and Nissan, among others. For the high-scoring Mercedes-Benz, having "desirable, unique" products was the essential element in customer satisfaction.

“Satisfaction is a lot about expectations” is Freed’s message to automakers. “Expectations of a BMW are going to be very different than a Kia.” When tabulating the FXI score, ForeSee takes these perceptions into account, acknowledging that buyers assess a product's value according how they view the brand.

This is all very interesting, but it's also good news for us. We as consumers stand to benefit when auto companies have a deeper and more nuanced understanding of what drives our buying habits.
Photos courtesy of Rick Case Honda and Hoehn Mercedes

pageElements.text: The insurance industry's nonprofit, the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, has just issued its list of 2014 Top Safety Pick+ winners, and the emphasis is all on that little plus sign. The IIHS testing, like Common Core standards in the public schools, has been toughened to require Good ratings, the top score, in four different crash tests, plus at least a Basic rating for front crash prevention technology. Still, twenty-two vehicles were named Top Safety Pick+, with an additional fifteen getting the Top Safety Pick rating for 2014.

The Top Safety Pick award originated in 2006, but Top Safety Pick+ was new last year. IIHS calls it "the next level of safety" because Plus winners are those that have systems that can keep crashes from happening or mitigate the damage from them. The crash tests it administers are side, roof strength, head restraint, and small overlap front (in which 25 percent of the driver's side front is crashed into a rigid barrier at 40 mph). IIHS rates front crash prevention systems on a scale of Basic, Advanced, and Superior, evaluating the presence of either standard or optional forward collision warning and autobrake technology. A car qualifies for the Basic rating if it meets the performance criteria of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA), IIHS said.

The fact that the organization is keeping a firm hand on the standard is good news for anyone shopping for a new car right now, even though the winner's circle is a lot smaller in 2014. Last year saw a list of 130 total Top Safety Pick and Top Safety Pick+ winners. Some dropped from the 2014 list because they simply haven't been tested yet; others haven't met the small overlap test standard (the test is shown at right). IIHS hastens to note that the 2013 winners still met "a high level of protection in four main crash types" even if they didn't repeat as winners.

See the IIHS website for the complete list of Top Safety Pick and Top Safety Pick+ winners for 2014.

Who won?

Without further ado, here are the vehicles that garnered the Top Safety Pick+ rating:

New this year:
Acura MDX and RLX
Infiniti Q50
Mazda 3 and CX-5
Toyota Highlander and Prius
Volvo S80

Winners with crash prevention as standard equipment:
Honda Civic Hybrid
Volvo S60, S80, and XC60

And:
Ford Fusion
Honda Accord (two- and four-door) and Odyssey
Lincoln MKZ
Mazda 6
Mercedes-Benz M-Class
Mitsubishi Outlander
Subaru Forester, Legacy, and Outback

title: 2014 Fiat 500L Easy
subTitle: The Italian icon has expanded to MPV size. Is it adorable or bloated? Here's what we think.
promoTeaserSmall: The Italian icon has expanded to MPV size. Is it adorable or bloated? Here's what we think.
promoTeaser: The Italian icon has expanded to MPV size. Is it adorable or bloated? Here's what we think.
metaDescription: 2014 Fiat 500L Easy: The Italian icon has expanded to MPV size. Is it adorable or bloated? Here's what we think. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
2014 Fiat 500L Easy

Price: $25,545 as tested, including destination
Engine: 1.4-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 160 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 24 mpg city/33 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Glass A-pillars
Option I can’t live without: Rearview camera and ParkSense rear park assist (both part of Premier package, $1,745)
You might also be considering: Kia Soul, Nissan Cube, Mini Cooper Countryman

What I Think:

I had been waiting eagerly since the hottest days of summer to get into Fiat's new 500L, and when my turn finally arrived, it was during the first snowstorm of the season. Well, that's part of the package when you live in Michigan, but instead of fulfilling my dream of la dolce vita with the sun streaming through the imported windows of the boxy "urban utility vehicle" from Fiat, I was scraping a thick layer of snow and ice off the windows. Instead of joyriding, carefree, around downtown Ann Arbor, I was gingerly navigating icy roads. But it wasn't all bad; I only had to unstick from drifts on the roadside twice in one day.

Seriously, though, the real test of livability is whether adverse conditions will still make you enjoy a car. You're not going to have ideal weather every day when you own it, after all. So, in a roundabout way, I enjoyed trying out the 500L in the snow for what it told me about the real-world ownership experience.

The 500L answers a question that I'm not sure who asked: What if you love the idea of a cute little Fiat, but you need a bigger car? Fiat is obviously looking to put a competitor up against the Mini Countryman, the Kia Soul, and the Nissan Cube in the stylish-box category, and to give American buyers a reason to buy a Fiat instead of a small crossover like a Kia Sportage. The fact that this one starts just under $20,000 is a definite enticement to the first-time car buyer or, really, anybody who is in the market for an affordable vehicle. There are four levels to the 500L lineup: the entry-level Pop, which costs $19,995 with destination charge; the Easy, the car we tested, which starts at $20,995; the higher-end Lounge, and the off-road-styled Trekking (which only looks rugged).

I happen to really like the way the 500L looks, and my eighteen-year-old son, Henry, a cranky iconoclast whose tastes run to ancient Volvos, agreed with me as he climbed into the passenger's seat. The body shape reminds me of the Steve Jobs insistence on rounded edges on Apple's icons. Just from feedback around me, I already know that it's not to everyone's taste, but Henry and I think it's seriously cute.

You hop in, and the first thing you notice is sterling visibility. I particularly appreciated the clear glass A-pillars, paired with clear glass D-pillars in the back corners. These create a nearly 360-degree view, even though it meant I had more windows to scrape ice off. I couldn't enjoy the power sunroof ($950) since it was obscured by more ice, but on a nicer day or one where I felt more inclined to clear off the roof of the car, I would have.

I was less a fan of the interior than I thought I'd be. The two-tone seats are not that comfortable, and the mainly grey ("Cementite") with black trim in the midlevel Easy model we had, I suspect, would start to look dirty in a matter of a few months. They do come in other colors; I'd go for dark surfaces myself. And then, the overall feeling was just not quirky. Compared with, say, the goofy instrument panel of the Smart Fortwo or the Mini Countryman, the switchgear was bland and disappointingly ordinary. A notable exception was the excellent Beats audio system, a $700 package that included SiriusXM with a one-year subscription. The heated front seats ($350) were much appreciated given the weather and, I increasingly believe, a must-have on a new car for anyone in cool climates. There were several non-skid surfaces and cubbies for placing phones and other devices, including a nice open shelf below the glove box, and connectivity was, as you'd expect, completely up to date.

But what counts more than looks inside a car is how safe you feel, and the Fiat 500L can compete with the heavy hitters in that department. It was named a Top Safety Pick in 2013 by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, garnering the top Good rating in all tests. It only missed the latest 2014 rating, issued this week, because Fiat doesn't offer front crash prevention technology (such as forward collision warning systems), a new IIHS requirement this year. The 500L is fitted with front and rear head curtain airbags and front seat-mounted torso airbags. There's also a separate driver's-side knee airbag in the lower instrument panel to help mitigate knee injuries in front crashes. Although the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration hasn't yet crash tested the 500L, the Top Safety Pick verdict means I'd feel confident in getting this car for one of my kids. (Sorry, Henry, not anytime soon.)

The 500L may be targeted at space-hungry Americans, but it's thoroughly European. It is built in Serbia, in the same plant that used to make the Yugo, but let's not think about that one too long and hard. The engine is sourced in Italy and, despite the Chrysler connection, the car has zero North American content. You're buying the Italian dream, and Fiat has done well in marketing the car that way.

That makes sense, since I think much of the appeal of buying a Fiat is the self-indulgence of owning a European car with a romantic pedigree. European streets are filled with tiny MPVs similar to the 500L: the Ford B-Max, the Citroen C3 Picasso, the Opel Meriva, and others. But, rising gas prices notwithstanding, it's not clear to me whether Americans really want one of those. We are still interested in having power at our disposal when we need it, and the 1.4-liter four, even though it's turbocharged, was not as vigorous as I'd like when I accelerate.

The Verdict:

I will stop short of saying I was dashing through the snow in the 500L, but the one-horse part is partly right. Perhaps because I did need that extra bit of pep to cope with the weather, I felt—and colleague Molly Jean agreed with me—that this Fiat seemed a little underpowered. That's interesting, because the 1.4-liter MultiAir turbo is the same engine I enjoyed in the Dodge Dart. Maybe there's something about the minibus seating position in the 500L that makes you feel you're just toddling along. And maybe, on a nicer, more carefree driving day, it would have mattered less.

If you are attracted to Fiats, I am not sure this 500L will do it for you aesthetically; I feel the same way about the Mini Countryman. These expanded models no longer seem like the minicars their makers started with, and if what you really want is a Mini Cooper or a 500, you might want to just go ahead and get one. On the other hand, if you are looking at other cubist products, or a small crossover, or if your budget means you need a car in the low $20,000s, the 500L is an interesting alternative. You won't see these coming and going, no matter what the weather.

Peanut Gallery:

Annie White: The 500L is an odd little car, and it looks too much like a bloated panda for me to consider it attractive. But if you can get past the exterior (or if you're one of the people who love it), the rest of the car has a lot to recommend it. The interior feels airy, spacious, and much more practical than the tiny 500. For the price, it has good standard and optional equipment. The back seats aren't terribly comfortable, but you could put adults back there and they wouldn't immediately complain. It may not be the right quirky car for me, but it could be the right one for you!

Scott Allen: I agree with Annie about the 500L's body. I think it has blowfish qualities. Maybe that roundness is what makes it feel so spacious inside. Everything was pretty easy to reach, although I didn't really like the controls for the audio system with its push buttons to go from one channel to the next. It was slow and distracting. And I didn't really understand the Euro Twin Clutch automatic transmission, but I also felt the car lacked power. I wouldn't buy the 500L because it just doesn't feel as serious to me as something like a Honda Civic.

Molly Jean: Unfortunately, the Fiat 500L leaves me teetering on the edge of adoration. It does not have the same level of attention to design and style that the 500 boasts. To me, it looks rather bloated. It appears to me that design decisions were compromised to make this car more attractive to the space-obsessed American market. The choice of materials seems cheap, and I especially think the seat material feels and looks bargain basement. And, where is the sublime mint green exterior paint choice? However, bravo to those same designers, because once inside, it feels downright spacious. What the 500L loses in style cred, it gains in affordability and usefulness. With its $19,995 base price (including destination), the 500L would definitely be a contender if I was buying my daughter a spankin' new vehicle. But I wouldn't put the ribbon on it until I purchased some aftermarket seat covers. As for myself, I'll take a pass.

Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: Every now and then—not often—the professional automotive journalist is faced with the horror of renting a car. This is my story.

Bob the Reluctant Show Dog had decamped for Florida for the AKC/Eukanuba National Championship in Orlando, Florida. My husband, the ever optimistic Tim, had packed Bob in his crate in the back of one of Automobile Magazine’s long-term test vehicles for the 2,400-mile round trip. I was flying around on business, so I veered south to join them. Only they were leaving immediately after the show, and I planned an extra day to go up to Saint Augustine and visit Hurley Haywood's new house.

So I needed to get a rental car. When I arrived, I went to Hertz, and they upgraded my basic rental to a Chevrolet Cruze LT. First of all, it was a gorgeous brown color that looked really nice. You never know what to expect; I’ve had some pretty crappy rental cars in my day. This car had 29,000 miles on it, and it smelled perfectly fine and looked brand-new. There was not a dent, it was super clean, and it was loaded (heated seats!). I can’t tell you how surprising it was to me how well the car drove and braked. There wasn’t a rattle; there was no road noise, no wind noise. It was solid and could have been a test car dropped here at Jean Knows Cars by Chevy PR; that’s how good it was.

I threw my luggage in the huge trunk, which had plenty of room to spare, and I drove from the airport past Sea World to a two-bedroom condo that my husband had arranged for us to share with Bob’s show handler. My husband is notoriously cheap. He is tighter than the bark on a log. I have gone with him to dog shows where he’s put me in a Motel 6, including one that the police cruised by every ten minutes because it was such a bad neighborhood, in Louisville, Kentucky. The floors were damp, the toilet ran, and the sheets were see-through. It was so bad that at midnight I sat up in bed and said, "We're leaving in the morning. I have been traveling for thirty-three years, and I no longer need to get a $39 hotel room.” He was smart enough to pack up everything right then, in the middle of the night, and take me to a Holiday Inn, which by the way had dog biscuits in a bowl on the front desk when we checked in. I looked at him and said “See? See what I’m talking about here?” No more Motel 6s.

So this place I was going was called Floridays Resort. Tim insisted it looked really good in the pictures online, which brought to mind another hotel we once got based on the pictures online, in Chicago. We were going to see the impossible-to-get-into Monet exhibit at the Art Institute of Chicago, so we chose a beautiful old hotel with a great name like Blackstone or something like that. When we arrived, it looked grand outside and incredibly tatty inside. We were handed the key, and the fob was a fluorescent green plastic with the number written on it in ink. I looked around the vast lobby, and about 25 percent of the tiles were missing. We got into the room, and paint was blistering on the ceiling and the bedspread was worn-out chenille. I burst into tears. We could have been at the Drake instead! But no. He tried to jolly me, and I was inconsolable until I woke up the next morning and he said: “The funniest thing happened last night. I woke up in the middle of the night to go to the bathroom, and I made my usual two left turns, opened the door, and stepped out, and instead of being in our bathroom, I was in front of the elevator, stark naked. So I turned around, and I couldn’t remember what room I was in.” While he was talking, I was just sitting there, dumbfounded. He went on: “I was trying doors, and luckily, I left our door slightly open.” The funniest thing is how nonchalant he was, completely unaffected by it, but it sure brightened my day.

Back to the Floridays Resort. It turned out to be a complex of six high-rise buildings surrounding a really big pool, and the condo inside was fantastic, beautiful, and super clean. The units are all privately owned, and it cost less than $150 a night for two bedrooms and two full baths, one with shower and Jacuzzi. There was a living room, a dining table, and a full kitchen. We cooked a big chicken dinner for Dr. Robert Garcia de Padua and his wife, Cindy, who drove down from Jacksonville to see GCH Irish’s Robert Garcia de Padua, a.k.a. Bob, compete in the nationals.

Sadly, Bob did nothing at the event, but dinner was great, and they drove back to Jacksonville. We laughed at the fact that, once Bob got his championship title, Bob the dog pushed Bob the doctor off the front page of Google search.
Five years on, Dr. Bob frequently has new clients who ask him if that’s his dog. Who would name his dog after himself? Certainly not Dr. Bob. He gets a big laugh, though.
The only thing central Florida has going for it, other than the weather (which, by the way, was 42 degrees when I got up), is palm trees.

It was a pretty quick trip. Tim loaded up the car and left at 1:45 in the morning for Michigan, and I drove up to Saint Augustine to visit my old friend, endurance-racing legend Hurley Haywood, at his new house. We had a great afternoon. I met his new English cocker spaniel, Watkins, who joined his other English cocker spaniel, Indy. (Typical racing-car-guy names.) These two little cuties join his three gorgeous cats. I was there just long enough to have a boat ride and walk the dogs in old Saint Augustine. Then I left the next morning and went back to Orlando and flew home.

But on my way back to Orlando, it occurred to me that the only thing central Florida  has going for it, other than the weather (which, by the way, was 42 degrees when I got up), is palm trees. My favorite overpass on the way back to Orlando is LPGA Boulevard, right around Daytona Beach, which is lined on both sides by varying heights of palm trees. You could see it from a mile away against the blue morning sky. The weather, the blue sky, the palm trees.
When I took my car back to Hertz, I was greeted by a very cheery lady named Donna who said, “You write for a car magazine.” I took this picture of her with the car, and we had a great conversation.
Even the parking structure is lushly landscaped with palm trees. Oh, call me a farmer from Michigan, but I took a picture.
Before I could get home, I was getting dispatches from the front, where my husband had arrived to sub-zero temperatures and multiple inches of snow.

Postscript: The sad news here is that Annie White is leaving us to go to the Big Apple, but she'll still be contributing. We've loved having her this past year.

One last thing: If you're in Ann Arbor for the rest of December, go to Cafe Zola, where our fantastic videographer Scott Allen's paintings are on the walls. He's a major talent, and we're glad we have him with us. You might have another look at our videos with new appreciation.

pageElements.text:
Mercedes-Benz AMG Vision Gran Turismo

There are a lot of concept cars that look like they belong in a video game; this one really does. The fifteenth birthday of the Gran Turismo video game series for PlayStation was celebrated this year with the release of Gran Turismo 6, even more realistic than the five generations that came before it. Mercedes-Benz developed the concept you see in this video specifically for an existence in the PS3 game.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/5Jvb520Ct84?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

The Gran Turismo concept was the work of Mercedes-Benz's Advanced Design Studios in Sindelfingen, Germany, along with Carlsbad, California, for the exterior, and Como, Italy, for the interior. They selected AMG's 585-horsepower V-8 biturbo engine, an aluminum space frame body, and heavy use of carbon fiber to end up with a light concept car at 3,053 pounds. All this for a car you can only enjoy in the virtual world, which kind of makes the virtual world more attractive.

Gran Turismo game creator Kazunori Yamauchi welcomed the concept with a statement: "For me as a child, the concept cars announced by automobile manufacturers in motor shows were fantastic presents that always brought promise of a bright future."

Well, this is a present for you, all right, Mr. Yamauchi. The Mercedes-Benz AMG Vision Gran Turismo is deliberately extreme, with a low, flowing silhouette and glowing red ambient contour lines. Its LED grille is aglow with varying light patterns, and its high brake light in back displays the Gran Turismo logo.

pageElements.text: If your New Year’s resolutions list has “have more fun” written near the top (as it should), here’s something you’ll appreciate. NASCAR has donated four VIP All Access passes to the 2014 Daytona 500. Mark your calendar for the weekend of February 23 to attend, and get in your bid on eBay by December 29: it’s for charity.
Where to bid? Here.

What is in the package? Besides the four VIP All Access packages—which let you in to the NASCAR garage and pit road—you’ll get four grandstand seats and four autographed hats that will be signed by team drivers.

Our friends at the Danville d’Elegance Foundation, who support organizations in the effort to find a cure for Parkinson’s disease, are behind the ticket package. The Danville people are in the Michael J. Fox Foundation’s top three fundraisers, and they also support the Parkinson’s Institute of Sunnyvale, California, with charity dollars in six figures.

The eBay auction ends on December 29, so if you’re interested, bid here, keeping in mind that all proceeds will benefit the Danville d’Elegance Foundation’s charity to support Parkinson’s research and patient care. Be prepared, though: bids on Monday were already up to $1,252.

title: 2014 Toyota Highlander on the Road
promoTeaserSmall: In the all-new SUV, I took the scenic route through California's artichoke-growing Carmel Valley.
promoTeaser: In the all-new SUV, I took the scenic route through California's artichoke-growing Carmel Valley.
metaDescription: 2014 Toyota Highlander Drive: In and around the Carmel Valley in the all-new SUV. Getting there was most of the fun. Read the story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I am a freelance writer in North Carolina, and I have been covering technology --including the technology in automobiles--since before Bill met Melinda or any of us met Google. I also write about education, parenting, family travel, and gardening. I currently write the Family Tech column in Family Circle magazine and Family Tech with Christina at FamilyCircle.com, and I blog on the Geek Girlfriends site. Clients--past and present--include Better Homes and Gardens, Popular Science, This Old House Magazine, USA Weekend, PC Magazine, PC World, Jaguar, Saks Fifth Avenue, and many others. I am thrilled to be a part of Jean Knows Cars.

pageElements.text:
Vital Stats

Base price: $29,880 (four-cylinder LE FWD) to $50,650 (V-6 Hybrid Platinum AWD) (prices include destination)
EPA fuel economy: 20 mpg city/25 mpg highway (four-cylinder FWD); 18/24 mpg (V-6 AWD); 28/28 mpg (Hybrid)
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 270 horsepower; 2.7-liter four-cylinder or gasoline-electric hybrid are optional
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Safety features: Safety Connect roadside and emergency assistance, pre-collision system, lane departure alert (part of optional Driver Technology package)
Tech features: Entune audio (6.1-inch touchscreen on LE, adds navigation on XLE, adds App suite and Premium JBL audio on Limited); rear Blu-ray DVD entertainment system (XLE and Limited models)
Chief competitors: Chevrolet Traverse, Honda Pilot, Hyundai Santa Fe, Kia Sorento, Mazda CX-9
I’d like to offer some tips if you ever get invited to Carmel Valley for a press preview of a Toyota Highlander. First, say “Yes!” Do not hesitate. You will not regret it.

Second, make it task one to study your fellow journalists and identify someone who understands you and your car aesthetic (mine is comfortable and fun to drive) and lifestyle (sarcastic, pleasure-seeking). The latter is a matter of simple mathematics. There are more people than cars at these events, so you have to share.

That means spending the day in a car with a complete stranger. Preferring not to ride along with Mr. Toad or chat with someone who thinks vehicle braking technology is a starting place for amusing anecdotes, I have learned to choose carefully.

Before we had the car doors closed, my choice, Jeremy, and I had identified the car’s most brilliant feature, at least from a hedonistic usability point of view: the in-dash shelf with USB and twelve-volt charger. Every car should have this. After a quick tussle for supremacy over shelf space, which resulted in a compromise that allowed us each to have our cell phones at the ready, we did a quick check to see if the Toyota people had stocked the roll-top center console with the fifty-eight juice boxes they claimed it would hold. Fortunately, they hadn’t. “Good,” said Jeremy, carefully studying the interior of this handy storage area. “I don’t think that’s a good use of space. Looks like it might hold enough beer, though.” (Toyota is positioning the car to appeal to a family van demographic, forgetting that parents have the same beverage requirements as other stressed humans.)
“Is it refrigerated?” I asked, thinking it might even hold a bottle of Pinot Gris. (It isn’t.)

Nonetheless, I decided this storage feature alone—as I dropped my oversized purse into it instead of letting my essentials fend for themselves in the back seat—made the 2014 an improvement over last year’s Highlander. Jeremy was more impressed with the crossover’s updated, more masculine exterior styling. “It’s more aggressive,” he said. Which, I’m pretty sure, for a man who doesn’t want to be seen as driving anything like a minivan, is a good thing. The third-row seating didn’t thrill either of us, but I’m sure we’d both be happy for it it if we were trying to fit eight people in the car.

The Highlander has an “LCD multi-information display” in the dash that hosts the smartphone-driven app suite, navigation system, and backup camera. I tossed the printed directions the Toyota people had provided us with in favor of this navigation system, plugging in our first destination.

The scenery was beautiful and the agenda—a tour of local farms where we would load this crossover SUV with room for eight with produce to deliver to a local food bank—was, we had to admit, a nice idea. We did our best to keep with the route, mostly because food was promised at every stop. But we quickly got lost. This happened mostly because the navigation system interrupted us constantly when we were trying to talk. (It should be technically possible to program some manners into these things, don’t you think?) She also mispronounced the Spanish-language street names, which just isn‘t hip in California. So, as cool kids do when faced with a lack of social grace, we ignored her.

When we found ourselves circling the same block for the third time, our human tendencies to blame someone of the opposite sex kicked in. So I switched to Google Maps on my Android phone. (She gets the street names right!) Harmony was restored in the car’s interior, and we were back in the game.

The first stop was at Pezzini Farms, where we viewed artichokes in their natural state: naked of butter or mayonnaise. Artichokes have been growing on this piece of land since the 1940s, we learned. They looked happy, tended carefully in that perfect weather with a stunning ocean view.
Then we ate some, fried and steamed. They were excellent.

Next stop: Tanimura and Antle Farms, where we would learn obvious things about growing lettuce and the fascinating history of water (with politics reminiscent of Chinatown, but without so much incest, face-slapping, or gunplay) and agriculture (Steinbeck said the same thing with more detail on marine science and hookers) in the Carmel Valley. There was a great collection of WPA-era watercolor paintings here that made the history come to life. Best of all, we would be treated to an outstanding lunch with a view of the valley.

After lunch, there was an opportunity for a car change. So Jeremy and I grabbed the Hybrid model and headed off to the food bank, where we put in a couple of solid hours of work sorting donated food for the homeless. We were not good employees. We overthought everything, tired easily, and were distracted by decisions that people who don’t write for a living would not have noticed. After an hour, we began wondering about mandated coffee breaks. After two, we were organizing into labor unions. If we’d stayed another hour, we would have gone on strike.
Fortunately, we jumped back into our SUV before gang violence broke out. “I don’t feel like I really drove this car yet,” Jeremy complained.
Our turn – back to the Carmel Valley Ranch – was ahead. So I missed it.
“Oops.” I said.
“I guess we’ll have to take the long way back,” agreed Jeremy, smiling.
The long way back involved lots of winding, hilly roads with stunning views of wineries and valleys. I drove too fast, turned too sharply, and braked with excessive suddenness.
“How’s it feel?” Jeremy wanted to know.
“Not bad for an SUV.” I said. “It’s not a sports car. But it’s fun.”
This annoyed him. “I better drive," he said.
He drove even faster, weaving up the hill like a maniac reptile at a Disney park. “Yep,” he agreed. “Handles better than the Lexus SUV.”
And then it was time for dinner.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. title: Road Trips with Babies Made Simpler
promoTitle: Road Trips with Babies Made Simpler
promoTeaserSmall: Four tips your mom should have given you about taking road trips comfortably with small children.
promoTeaser: Four tips your mom should have given you about taking road trips comfortably with small children.
metaDescription: Road Trips with Babies Made Simpler: Four tips your mom should have given you about taking road trips comfortably with small children. Read them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Liane Yvkoff dipped her toe in the pool of automotive writing five years ago and fell directly into the deep end. Since then, she has written about cars for CNET.com, AutoUSA.com, Babble.com, and, oddly enough, Hustler. Residing in the Seattle area, she obviously drives a Subaru Outback.

pageElements.text: Missions to the moon have been executed with less planning and stress, and certainly less stuff, than the annual holiday road trip that millions of families are embarking right about now.

Did you pack your shovel and fire starting kit? How about snacks? Do you have enough snacks, because what if you get trapped in a freak snowstorm for days and no one can find you? Better stash another box of cereal bars and another blanket while you’re at it.

And toys. 
And DVDs. 
And water. 
And cat litter (in case of ice). 
Whatever you do, DO NOT forget to bring the chargers. Yes, all of them for a weekend trip only five hours away.
Was it always like this? I wouldn’t know, having become a parent in the age of Google.

Search for “road trips with kids,” and Google finds 48 million links in 0.38 second. Imagine what they could do with more time. And each article offers tips, strategies, and hundreds of differing opinions on the ten essential products you need for your car in the event you get trapped in an avalanche on the way to Grandma’s house and die. It’s all just one big “to do” list in the middle of the busiest shopping season of the year.
The old adage is true that you can never be overprepared. However, if you try you will most likely be overpacked.
Before you consult The Art of Survival, try asking your parents how they traveled with kids. Chances are good that the tips they offer will have less to do with gadgets and more with common sense:

1. Leave early in the morning to avoid traffic. You can also travel at night to attempt to capitalize on kids' sleep schedules and avoid traffic, but gas stations and restaurants may be closed if you need them.
2. Play road trip games. Sure, nothing keeps kids entertained quite like a movie or iPad, but road trips can be quality family time if you make it fun.

3. Plan for emergencies, but not every emergency: A first aid kit is great, but a snake-bite kit is probably overkill. Maps (the old printed kind), jumper cables, gloves, a spare tire, blankets, candles, water, and nuts were in my mom’s emergency kit. Add cell phone charger to the list and call it good.
4. Be flexible: Planning your route is great, but don’t hold yourself to a schedule or force stops if little ones are sleeping.
Image at top: Renata Osinska/istock/ThinkStock

title: Merry Christmas, Everyone!
promoTeaserSmall: I had so many plans....and I changed them to be home with the family. My holiday letter to you.
promoTeaser: I had so many plans....and I changed them to be home with the family. My holiday letter to you.
metaDescription: Merry Christmas, Everyone! I had so many plans....and I changed them to be home with the family. My holiday letter to you on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: We were readying the four dogs for the trip to the kennel and packing the 2014 Acura MDX for the drive to New Orleans to see the family, eat cousin Mark’s famous Christmas day gumbo, go fishing for redfish south of Delacroix with cousin Tim, look for stray dogs in the ditches of Mississippi…

But here we are in snowy Michigan. The dogs are snuggled around us with new blankets and giant biscuits. Hall and Oates's Home for Christmas unraveled everything. I was running last-minute errands, popped it in the changer, and the weeping began. My mom is in a nursing home, and I wanted her in my living room by the fire. I wanted to see my brothers. And what if fourteen-year-old Lulu Belle, the love of our lives, shot through at the kennel while we weren’t home with her?
I began to unwind the Big Plan.

Right now, I am simultaneously vacuuming up the tumbleweeds of dog hair, decorating the house, cooking the ham and sweet potatoes (with lots of bourbon), and wishing that each and every one of you is Home for Christmas, if only for a day, if only in your heart. And thank you so very, very much for welcoming us into your home for the past year.
Have a happy, blessed, healthy, and joyous year to come!
Love, Jean

title: 2014 Mazda 3 S Grand Touring
subTitle: In search of the elusive Holiday Spirit in a great little car for adventure.
promoTeaserSmall: In search of the elusive Holiday Spirit in a great little car for adventure.
promoTeaser: In search of the elusive Holiday Spirit in a great little car for adventure.
metaDescription: 2014 Mazda 3 S Grand Touring: I headed off in search of that elusive animal, holiday spirit. Well, getting there was way more than half the fun. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
Price: $29,185 as tested, including destination
Engine: 2.5-liter four-cylinder, 184 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic with Sport mode
Fuel economy: 28 mpg city/38 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Rearview camera
Option I can’t live without: Navigation system (a no-cost option)
You might also be considering: Ford Focus, Hyundai Elantra, Nissan Altima, Volkswagen Golf

As I grow older, I can feel my levels of adrenaline and other risk-taking hormones plummeting year by year. Never a thrill seeker on my best day, nowadays I am increasingly interested in staying home and staying comfortable.
It’s for that reason that the Mazda 3 was such a revelation to me. This is a reasonably priced car that you can climb into and immediately feel young, adventurous, and ready for anything.

Well, maybe not ready for towing a boat, or carrying a family of six, but anything that a person on her own might find fun. It is for that reason that I climbed out of my dull, ordinary weekend routine and took a little road trip. My goal (other than enjoying the drive) was to stalk that elusive animal, Holiday Spirit, to its small-town lair.

One place where the Christmas frame of mind was advertised as still alive and well is the town of Holly, Michigan, about an hour’s drive north of Ann Arbor. Philosophically, it’s several decades removed: five miles off the expressway, with no city, shopping mall, or chain store anywhere within range, and with a deliberately charming main shopping area. My choice of a drive up to Holly was determined by the fact that the 40th Annual Charles Dickens Festival was in progress. Would this warm my Grinch-like heart or sicken me? I was about to find out.

It was a good thing I started my trip by heading north on the always unpleasant U.S. 23 North, because it made me appreciate the Mazda 3 immediately. There is something about this unremarkable straight stretch of divided highway that makes people drive like idiots. They tailgate, they speed, they pass unsafely, and they talk on the phone while they’re doing it. So I was especially enjoying the Mazda driving experience and the Mazda 3’s ability to pour on the power instantly, whenever I asked for it.  You always hear cars referred to as “nimble,” but in the case of the 2014 Mazda 3, that is not an exaggeration.

High Praise for the Mazda 3

The car I was driving was the five-door model in top-end Grand Touring trim. It has many of the modern features that I am quickly coming to find indispensable: push-button start, heated front seats, rain-sensing wipers, a seven-inch touchscreen display, and a navigation system. In the case of the Mazda, it was a navigation system that was so intuitive that I actually used it instead of asking Siri on my iPhone for directions, and that is high praise.

The safety features are also up to date: blind spot monitoring, rear cross-traffic alert, traction control, and a rearview camera. And did you see those mpg numbers (28/38 mpg), thanks to Mazda’s Skyactiv engine technology? All of this for an out-the-door price under $30,000. The price of entry to the Mazda 3 family is a very youth-friendly $17,740 (including destination) for the base four-door S with the 2.0-liter four-cylinder making 155 horsepower and a six-speed manual transmission. That one gets 29 mpg in town and a sterling 41 mpg on the highway.
This is a car that knows who it’s for: enthusiastic young drivers, the kind without a lot of money but with plenty of taste. Everything is just right for that driver.

This is the third generation of the Mazda 3, and as the automaker says, it’s “all new from the ground up.” It is already critically acclaimed for its sleek, attractive, dare I say hip, yet not extreme styling, and for how much zoom-zoom you get per dollar. It was even a finalist for our brother publication Automobile Magazine’s 2014 Automobile of the Year award, high praise indeed for what used to be dismissed as an economy car.

The energetic, rewarding driving experience, the comfortable, cosseting driver’s seat, the expensive appearance, and the miserly fuel economy all combine to make you ask yourself, What am I doing just sitting here when I could be driving?

Where Is Charles Dickens When You Need Him?

After leaving U.S. 23 at the town of Fenton, I had the best part of the drive ahead of me: five miles down the evocatively named Grange Hall Road and then up North Saginaw Street into Holly. I was pleased to see that these, unlike the highway, were gently curving roads with very little competition from other cars. I thought it would be nice to wash the car, but after unwisely bypassing a mom-and-pop shop right at the highway exit, I never found another. Nor did I see a McDonald’s, a Starbucks, or any of the other bright and shiny detritus of modern life. It was handpainted signs and tree farms all the way.

Pulling in to the main drag in Holly, there were unmistakable signs of small-town Michigan life that I recognized from my childhood in a burg with population 4,300. Kiwanis Club guys were standing in the middle of the street, asking for donations at red lights, which they dropped into red buckets. The streets were being blocked off by logs on stands painted orange, block-party style.  And slowly at first, but in growing numbers as the afternoon wore on, I spotted people dressed in what, to central Michigan, passes for authentic Victorian apparel. Yes, some of this was about pulling in tourists from the Detroit suburbs, and there they were, crowding the six (count ‘em) antique and gift shops that line Saginaw Street downtown. I wound my way through them, too, comforted by knowing that my Mazda 3 couldn’t fit any of the charming antique furniture that was selling for reasonable prices at The Pigeon in the Parlour in its 1865 building. I did buy a little hardcover book with a pigeon on the spine, which opens to reveal a secret compartment. See if you can find it in my house, burglars!

Then, on the edge of the railroad tracks that cross diagonally right through the heart of town, I spotted the Historic Holly Hotel, which is just as creaky-looking and old as its name implies. No fake-restored McMansion here. You make your way up onto the elderly porch on the side, and once inside, it’s a plush Victorian refuge from the twenty-first century. I held the door for a mother and daughter; the mother, struggling up the stairs with the aid of a walker, was in her Sunday best and elaborately done hair, while the daughter was rocking a hand-knit Christmas sweater. This was obviously a much-looked-forward-to occasion for them.

High Tea, Middle American Style

I was seated in a comfortable booth deep in the bowels of the hotel and offered High Tea. This is something you don’t often see in mid-Michigan. I remembered where I was, though, when the waitress offered me a tray of tea bags with a pot full of hot water instead of brewed tea, and when I asked for Earl Grey and was met with a look of incomprehension. “We don’t got any of that, but you might want to try this Oblong tea. It’s pretty popular,” she said, pointing to the Oolong tea bags. (I settled for English Breakfast. It was fine, and the salmon, dried-cherry salad, and scones were all excellent.) The Holly Hotel also trades on its glamorous interior with elaborate Sunday brunches and dinners, “fairy” tea events for children, and other special meal occasions. Worth the drive—but bring your own Earl Grey unless you want to try the Oblong Tea for yourself.

Now in the mood for Dickens, I made my way through Battle Alley, named for its reputation as a street-brawling kind of place in the long-gone days when train travel brought lots of partiers through town, and over to where the Lions Club was putting on A Christmas Carol in a kind of beer tent on a side street. Townspeople, more than out-of-town shoppers, seemed to fill this audience. They were seated on long benches, bundled up against the cold while a roaring propane heater almost drowned out the dialogue. Clearly, the actors were enthusiastic amateur locals, and they were really in the spirit of the thing. After watching them thoroughly revel in their moment upon the makeshift stage, I am not sure I want to watch any lavish PBS versions of this story ever again.

Being Here Now

When I was a young hippie, I had a book called Be Here Now. The lesson from that is as important to me now as it was then: the secret of happiness is, really, to be where, who, and what you are, and not covet another life, another experience, or another reality. In the little town of Holly, where they are ambitious enough to honor Charles Dickens, they are being the creaky little village they are, and enjoying it. Sure, there must be teenagers here who are numbering the days until they can move to Chicago or anywhere but Holly. But, if the specially constructed sledding hill, the street carts of food (“Bless their hearts being out in this snow!!!” commented someone about a Facebook photo of the street barbecue), and the choirs of high-schoolers dressed all in red hats, cheerfully mobbing the street corner, lead me to think, this is a town that knows how to be what it really is.

Which inevitably leads me back to the Mazda 3. This is a car that knows who it’s for: enthusiastic young drivers, the kind without a lot of money but with plenty of taste. Everything on this car is just right for that driver, from the appealing exterior to the plethora of safety features to the delicious feel of your hands on the steering wheel commanding it. I’m no twenty-five-year-old, but like the town of Holly, I can look back and honor the twenty-five-year-old I once was by holding a festive commemorative weekend, and that’s exactly what I did.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text:
2014 Honda Accord Coupe EX-L V6 Navi

Vital Stats

Base price: $31,415 (includes destination)
This car's price: $33,190 (includes destination)
EPA fuel economy: 18 mpg city/28 mpg highway
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 278 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual
Safety features: Six airbags, vehicle stability assist with traction control, forward collision warning, and lane departure warning (all standard)
Tech features: Touchscreen audio, SiriusXM satellite radio, push-button start, MP3 and USB connectivity, heated front seats
Chief competitors: This is one of the few cars that stands alone in its segment.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/-jk8KnLSBjs" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Key Points

• The 2014 Accord Coupe is a carryover model.
• The car shown in the video is the top-of-the-line Accord Coupe model, and it has no options. The base price for the 2014 Accord LX-S coupe with six-speed manual transmission is $24,415 (including destination).
• This EX-L with navigation costs $1,775 more than the EX-L without navigation.
• The model tested has a six-speed manual transmission. There's no price penalty for upgrading to a six-speed automatic.
• The same version with the six-speed automatic transmission gets better fuel economy at 21 mpg city/32 mpg highway. • You can get the Accord Coupe in V-6 and four-cylinder versions. The four-cylinder version delivers 185 hp.

• Honda has always been known for its attitude that “safety should be standard, not optional.” The Accord Coupe earned five out of five stars from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration for frontal, side, and rollover safety.
• The 2013 Accord Coupe was named a 2013 Top Safety Pick + by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. It earned the top Good rating in all IIHS tests, except for an Acceptable rating in the small overlap front crash test. These are still effective ratings, since the Accord was fully redesigned in 2013 and the changes for 2014 model year are minimal.

• Car shoppers don’t have much choice in the mid-size coupe segment, especially since the Nissan Altima Coupe has been discontinued for the 2014 model year. Nissan said the Altima Coupe was a “very low-volume product” and that the discontinuation means that more four-cylinder engines will be available for the 2014 Nissan Altima sedan.

• Why does the Accord Coupe survive? The answer is probably reliability and practicality. • Why do people buy coupes? Style and performance. Just a few years ago there were many mid-size coupes. Among them were the Camry-based Toyota Solara, the Pontiac Grand Am and Oldsmobile Alero coupes, the Ford Probe, and the Mercury Cougar.

• The Accord Coupe has a practical side in that it seats five.
• For 2014, the Honda Accord sedan–not coupe–comes in hybrid and plug-in hybrid versions.
• The 2014 Accord sedan is cheaper than the coupe; the 2014 Accord LX sedan starts at $22,745 (including destination).
