title: Ford F-150 to Brooklyn
promoTeaserSmall: Big trucks may be best out on the range, but they are also ideal for a major cross-country move.
promoTeaser: Big trucks may be best out on the range, but they are also ideal for a major cross-country move.
metaKeywords: Road trip to New York City
metaDescription: Ford F-150 to Brooklyn: My road trip to what was soon to become my new home, in a vehicle that could handle all my stuff. Read about the road trip on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
2013 Ford F-150 4x4 Supercrew

Price: $53,635 as tested (including destination)
Engine: 3.5-liter turbocharged V-6, 365 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 15 mpg city/21 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Heated and cooled driver's and passenger's seats
Option I can’t live without: King Ranch luxury package ($2,665) includes navigation, power moonroof, King Ranch interior accents, HID headlights
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Silverado, Ram 1500, Toyota Tundra

In the tradition of countless twentysomethings before me, in the eighteen months since I left college I have moved from place to place, house to house, like a rolling stone. I’ve moved four times since last September, and I’m about to add another location to my list: next stop, Brooklyn!

Moving is easier said than done, though. How am I going to get all my stuff across the country and into a tiny apartment in the most densely populated city in the United States? Luckily, I’m a big believer in a minimalist lifestyle. In college, I lived for nine months with only the clothes I could carry in my sixty-five-liter backpack (and my laptop, of course). I’m prepared to do it again. But what about my bed?

With access to test cars that could theoretically transport a mattress cross-country, I couldn’t justify buying a new bed or spending my limited cash on a moving truck. So instead, I got hold of a 2013 Ford F-150 King Ranch over Thanksgiving weekend and started planning for a two-day there-and-back dash from Fort Wayne, Indiana, to Brooklyn and back again in time for a good night’s sleep in Ann Arbor before work Monday morning. Total miles driven during the long weekend would eventually top 1,700.

It all started with a Friday night trip to my ancestral home in Plymouth, where my dad helped me haul my mattress into the back of the F-150. I’d assumed that any truck bed would be large enough for my full-size bed, but this was a Supercrew model with a short bed. That was great news for any hypothetical back-seat passengers, who would enjoy 43.5 inches of legroom. But not great news for my mattress, which was six feet long and had to fit in a five-and-a-half-foot truck bed. The F-150 came with an optional bed extender, which cost $250 and allowed me to drive with the tailgate down and my cargo secured with a locking gate.

With the bed extender in place, my mattress just fit in the truck bed. I filled the back seat with a couple of laundry baskets full of bedding and clothes and went home to Ann Arbor for a night of rest before my drive the next day.

My first destination of the day was a bridal shower in Fort Wayne, just a few blocks from the house my mom grew up in. I wasn’t quite sure of the way, so I used voice commands to enter the address into the standard MyFord Touch infotainment system. The system immediately launched into route guidance. At first, all was well. But then, the navigation system started getting confused about my location. Although I never left the highway, it showed me traveling down a side road parallel to the freeway and issued repeated voice commands urging me to return to I-94 West at the earliest possible convenience. This continued for over an hour, until I got annoyed and turned it off.

This F-150 was a King Ranch model, one of the F-150’s top trim levels. It’s named for a working ranch in southern Texas, and it has the real King Ranch’s swoopy cattle brand logo throughout. The King Ranch package costs $2,665 and comes with HID headlights, a power moonroof, and brown leather seating in both the front and back rows, as well as a leather-wrapped steering wheel and center console. The seats were attractive and comfortable, and I felt like I was sitting in a nice armchair as I went down the road.

The rest of the F-150’s interior wasn’t nearly as cushy. The door and dashboard trim were made of hard, black plastic, which would make perfect sense in a more utilitarian model. But in a $53,000 car, an interior that could be hosed down feels out of place. I found myself dreaming of the 2014 Chevrolet Silverado I’d driven a few months earlier. It had leather seats, soft-touch materials on all the interior surfaces, an intuitive infotainment system; now that’s a truck interior. I’m hoping Ford has something similar in store for the all-new 2015 F-150, out next year.

After a morning of pre-wedding festivities (I passed on the mimosas, mindful of the long drive ahead), I set out for Brooklyn. I was pleasantly surprised to find that the F-150 was a comfortable highway cruiser. I didn’t hear any rattling or rumbling from my cargo, which stayed firmly in place behind the bed extender. The F-150 didn’t get fantastic fuel mileage – my average hovered just above 15 mpg for most of my trip, though its V-6 EcoBoost engine is rated at 21 mpg on the highway, but the thirty-six-gallon fuel tank meant that pesky fuel stops were limited. That’s not to say those stops were painless, though. Each thirty-gallon plus fill-up cost in the neighborhood of $100.

I’d been worried that my big truck would be a fish out of water in New York City, but the F-150 handled the Big Apple with grace. The navigation system that had faltered earlier guided me to my final destination without error. The truck felt big in the narrow lanes, but I kept my wits about me and never had trouble. Once in Brooklyn, I found a free parking space right across the street from my apartment, unloaded the truck, and went to bed, preparing to do it all over again the next day.

From the very start of my drive on Sunday, I was battling post-Thanksgiving traffic. The first ten miles or so (from Brooklyn through Manhattan and onto the New Jersey Turnpike) took more than an hour. Just outside New Jersey, I hit another log jam leading up to a tollbooth, and listened to two entire discs of my Harry Potter book on tape while waiting to escape it. Two hours later, I was snagged again. In those hours inching west, I was happy to have the F-150 King Ranch. Tacky door trim aside, the truck was comfortable, and I was glad for my high seating position and armchair seats as I made my way home.

I’ve never been convinced that pickup trucks make sense outside of construction zones or working farms, and I’m still not. The F-150 gets decent fuel economy for a truck, but you’ll spend $830 more in fuel every year compared with the driver of an average new car, and parking and maneuvering this beast (even with a rearview camera) will make you wish you were driving a Smart Fortwo. Still, for a move across the country with large cargo, the F-150 King Ranch was just what the doctor ordered.

pageElements.text: One of the best venues to see works of art at Art Basel Miami in December was not at the art fair, but on an entire floor of the Herzog & de Meuron parking garage-turned-art- car-gallery on 1111 Lincoln Road. “Piston Head: Artists Engage the Automobile" was an exhibition timed to Art Basel that explored the power, refuse, and imagination induced by car culture.

pageElements.text: The New York gallery Venus Over Manhattan showed fifteen art cars and one 1965 Harley motorcycle, all as imagined by serious contemporary artists. Ron Arad’s disfigured Fiat 600, Virginia Overton’s humble 1993 Dodge Ram, and several virulent American models drew spectators to the far corners of the open-air garage overlooking the Miami skyline. High-profile works included a polka-dotted Mini Cooper produced by Damien Hirst, Richard Prince’s red and black 2012 Dodge Challenger R/T in the style of Vanishing Point, and Keith Haring’s playful 1963 Buick Special. The brand-new Playboy-commissioned 1972 Dodge Charger made by Richard Phillips made its debut at the show. “This car was a raw chassis when I started,” said Phillips at the opening, as he pointed out the #43 Richard Petty-inspired design cues. “Now you have a hybrid of a Cup car.” Then he climbed into the driver’s seat, opting to let the growl of the engine drown out the clink of champagne glasses and the clamor of conversation.

The show ranges from functioning cars to highly conceptual works. Artist Salvatore Scarpitta raced his single-seater Ernie Triplett Special dirt racer in Pennsylvania and was sponsored by the legendary art dealer Leo Castelli. Whereas the French sculptor César's compressed crushed car sculptures have deliberate impact, real-world cars like sculptor Franz West’s coy 1970 Rolls-Royce Silver Shadow were contrasted by think pieces like the rusted-out, shot-up Ford pickup truck repurposed by Lucien Smith. Then there is the catastrophic humor of two whimsical white Volkswagen Beetles engaged in an intimate crash, as footage played out on the windshield, courtesy of the collective Bruce High Quality Foundation.

Adam Lindemann, who curated the show and owns the gallery, is also a car collector. He favors vintage Ferraris and those of classic British pedigree. “What was nice about the show was that we somehow struck this intersection between art, cars, artist cars, and Miami, and we found collectors for the cars, which is so amazing, because people come to Miami to buy paintings, not cars,” he said.

Ferrari, a sponsor of the five-day exhibition, once used the garage to show a parade of its fine exotics during Art Basel. This year, a LaFerrari was on exhibition on opening night to accompany the only two-dimensional work, by California artist Joshua Callaghan, who made a rubbing of the car. “I spent the last three days in the basement at the Ferrari dealership,” said Callaghan. “It’s a future archaeology.” The piece was auctioned off to benefit the Art Production Fund.

I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. pageElements.text:
Price: $20,405 as tested (including destination)
Engine: 1.4-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 138 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual
Fuel economy: 29 mpg city/40 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Heated, power-adjustable side mirrors
Option I can’t live without: Chevrolet MyLink with voice recognition for phone and Bluetooth streaming audio ($200)
You might also be considering: Ford Fiesta, Hyundai Accent, Nissan Versa

What I Think:

I first became acquainted with the Chevrolet Sonic when my mother bought one last year, passing her four-year-old Saturn Astra down to me. Before the Saturn, she drove a Saab 9-5 wagon. My dad joked when she bought the Sonic that it was an omen of bad times ahead for Chevy; thankfully, he has been proven wrong. She’s had the Sonic for a year now, but I’ve never spent much time in it, so when we took delivery of a 2014 Sonic LT hatchback for a week, I didn’t know exactly what to expect.

I did know that this subcompact hatch aims to strike just the right balance among utility, affordability, and efficiency. With a 40-mpg highway EPA rating,  it’s off to a good start. The cargo area doesn’t have acres of space, but it’s more than adequate for the average single person. As for affordability, our near-base model comes with a satisfying array of options and tips the scales at just over the magic $20,000 mark after delivery charges. A very promising start.

My time with the Sonic coincided with the first big snowstorm of the winter, so I spent a day slipping and sliding all over town before the snow stopped, the roads cleared, and I was able to actually drive the thing. Our test car came with the optional 1.4-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine making 138 horsepower, which adds $700 to the price. The upgraded engine also got us a six-speed manual transmission instead of the standard five-speed manual. The Sonic LT comes standard with a 1.8-liter normally aspirated engine that makes less torque and earns five fewer highway mpg.
The manual transmission was slick and easy to drive, exactly the kind of manual I wish I’d learned on.

I found our upgraded powertrain to be well matched to this little hatch. It can accelerate reasonably quickly when pushed, but it doesn’t feel souped up or overdone. The manual transmission was slick and easy to drive, exactly the kind of manual I wish I’d learned on. The turbo model’s 33-mpg fuel economy rating will help pocketbooks almost as much as the low price; it’ll save you $3,500 in gas over five years, according to the EPA’s calculations, no small matter for penny pinchers.

The Sonic’s design is quirkier and more unusual than Chevrolet’s larger offerings—like the Cruze or the Malibu, for instance—but not quite as odd as the even tinier Spark. I thought it struck a nice balance between looking distinctive and looking like a toy, which is exactly what I think small car design should do. You’d never feel embarrassed driving this car, but you also wouldn’t feel like a mid-level manager at Dunder Mifflin.

On that cold weekend, I wished my Sonic had heated seats instead of the base, unheated cloth ones, but I enjoyed Chevrolet’s MyLink system as I have every time I’ve used it in any car. It’s simple and intuitive, and it won’t distract you from the task at hand. If you do get a little wrapped up in changing the radio station, though, the available forward collision alert and lane departure warning systems (in the advanced safety package, $395) could save you. Those warning lights are oddly placed, positioned atop the center stack right above the infotainment system. They’d be more useful in the dash or a head-up display so you didn’t have to rely on peripheral vision to catch the warnings, but in a car at this price, it’s impressive to have those systems at all.

The Verdict:

I, of course, could never buy a Sonic, because my mother drives one. But forgetting that detail, I couldn’t help being impressed by the Sonic LT. It’s not packed with technology, but it has most everything you could hope for in a $20,000 car and a little more. It’s neither large nor tiny but operates in a comfortable middle ground. It can be driven aggressively if the mood strikes, but sedate driving will return excellent fuel economy. And if you’ve really got your heart set on heated seats or a sportier ride, the Sonic’s upper trim levels have plenty to keep you happy. Call this one a winner.

Peanut Gallery:

Laura Sky Brown: As long as I stay inside the Sonic, I am having a good time. The somewhat cartoonish visuals on the controls are actually kind of fun, and despite the low price point on this little car, there's a surprising amount of content, from a rearview camera to complete telematics and the most intuitive Bluetooth hookup I've found to date (which went ahead and paired my phone without being asked). Shifting with the six-speed manual transmission is smooth and enjoyable, and it's ridiculously fun to call on the turbo for a sudden burst of speed. The seats are comfortable, the back hatch has a good amount of space, and the interior, while not upscale or luxurious, has decent quality. But then you get out of the car. I am very forgiving of various body styles, but I'm sorry, this is just ugly.

Molly Jean: The turbocharged Chevrolet Sonic may not be supersonic, but for $20,405 it is super. Unlike Laura, I actually like the exterior design; it is unique enough that it is easily identifiable as it zips down the road. The unique style continues on the inside with the motorcycle-style gauges and the patterns on the seats. There is a lot of hard plastic, but it looks not only well designed but also capable of holding up for many years without showing wear. The best part of this particular package is the manual transmission. Coupled with the turbo, it makes this economy car a great choice for both new drivers and price-conscious shoppers who want a little sportiness in their whip.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

contributors.bio: When people ask me how I started writing about cars, I tell them I'm from Detroit. I tell them about my father, who was a Chrysler engineer, and the crazy cars he would bring home to test drive. But before I discovered the glamorous life of an automotive journalist, I was a writer living in the Motor City, covering music and art in the Nineties. Things changed when I became curious about the industry that made the city tick and interned at AutoWeek magazine. I moved to New York City in 2003, where I’ve worked as a freelance writer for almost a decade. I’ve written for more than 100 magazines, newspapers, and websites, including the New York Times, Rolling Stone, Forbes, Jay-z’s Life and Times, Vibe, Automobile Magazine, AutoWeek and the Detroit Free Press. I finished an MFA in creative writing at the New School this year. I live with two car buffs, Lee Quiñones and our four-year-old son, who both think what I do is pretty cool.

pageElements.text: The artist Virginia Overton has recast the pickup truck from a capable worker to conceptual work of art. I saw the most recent example of her work in Miami Beach in December: Overton’s interpretation of a 1993 Dodge Ram. It was included in Venus Over Manhattan’s group exhibition “Piston Head: Artists Engage the Automobile,” held at the Herzog & de Meuron parking garage in Miami during Art Basel in December. The Ram appeared in silver metallic paint, lined with a simple, suggestive red racing stripe along the body and hood leading up to the windshield. An immovable red tonneau cover obstructed its bed, limiting its capabilities. The truck was actually a former workhorse, made lame through the act of stripping it of its basic skills.
Overton has mined the truck’s functionality with a keen eye for the part and process of labor-intensive work. Her work invokes the physicality of construction.

Overton has explored the pickup truck as sculpture in several exhibitions, and in each instance she has mined the truck’s functionality with a keen eye for the part and process of labor-intensive work. Her work invokes the physicality of construction and incorporates materials as they relate to the environment, calling the nature of work into question. In 2012, she created a site-specific truck installation of a 1994 2WD Toyota for the Highline park in New York City. It sat in an elevated car park visible from the Highline's walkway, with its bed entirely bricked off.

For the 2012 exhibition “Chevy Deluxe” at the Power Station in Dallas, she installed a blue light box into the bed of a faded 1984 Chevrolet  Deluxe pickup that was displayed in the gallery. She once received a permit to park a pickup truck in front of the White Box Gallery for a 2007 show.
“I pimped my truck by adding green neon to the underside and then drove it on top of a glass mirror, where I left it for the show,” she said in an Interview Magazine article.

Overton, who grew up in rural Tennesee, also told Interview: “I think the roughness of my work comes from the fact that I grew up on a farm. You learn to use and reuse the same materials in a pretty thrifty way.” Her work incorporates solid, constructive materials like Sheetrock, fluorescent light tubing, and wood beams. In another, earlier truck-themed excavation, she drove from Norfolk, Virginia, to Memphis, Tennessee, acquiring discarded tool and rubbish en route to her destination, tossing them into the bed.

For her recent exhibition at the Kunsthalle in Bern, Switzerland, she said, “I feel like the work I make can exist in a museum or on a driveway or in a barn or whatever, and still function as real things in the world, not as some extraneous objects to be placed on a pedestal.”

contributors.bio: I am a person who loves to study other people. I like to interview them, learn about their lives, photograph them, and write their stories. The people at Jean Knows Cars noticed me through my project, Humans of Ann Arbor. In that project, I tool around the city of Ann Arbor, introducing myself to anyone who draws my eye. If they are open to it, I take a photo of them and hear a little bit about them. Then I post the photos and stories on Facebook. Humans of Ann Arbor has followers from all over the world who check in on a daily basis to see ordinary people and their extraordinary stories. I have been studying people since I was a little girl in Missouri. Where I grew up, studying people often led you to the cars they loved. My grandpa had a gas station in Claycomo, Missouri, which he opened in the 1950s, and he passed his love of cars and taking care of the people who drove them down to my dad. Dad was a mechanic and a service supervisor all his life. We had a steady barrage of cars coming into our lives…mostly Chevys. To impress my dad, I learned to identify every car I could, and I used to name the cars while we drove down the road. Car culture is big in Missouri. Would you believe that I had friends who were sisters named Nova and Chevelle? If you didn’t grow up the way I did, you might not get the significance of that, but suffice it to say that my people love their cars. The car I adored most was the Chevrolet Corvair my dad gave me when I was in high school. It spent more time in my dad's shop than it did on the road, but in those moments when it was drivable, I knew what it was to love a car. It was a thing of beauty: pale cream with a plaid madras interior. I loved the sound and feel of the engine…it was more like a soft purr than a roar. I can still remember how it smelled and what it was like to drive it with the windows rolled down on a warm day. I've had lots of cars since then, and I loved some of them, too. But the Corvair was my first car love and will always be my favorite. After high school, I drove my car to Springfield, Missouri, to study communications at Missouri State. Later, I drove a different car to Chicago to study photography at Columbia College. I worked in Chicago as a freelance photographer and studio manager for many years before moving to Ann Arbor, where I continue to do freelance photography. I am excited about combining my love of studying people with my interest in cars. I want to explore how cars serve us, how they are intertwined in our lives, and what makes us love them. I can't wait to let you know what I find out.

pageElements.text: “When my parents were cool” is the caption under a photo a friend recently posted on social media. In the photo, two impossibly sophisticated people, dressed to the nines, are stepping out of an amazing old car that appears to be from the Thirties or Forties. The man is helping the woman out, and both of them look excited to start an evening of what I can only imagine will include dinner, cocktails, dancing, and witty conversation with charming friends. The photo is so interesting because everything in it paints a vivid picture of a time and place that has gone by.
Cars in photographs are like a date stamp that puts everything into context.

When we look at photos of ourselves, they link us to our memories. When we see photos of our parents or grandparents, they link us to history. Cars in photographs are like a date stamp that puts everything into context. In decades to come, the photos we take of our families and cars now will make our children giggle about the clothes they were wearing, the hairstyles their parents had, and how cool those old cars that you had to steer yourself were!

image.altText: The Car Stays in the Picture

pageElements.text: The Spangler family and I went outside for photos that included their two cars: a 2011 Ford Flex they call “Black Sidious," after the Star Wars character Darth Sidious, and their 1993 Ford F-150 that they call “The Bengal Bomber,” which was painted in Bengal tiger stripes with $40 worth of spray paint. Both of the cars mean a lot to them, so we tried out a few things and came up with five different ways for you to take photos with your car that will stand the test of time.

1. Be natural.

A natural, unposed photo of your family getting ready to go somewhere in the car shows everyone as they actually are. You can take this in your driveway so you can also see a bit of the house, the garage, or the neighborhood. This is a slice-of-life photo to capture your real life. People and cars always look best in soft light, so try taking this photo when it is overcast, or during “magic hour” just before sunset.

2. Pile in.

A photo of you in the car is going to remind you of all the places your car took you and all of the memories you made along the way. You will be reminded of details like which side you sat on, which of the adults usually drove that car, and what it felt like to sit in that particular seat. You may even start to remember details of the scenery you saw through the windows when you were on a road trip, or the game you played together to make the time pass. Future members of your family will imagine what adventures you may have had that day.
Silliness always, 100 percent of the time, makes a better photo than forced smiles.

image.altText: The Car Stays in the Picture

pageElements.text:
3. Ham it up.

Let the personalities in your family shine through. Get everyone in front of the car, and tell them to yell out their favorite food, or maybe, “Go Bengals!” Tell them to say anything but “cheese.” Ask them to jump up and down. The idea is to make everyone have fun, and to capture it on film. Silliness always, 100 percent of the time, makes a better photo than forced smiles.

4. Play with framing.

Really look at what is in your viewfinder. Try stepping forward a few feet or sideways, or squat down. Move around until you get a nice view of the car and the people. Notice if there are weird, distracting things in the frame, and move until they aren’t showing. If you just take a few seconds to think about the best way to take your photo it will result in a really nice image you can be proud of.

image.altText: The Car Stays in the Picture

pageElements.text:
5. Get close.

Try taking a photo of the little people in your life playing together, with the car filling the background. This gives you just a little glimpse of the car while your kids are the main focus. This is an easy way to take a simple photo where everything in the frame is something that is important to you.
After you have taken these photos, just put them somewhere safe and wait. In ten to fifteen years and beyond, the details of time and place will come more sharply into focus than they are now.
You’ll probably laugh at your hair and your clothes, but if you are lucky you might say to yourself, “Wow. I don’t remember ever looking that cool.”

contributors.bio:
Jean Jennings has been writing about cars and the car business for more than thirty years. She learned about cars at the kitchen table from her father Robert, the late editor of Automotive News. At the age of eighteen, she bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, Jennings went to Chrysler’s test track where she worked as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, she was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine when she was laid off her Chrysler job, and in 1985 she left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr., as its first executive editor. She became Editor-in-Chief in 2000 and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

Jennings has won awards for her feature writing, for her car reviews, and for her monthly Automobile Magazine column “Vile Gossip.” She was the recipient of the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism. Jennings has the unique experience, sensibility, and personality to connect with women and to give them voice in the male-dominated automotive space. She was the subject of a Susan Orlean profile in the New Yorker, has appeared on numerous television news shows, has been on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno, and was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000.

She is currently a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News.

Jennings lives in the Michigan countryside with her husband, Tim, and the entire food chain.

pageElements.text: Q. "Alphabet" questions: What is the effect of ABS, ASC, AWD, RWD and FWD in the snow?
Ancient Motorbiker asked me this question on our Jean Knows Cars Facebook page. Thanks for the inspiration!

A. First off, Ancient One, my motorcycling days came to a rapid close after a few years of riding, mostly because I was acutely (and constantly) aware that my lack of experience on a bike left me empty handed in an emergency. On the other hand, I have spent more than three decades driving very fast on closed courses, including time spent practicing emergency avoidance techniques and drills to sharpen my skills for when the shit inevitably hits the fan.
So my experience applies only to four-wheeled vehicles. And I would add that my answers don’t apply to driving on ice, where the only things that work are ice skates and hockey pucks.

ABS

Anti-lock Braking Systems help prevent your wheels from locking up in a skid by automatically pumping the brakes way faster than your puny little legs can do it. All you have to do is slam your foot on the brake pedal and hold it there. The real beauty (and point) is that you can still steer the car, so even if you are skidding to an eventual ABS stop, you have some maneuverability.

Warning: Your ABS stopping distance can be longer in the snow than an old-fashioned two-feet-on-the-brake-pedal skid, because a skid builds up snow in front of your four wheels, eventually helping to stop your car. The most modern four-wheel ABS works by sensing wheel lockup and unlocking that wheel until all four wheels are stopped. No skid, no little snow wedgies.
Lesson: Keep your distance, slow down for stop signs and curves, and practice your braking in an empty parking lot or with plenty of room to stop before you really need them.

ESC

Electronic Stability Control (sometimes known as automatic stability control, or ASC) is a fantastic system, which the federal government says reduces single-vehicle car crashes by 35 percent and single-vehicle SUV crashes by 67 percent. ESC senses when you’ve gotten in over your head in a turn—typically, you’re going too fast, causing oversteer or understeer—and applies brakes at individual wheels as needed to settle the car down. You can see how this could be helpful in the snow. It’s when you’re stopped in the deep snow (or stuck) that ESC can work against you. That’s when you’ll want to find the switch that turns it off, allowing you to spin your wheels and rock your way out of deeper snow.
Warning: Just don’t forget to turn it back on.
Nothing helps a rear-wheel-drive car more in snowy conditions than a good set of real snow tires.

RWD

Rear-wheel-drive vehicles can be the most difficult to manage in snow, but when I was growing up, that’s all we had. (I’m an excellent drifter, by the way!) When your rear drive wheels are the ones that lose traction, they tend to slide out, and when that happens, a spin is not far behind. It helps to get weight over those rear wheels to improve traction. Use big bags of kitty litter in the trunk, not sandbags. Sand freezes; kitty litter doesn’t. When you’re stuck on glare ice, you can pack the litter around the wheel to give your tires something to grab on to.
Nothing helps a rear-wheel-drive car more in snowy conditions than a good set of real snow tires.
Lesson: In a rear-wheel-drive car, drive into the slide. That is, if the rear slides out to the right, steer into the right. Practice this in an empty parking lot.

FWD

Front-wheel-drive cars are famously good in the snow, especially in hilly areas. With the engine sitting over the drive wheels—and let’s say those wheels are shod with real snow tires—you’ve got weight and traction up front, pulling everything along behind it. You’ve almost got yourself a little tractor. In fact, are you sure you need four-wheel drive?
Warning: All that weight causes wear and tear on front brakes and tires.

AWD

All-wheel drive is the kind of vehicle to own in the Snow Belt (and where the rain can be heavy) if you’re not a hard-core off-roader. It offers traction at all four wheels, but it apportions the amount of traction to the wheels without your input. So you don’t have to slow to a crawl and flip levers; you don’t have to get out and lock wheel hubs. Very civilized. And it’s easier on your wallet at the gas pumps, too.
Some all-wheel-drive systems also allow you to lock in four-wheel drive, making them more useful in snowier climes and off-road.

title: 10 Cars for Downton Abbey's Women
promoTeaserSmall: Jump forward in time, and let's imagine what cars they'd drive if they were going to a dealer today.

pageElements.text: I just learned on the TV news that Barack Obama enjoys watching Downton Abbey. I’m not sure what impact that has on his policy agenda, but it’s nice to hear that our head of state is emotionally involved in the life stories of such beautifully drawn characters as Mrs. Patmore, dominator of the kitchen, and Lady Mary, the emotionally challenged widowed aristocrat.

One thing Downton Abbey and President Obama have in common is an extremely rich online population of detail checkers and historical-accuracy wonks. Check out for yourself the Internet Movie Car Database, which grouses: “The second season ends in 1920, yet we see a 1925 Sunbeam and numerous Model T Fords that hadn't been built yet.” Excellent point, although not one that takes much away from enjoyment of the period-charm series.

It made me wonder, though: Suppose there really was no need for historical accuracy, and the characters in Downton Abbey could step out of time and choose whatever 2014 model car they felt best expressed their personalities?

Here’s a highly subjective list of some of the current starring women of Downton Abbey, and what I imagine they would choose to drive from today's showrooms. What do you think of my suggestions? Got some of your own? Please comment!

1. Violet, The Dowager Countess of Grantham (Maggie Smith)

First of all, the Dowager Countess would never stoop to drive herself. She is shown in Season 4 of Downton Abbey being chauffeured in a traditional 1920s luxury tourer. As a modern shopper, I think she would choose a Mercedes-Benz S550 sedan in basic black with the nut brown/black leather interior and burl walnut trim, none of which cost extra. It could be driven by a modern-day chauffeur quite well. She’d give approval to the heated rear seats ($620), but she’d disdain the cabin fragrances and air purification of the Air Balance package ($350) as tacky. Total cost: $94,445, including destination. As Oscar Wilde would say, Violet is a woman who has very simple tastes: she is always satisfied with the best.

Jean disagrees, feeling sure the Dowager would have a Rolls-Royce. Much as I can see Violet in the back seat of a Phantom, I believe she'd choose a lower profile and more discretion on modern streets. But let's split the difference and presume she would own both the Rolls and the S-Class.

2. Cora, Lady Grantham (Elizabeth McGovern)

Coming from money that she couldn’t keep control of, and far from her home country, Lady Grantham needs to be driving an American car. I'd love to see her in something resolutely modern, in which, as a soon-to-be empty nester, she can go have an independent adventure for once. How about a Tesla Model S? Hers would be in Tesla's aristocratic-looking multi-coat Pearl White. She'd also get the all-glass panoramic roof. Inside would be tan leather seats with lacewood accents. The price would come to $69,720 total, assuming she got the U.S. tax credits, and she can have one of the footmen plug it in during the evenings.

3. Lady Mary (Michelle Dockery)

Her husband having been killed behind the wheel of a sporty AC Six Roadster in Season Three, Lady Mary will value safety...and a closed roof. I see her in a top-end Audi A8 4.0 TFSI, with quattro all-wheel drive and an eight-speed automatic transmission. She’ll choose it in a personality-matching Glacier White metallic, with Titanium Gray Valletta leather seats. Lady Mary will definitely check the box for the $3,250 Driver Assistance package (adaptive cruise control, top-view camera, Audi side assist, and lane assist), plus the required additional Premium package ($4,000) with LED lights, ventilated massaging front seats, and more safety features. None of it might have saved Matthew, but Lady Mary is all about self-preservation. She’s got an empire to build. Total cost: $91,150, including destination.

4. Lady Edith (Laura Carmichael)

Left at the altar, undermined by her older sister, and condescended to by almost everyone else, Lady Edith is just not a lucky person. She loves cars, though, so let’s picture her going down the road in the new BMW 4 Series coupe. (She does seem to have Germany in her future, after all.) Let's let her have it in the Sport Line trim. Hers might be the Mineral Grey Metallic outside, and an interior in Coral Red Dakota leather with black accent stitching, complemented by brushed aluminum trim. She'll take the Technology package ($3,150) giving her BMW's navigation system, head-up display, and smartphone apps, and the Dynamic Handling package ($1,000) for the variable sport steering and adaptive M suspension. She'll want to be civilized but drive fast, and there's no doubt she'd be an early adopter of technology. Top it off with the six-speed manual transmission (a no-cost option), and she'll be paying a reasonable $53,775 (including destination). Her other car, by the way, is a black Chevrolet Corvette roadster.

5. Lady Rose MacClare (Lily James)

A relatively new addition to the ensemble cast, Lady Rose is young, silly, and doesn’t mind slumming at a thé-dansant with the working class, as long as she can get back into her silk in time to join the ruling class for dinner at the castle. She’d like to drive a Mazda MX-5 Miata to let her buzz back and forth from one walk of life to another. The Miata would be the top Grand Touring model with a power retractable hard top and black leather seats. She’d look at it in Zeal Red but go with the cuter and less aggressive Liquid Silver in the end. She’d pay an extra $1,390 for the Premium package to get the Bluetooth connectivity that she'd rarely stop using while driving. Total cost: $32,735. I suspect she’s destined to be married off before long to someone who has a Bentley and no sense of humor, so let her have her fun for now.

6. Isobel Crawley (Penelope Wilton)

Mrs. Crawley is nothing if not sensible. She always has some kind of social-work project or garden activity in the works, so she would be an excellent customer for a Volvo wagon. The Volvo XC60 T6 AWD crossover would suit her need for timeless quality and meet her requirement for strictly no frivolity. She might choose it in Twilight Bronze Metallic (a $550 option), a resolute color for middle-class tastes. Inside, she’d pick the Soft Beige leather upholstery and walnut trim. She’d spring for the rational Technology package ($1,500) for its adaptive cruise control, lane departure alert, and collision warning with auto brake. She might add on the park assist camera ($850) but would draw the line at adding any luxury options with no practical purpose. Total cost: $45,365, including destination. She’d enjoy bringing it in under $50,000, I suspect.

7. Mrs. Hughes (Phyllis Logan)

The Scottish house mother puts on no airs, but her longing for a little romance in her life is undeniable. She should be driving something indulgent, but she’d be more likely to turn wistfully to a duller car. But this is my fantasy, so she gets a Cadillac ATS. She’d choose it in Radiant Silver, with the base 2.5-liter four-cylinder that makes 202 horsepower, and choose the caramel-and-black leatherette interior. Since this would be a big expenditure for her, she’d spring for the theft-deterrent Advanced Security package ($380). She’d love the Cadillac CUE telematics and the SiriusXM, both included. Final price: $35,270, including destination. Maybe she can get Carson to go for a spin.

8. Anna Bates (Joanne Froggatt)

Anna has made the best of the hard knocks she’s been presented with, and who (besides Thomas Barrow, perhaps) can fail to love her? She is always warm and kind, but clearly she has very few illusions. Even if she had money, she would not waste a cent on comforts for herself. Her husband, of course, Mr. Bates, needs an accessible vehicle. I think the Bateses would like a Dodge Grand Caravan. Minivans are easy to get in and out of, and they are practical for the occasional picnic or trip to London to investigate the latest intrigue in either of their lives. (Besides, I harbor a personal hope that they’ll have or adopt children eventually.) They’d pick the base American Value Package model, in cheerful Redline Red. Despite the base trim level, they’d get Chrysler’s UConnect audio, a six-speed automatic transmission, and a 3.6-liter V-6. Mrs. Bates would appreciate this simple but friendly transport, especially since she’d get it for a total of $20,490.

9. Mrs. Patmore (Lesley Nicol)

I love the frazzled kitchen despot Mrs. Patmore. She’s very uncomfortable with technology and change, so she will need a car that is extremely user-friendly and traditionally designed. She’d probably love the Toyota RAV4. I think a woman who spends most of her life trapped below stairs would enjoy a moonroof, so she’ll step up to the midlevel XLE to get one. She will stick with the front-wheel-drive model, though; no AWD newfangledness for her. The four-cylinder engine and six-speed automatic transmission are plenty exciting enough. She’d like the pretty green Spruce Mica exterior, which would go nicely with what’s left of the red in her hair, teamed with a sensible black cloth interior. Total price: $25,150. I just hope she takes time to go for a drive on her half-day off.

10. Daisy Mason (Sophie McShera)

Last but not least, we come to Daisy, the kitchen maid turned assistant cook. She still wears her wedding ring, I noticed in Episode 1 of Season 4, although her marriage to a dying young soldier lasted only minutes. This hard-working girl is still a dreamer, and since she has become close to a doting father-in-law, she is definitely on the move upward from extremely impoverished beginnings in life. She would look good behind the wheel of a Volkswagen Beetle, and she'd like one in sunny Yellow Rush. Let's make it the TDI for durability and fuel economy; Daisy is likely to keep a car for a long time. The Sunroof, Sound & Navigation model, with a six-speed automatic with Tiptronic and sport mode, adds up to $28,915, a lot for an assistant cook but not too much for the eventual head of the Downton kitchen. Take that, Ivy!

title: Why Kevin Loves His Nissan Titan

contributors.bio: I was a contributing editor to the (now sadly defunct) Art Economist and have been published in Cosmopolitan, New York magazine, the New York Post, US, and Avenue magazine. I blog (about arts, not cars) for The Huffington Post, and you'll notice in my photo there that I am also a hat lady.

pageElements.text: Kevin Kanz loves his 2005 Nissan Texas Titan so much that he says, “I’m going to drive it until the wheels fall off!”

Kevin refers to himself as an “Urban Redneck.”  We are in Sunset Canyon, a subdivision of Austin, in Texas Hill Country west of downtown, emerging from his spacious pickup.  Kevin has masterfully driven through twenty-five acres of rugged fields bursting with blue-green buffalo grass, vegetation native to North America for at least seven million years.  I watch him change the batteries on some jury-rigged feeders, which are distributing cracked corn, millet, and pumpkin seeds, revivifying local animal life that had been vanishing from the region and attracting native pigs, deer, bobcats, and wild turkeys.  Kevin is not only passionate about his Titan, but deeply committed to wildlife management.  He repairs fences and tracks returning flora and fauna, helping to restore various local lands to their pre-developed states.  These are properties that have been decimated from years of pasturing horses, cattle, and goats.  He shows me pup tents, where deer are photographed and counted.  And even though suburban houses are nearby, all is quiet and the fields are full of persimmon, red oak, native ash, and juniper trees.

His muscular full-size truck has 205,000 miles on it, and he swears it has been almost problem-free. A dedicated fisherman and bow-and-arrow hunter, Kevin shows me how his bed extender and removable tailgate are ideal for carrying feed, camping gear, and other equipment. And he explains that unlike some other pickup trucks, his rear cargo area has a spray-in bedliner coating rather than the typical plastic, which he finds much more durable and less prone to scratching and rust.
I bought it brand-new in 2005.  At the time, it had the largest interior of a half-ton pickup, and I have kids.

Kevin is by profession a chiropractor with offices near the University of Texas campus.  That bed extender and the Titan’s dampened assist tailgate have also proven useful when he has needed to carry his professional tables to various athletic events.  As the former president of the Texas Chiropractic Association, Kevin was often required to drive across that grand state of his.  He also travels for hunting and angling excursions, out to Port Aransas on Mustang Island, a barrier island on the Gulf Coast, or to the swamps of Bedias Creek, a tributary of the Trinity River between Dallas and Houston.  A single dad of two, he makes locally legendary organic meals from his catch and kills.  And he partners with both a UT biology professor and a Texas Natural Resources attorney in wildlife management and preservation efforts, including the restocking of the fields.

Nissan’s Titan, the Japanese carmaker’s pickup, manufactured in Mississippi, is so popular in these parts that there is a special Texas limited edition, introduced at the Texas State Fair in 2004. Kevin’s fine white vehicle is from that first crop. The original Texas Titan package included a state badge on the tailgate, a chrome billet front grille, chrome step rails, eighteen-inch chrome-clad wheels, chrome outside mirrors and door handles, fog lamps, a rear sonar system, special dash accents, lockable bedside storage, carpeted floor mats featuring the Texas star, and a power adjustable driver’s seat with lumbar support (excellent ergonomics are very important to a chiropractor!).

Kevin purchased the Crew Cab, which offers roomier rear seating than the King Cab. He also has a leather-clad steering wheel, traction control, a cargo lamp, a power sliding rear window, and great center consoles and storage. Aftermarket, Kevin added power struts and power shocks and the largest tires for his vehicle; he gained two and a half inches of lift. And I sat on his camouflage fabric seat covers in the front cab.

Kevin says, “I bought it brand-new in 2005.  At the time, it had the largest interior of a half-ton pickup, and I have kids. I like a nice big engine and wanted to haul anything I needed to haul: bicycles, kayaks, a trailer.  Other people might even tow a mobile home.  It had a real good maintenance record and an excellent transmission. And it’s comfortable.”

And while native Texan Kevin Kanz sits up high and clearly requires four-wheel drive for his wilderness forays, his Nissan offers 305 horsepower, 379 pound-feet of torque, and up to 9,500 pounds of towing.  It has a 5.6-liter V-8 engine.  While Titans are not known for their fuel economy, and this one is rated at 13 mpg city and 17 mpg highway, Kevin describes his truck as “greener,” and it definitely is at least a little cleaner and less carbon intensive, as it is a flexible fuel vehicle burning E85 and reducing emissions.
[Guys like me] may have other cars, but we all have a pickup because there are things you can do with a pickup you can’t do with anything else.
Kevin says about guys like him: "We may have other cars, but we all have a pickup because there are things you can do with a pickup you can’t do with anything else."
Kevin mentions that he is cooking a venison roast tonight, in a Crock-Pot, with apples, apricots, potatoes, and garlic.
The Texas Titan lets out a deep growl as we drive back on U.S. 290.

pageElements.text: This all begs the question that’s burning in my mind. “Will my next car do the driving so I can have back all that time I waste on long freeway drives and bumper-to-bumper traffic?”
“This is all in the research stage,” BMW’s Werner Huber  told me with a sly smile. “Though technically we are very close to a car that can do that."

“This is all in the research stage,” BMW’s Werner Huber told me with a sly smile. “Though technically we are very close to a car that can do that.” He is head of Driver Assistance and Environmental Perception at BMW Group Research and Technology. But just because the technology exists doesn’t mean you can buy it. Sure, you'll have a choice of cars that can park themselves in the next couple of years. But a fully automated car is a long way off. And one reason for that is evident in Bosch’s demonstration of that self-parking car technology.

Before that demonstration car would park, the driver had to accept a liability waiver. And the app he used to manage the parking remotely requires that the driver touch an icon while the car parks. If he lifts his finger off the icon, the car stops. There is a good reason for this.

“The driver must always be in control of the car, even if the car is in an automatic mode,” explained Huber. Legally, the liability for anything the car does must be with the human. So, even though research prototype automated cars can technically do a lot of things on their own, we can’t let them. Allowing the car to drive means changing laws that vary by state and country and that have governed transportation for decades. No easy task. And not a task that is likely to happen in time for me to start shopping for a fully automatic car anytime soon.

Until the legal landscape is clear, explains Huber, car manufacturers will keep testing the limits of human control of the vehicle. Cars will increasingly correct mistakes, take over some of the driving chores, and intervene in case of emergency by braking or correcting the human's steering. Cars might be able to take over in some circumstances or at some speeds. But the driver will have to maintain ultimate decision making power.
And that is bad news for that nap I was hoping to take during my commute.

title: 2013 Nissan Juke Nismo
promoTeaserSmall: This quirky crossover's looks, but not its continuously variable transmission, won my heart.
promoTeaser: This quirky crossover's looks, but not its continuously variable transmission, won my heart.
metaDescription: 2013 Nissan Juke Nismo - This quirky crossover's looks, but not its continuously variable transmission, won my heart. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
Price: $25,290 base price of this model
$27,710 as tested (including destination)
Engine: 1.6-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 197 horsepower, 184 lb-ft of torque
Transmission: Continuously variable
Fuel economy: 25 mpg city/30 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Nismo Alcantara and leather interior with red leather accents
Option I can’t live without: Rockford Fosgate premium sound system (part of $1,170 Navigation package)
Notable standard features on this model: Intelligent Key with push-button start, Bluetooth connectivity, Sirius XM, halogen headlights with auto off; NISMO-tuned engine, transmission, suspension, and steering; NISMO styling cues including gauges, shift knob, grille and spoiler, and mirror covers
Notable options on this model: Navigation package ($1,170) including Nissan navigation system, Rockford Fosgate premium audio, USB connectivity, rearview camera, all with five-inch color touchscreen
You might also be considering: Hyundai Veloster Turbo, Kia Soul, Mini Countryman

I’ve always had a thing for quirky crossovers. When my parents and I were shopping for my first car, I fought hard for a first-generation Scion xB before eventually settling on a 2006 Chevrolet HHR. I’ve since moved on to a more sophisticated ride—although I miss my HHR almost every day—but I still have a soft spot for the weirdos of the car world. Which is why I’ve been itching to drive the undeniably odd Nissan Juke. Even better: when I finally got the chance, it was the 2013 Juke Nismo, the performance version of Nissan’s smallest crossover.

Performance is a relative term, though, and the Juke Nismo we tested was still a far cry from being truly sporty. The 1.6-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine makes 197 horsepower and 184 pound-feet of torque. That’s just 11 extra horsepower compared with the base Juke powertrain. Our Juke came outfitted with a continuously variable transmission (CVT), which immediately disappointed me. I was hoping for a six-speed manual transmission, which is available with the front-wheel-drive version of the Juke. Our all-wheel-drive model was only available with the continuously variable transmission, a notoriously sluggish setup.
I have a soft spot for the weirdos of the car world. Which is why I’ve been itching to drive the undeniably odd Nissan Juke.

The Juke Nismo AWD feels nimble and planted on the road, thanks in part to a Nismo-tuned suspension, and it is plenty willing to be tossed around corners. But during my weekend with the Juke, I never stopped wishing for a manual transmission. The CVT got bogged down in the high rpm on acceleration, giving the car an undesirable four-cylinder engine whine soundtrack. I’ve felt for some time now that the best way to enjoy a car with middling power is to drive it with a manual transmission. Focusing on timing shifts just right and executing them well is what turns a decent car into a fun one.

What the Juke Nismo AWD was lacking in driving enjoyment, it makes up for with lovably wacky styling. Starting with the base Juke’s odd, squat body, the Juke Nismo adds a revised grille and front fascia designed to allow more air through the engine bay. Red door mirrors and gloss black B-pillars and door sills, as well as Nismo badging on the grille and the rear, cue the viewer that this is not your everyday Juke. Ours came with sparkling Pearl White paint, and I found the white-and-red color scheme attractively sporty without being obnoxious.

All Juke Nismos come with black cloth seats and interior trim. The interior was comfortable and attractive, if not particularly spacious. I was flummoxed by the controls on the center stack, though. A small screen below the infotainment system showed real-time information about g-forces and torque distribution (helpful, I guess?), but I couldn’t find the climate controls anywhere. Some experimenting revealed that pressing a button above that display labeled “climate” brought up fan direction controls and temperature information, but it was an odd design that I never quite got used to.

The Verdict:

I still have a tender place in my heart for the Nissan Juke, which I think is a fine example of fearlessly strange automotive design. If you’re looking for a car about this size with unusual looks, there aren’t a ton of choices. A Hyundai Veloster Turbo could fill the bill and is fairly fun to drive, but it’s a shade smaller. A Mini has plenty of attitude, but it’s a bit pricier. So the Juke Nismo should be a good Goldilocks option. And from what I’ve heard, the front-wheel-drive Juke Nismo equipped with a manual transmission is genuinely fun to drive. But I was ultimately underwhelmed by this package and what I considered to be its dull transmission. If you’re interested in one of these, shop away! But my advice is, steer clear of the CVT.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly Jean: I am often intimidated by cars that manufacturers create specifically for the tuner crowd. The Juke Nismo reeled me in with its red mirrors, white jellybean design, and nice Nismo details on the interior. I especially liked the slice of red leather on the steering wheel. But what really landed me was how fun the Juke was to toss around the mean streets of Ann Arbor. I am a rule follower, but I was weaving and juking around traffic, possibly stretching a law or three.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: Don’t cry for me, Argentina…
Dateline: Detroit, Michigan, New Year’s Eve, 14 degrees F

It was 4:45 a.m. when we jumped in the Acura MDX and headed for the airport for our 8:00 a.m. departure for Maui. It takes about an hour to get to DTW. Don’t ask. If he could, Tim Jennings would settle in with a good book at the gate four hours before a flight's departure time. I will admit that a storm was on its way and if we missed the flight to Maui, I would surely die. Not to put too fine a point on it.
Acura MDX Point #1: Great heated seats, but where’s the heated steering wheel?? What did I care? Tim was driving, and I was fast asleep within ten minutes.
This would be our first visit to that particularly fabulous Hawaiian island. We were guests of Hyundai, who generously included my husband so he could carry my bags. As if.
The closest I got to driving a car on Maui was driving a bar stool in the poolside tiki-hut bar and being served by an exceptional waitress named Portia.

I would like to clear the air up front by saying the closest I got to driving a car on Maui was driving a bar stool in the poolside tiki-hut bar and being served by an exceptional waitress named Portia. This was not an official test drive event. Hyundai was there as title sponsor of the PGA Tournament of Champions. We were there for the golf. That’s right, golf.

I golf, but not as seriously as you might imagine. I already have a high-pressure job; I don’t need a high-pressure sport. I have been known to pay my caddy to throw the ball down course when the going gets rough. I didn’t golf in Hawaii, but Hyundai’s charming public relations chief, Chris Hosford, mysteriously came up with a slot in the Pro-Am game for husband Tim, which made him nearly swoon. He was paired with Matt Kuchar (right), a car fanatic and genuinely nice guy who asked me to recommend a beach car for his home on Sea Island, Georgia. That would be a Fiat Jolly, Matt. Check out Jerry Seinfeld and Louis C.K. testing Seinfeld’s Jolly in Comedian in Cars Drinking Coffee.

Instead of hitting the little round white ball, I took a yoga class every morning, got a massage and a facial, did the coastal walk one day, and had an umbrella drink every afternoon. In the evenings, I hung out with Hyundai dealers (you do know how I love good car dealers!), who were still buzzing over the sudden “resignation” of Hyundai’s U.S. CEO, John Krafcik. I don’t read anything into this regarding hard-charging, high-energy engineer Krafcik. He was wildly successful and worked like a demon, but he would not be the first Hyundai boss blown out by the Koreans in the wake of a great sales year. The head of sales, dealer fave Dave Zuchowski, was named to replace Krafcik.

I don't want to dwell on the 85 degrees, the sun, the seas, the whales breaching just offshore, and the warm trade winds, because arriving home to a blizzard after four days in paradise was a way more real reality. If you know what I mean.
The Acura MDX was waiting to suck all the luggage back in its vast hold (there was plenty including golf clubs), and took us home through a raging blizzard.
Acura MDX Point #2: Great heated seats, but where’s the heated steering wheel?? I care!

It hasn't been this cold in Michigan in twenty years anyway. In the old days, we used to count on one weekend where the mercury would hover at -40, -50, even -60 degrees Fahrenheit with the wind chill factor. It has been brutally cold since we arrived home. We saw -20 real degrees on the thermostat two days in a row and a windchill of -35 on Monday. I had to leave the house to come to work because it was too cold in the farmhouse. The howling wind pummeled our house, finding its way inside under every door, through every crack and every bit of loose grout.

I couldn't contemplate sleeping in the icy bedroom, so I ripped the down comforter off the bed and made my way to the couch right in front of the fireplace. Tim went upstairs with Stella (who would just as soon kill Ray the Stray as look at him), while I settled in with the other three dogs. Louie was curled on a thick dog bed next to the couch, and Bob was sprawled on the floor, but Ray crawled right up on top of my chest, spun twice, and curled up like an armadillo. On my chest.

I can make a Chesapeake move out of my spot on the bed, but I cannot make that hound dog move an inch. I cannot make that hound dog do anything that he doesn't want to do. He is fierce. On the other hand, he is also a very, very warm sixty-two-pound pet rock.

Today was the fourth day of solid sub-zero temps. By now, I not only want the Acura to have a heated steering wheel, I want the armrests to be heated, the headliner to be heated, and the windows to be heated.
Overpasses are skating rinks, glinting in the morning sun, which I find easiest to traverse by putting my two outside wheels on the snowy shoulder for support.

The roads are still a disaster out here. Even the freeway ramps are just packed snow. One of three freeway lanes is actually cleared. Overpasses are skating rinks, glinting in the morning sun, which I find easiest to traverse by putting my two outside wheels on the snowy shoulder for support.

I was surprised to find a bad shudder throughout the Acura at more than 65 miles an hour on the freeway. I suspected snow in the wheel wells, and when it didn't get better after ten miles, I pulled in to a gas station for a look. I kicked giant chunks of snow out of all four wheel wells but could do nothing about the ice that had packed the right rear wheel itself.

I took off, and after about five miles, the ride straightened out considerably. It was just too brutally cold to hit the car wash, even though car washes use heated water. I just wasn’t prepared to deal with the resulting frozen door locks and iced-over windows and frozen window winders and so on.

The North American International Auto Show kicks off this weekend for the press, and a warm spell is predicted. That means it will be 45 degrees and raining, and I couldn’t be happier. Bring on the sleet! Bring on the slush! Because right now, the Acura’s floorboard is so cold that, even using heat aimed at the floor, my feet are frozen.

Love,
Jean

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.
