contributors.bio: I was born a suburban Detroit gal where the preoccupation with cars is practically genetic.  As a young adult I kicked around motor-racing, training to drive while I worked at a Brands Hatch satellite in Miami.  I've been race staff at the Detroit Grand Prix, worked TV coverage of Formula 1, Indy and NASCAR and done the occasional ride and drive program.  Eventually my racing aspirations gave way to a long held interest in filmmaking and I got my B.A. from the University of Michigan's burgeoning film program.  U of M taught me to write and introduced me to my excellent husband.  We spent five adventurous years in Los Angeles in the entertainment and publishing industries before returning to Ann Arbor where our lovely daughter came into the world.  Personally, I expend a good deal of energy on K-12 public education advocacy.  Professionally, I've been a freelance writer for the last ten years specializing in health issues and automotive content from a lifestyle perspective.  There's a lot more to auto life than zero to sixty.

pageElements.text: In the years since my daughter, Rory, was born, we’ve had our share of girly mother-daughter outings: visits to the hair salon, ladies’ tea, and the American Girl store. Last MLK Day, my daughter had the day off from school,  and I suggested another kind of excursion, her first North American International Auto Show in Detroit.  My parents took my sister, brother, and me. Now it was her turn.

I had my concerns about how this would go, since there’s a certain way one does the auto show. The goal is to sit in as many vehicles as possible, which takes hours. And up until that day, Rory had exhibited only a passing interest in cars. While driving, if I yelled out: “Look look look! It’s the brand-new Ford Escape!” she would muster a halfhearted “Oh, Mom, that’s great.”

Also, there is the endless walking. The show covers what feels like like a million square feet of the Cobo Center convention hall in Detroit. That’s once you get inside. First you have to withstand the cruel run from even the closest possible parking through the bone-chilling winds. We’re talking lung-stopping icy air that rips through the absurdly light jacket you wear, even though it’s January in Michigan, because you plan to skip the coat check line.
The massive digital walls screamed “spectacle,” and her nine-year-old eyes lit up like we were in Cinderella’s castle.

On entering the expansive show floor, though, Rory was dazzled. Bright lights bounced off perfectly polished metal, chrome, and plastic. Futuristic concept cars spun on glamorous revolving platforms, the massive digital walls screamed “spectacle,” and her nine-year-old eyes lit up like we were in Cinderella’s castle. But would she last from the first Acura to the last Z coupe?

Maybe I shouldn’t have worried. Automobiles have fascinated humans since they first puttered past the horse and buggy, and given the right presentation, my daughter was not immune. While I lusted after the Tesla Model X—I'm a sucker for a car with falcon-wing doors—her tastes ran from the very small to the ridiculously huge. I couldn’t get her away from tiny cars like the Smart Fortwo, the Minis, or the new Fiat 500. “It’s just my size!” she exclaimed.

The reverse was true when we approached a humongous Jeep, roll bar exposed and monster tires looming large.  She happily waited a good ten minutes behind a bunch of other kids, and, ahem, grown men, to literally climb up into the seats.

When I was a kid, the thrill was simply getting the chance to sit in a fresh-off-the-line Corvette. Now manufacturers have added high-tech interactive displays. At the Michelin booth, we could feel what it’s like to Be the Tire by standing on a road-approximating pedestal. Subaru’s giant touchpad not only took our picture but allowed Rory to place us in a beach scene with a bright blue BRZ, surfboard, tent, and even a bald eagle swooping at our heads. Once complete, we e-mailed the final picture off to my husband via the same touchpad.
In the Mazda simulator, Rory was nervous when I secured her five-point harness, but fear gave way to giddiness as we were pitched into each curve of the virtual Laguna Seca racetrack.
I couldn’t get her away from tiny cars like the Smart Fortwo, the Minis, or the Fiat 500. “It’s just my size!” she exclaimed.

Midday, we refueled with $10 hamburgers in the glass-walled food court and watched the freighters passing along the Detroit River. I found myself telling Rory the stories my parents had told me whenever we were downtown. The Motor City was the land of opportunity when they came in 1949, and even as the city declined, they wanted to make sure we kids still appreciated that legacy. For Rory, the city’s current struggles are eclipsed by the inspiring Detroit destinations she loves: a Tigers baseball game, the Thanksgiving Day Parade, and the Detroit Institute of Arts.

That January day, she added another event to her list: the auto show. After lunch, we tied our coats around our waists and began Round Two. As we slipped back into the sea of auto lovers from every walk of life, I knew she was hooked. “Oh, Mom, let’s make sure we find that Lincoln that everyone is talking about.”

If you're in the area, this year's North American International Auto Show opens to the public on Saturday, January 18, and runs through Sunday, January 26. The show is open 9 a.m. to 10 p.m., except the final day, when it closes at 7 p.m. You can buy online tickets here.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: We call our Chesapeake Bay retriever Bob "the reluctant show dog" because he'd really rather be out hunting with Tim or hanging around with our other dogs than on the show circuit. At least, that's what we used to think. Lately he has been on a serious winning streak.

This past weekend, at the Michigan Winter Dog Classic, he won Best of Breed all four days (in a field of nineteen to twenty-one Chessies). In the capable hands of handler John Benoit, Bob also had his best finish ever, third in the highly competitive Sporting group.

This was his last show before Westminster. The Westminster Kennel Club's 138th annual show is February 10 and 11 in New York City, and Tim and I will be there and hoping not to jinx GCH Irish's Robert Garcia de Padua, a.k.a. Bob, during his big moment in the national spotlight.
He'll train by standing very still in the kitchen for the next three weeks, begging.

We will know soon whether he is the number-one Chessie in the 2014 standings. That won't last long, because we don't show him much, so once we see the official standings, we'll print it out, guzzle good champagne, and keep it in the box with the ribbons.
Craft ideas for displaying a couple hundred ribbons are welcome...

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: I was there when they departed before dawn on Sunday, January 5, steering through the throng of spectators who had stayed all night near Argentina’s national flag memorial to see them off. Among the 196 motorcyclists entering the Dakar Rally, two women had a great chance, although they were also subject to the same potential perils awaiting all riders.

One week later, the Dakar—the marathon 6,000-mile rally through three South American countries—neared its halfway point. Then, everything came to a stop: this was the scheduled rest day for riders, drivers, and their crews.

By this time, Laia Sanz, the Spaniard who has multiple world championships in the difficult sport of motorcycle trials, had distinguished herself, climbing to nineteenth place overall after the first six of thirteen grueling daily stages. She went on to finish in sixteenth place.

Another Spaniard, Rosa Romero, with two previous Dakars to her credit, dropped out of competition after the fourth stage. (Her husband, Nani Roma, and his co-driver were the winners of the Rally in a field of 154 cars.)

Sanz, aboard a Honda 450 Rally, had an especially strong second day on a grueling special stage that covered nearly 400 miles. Not all of the 196 riders listed in the class could say as much; dozens withdrew during the course of the rally. The Belgian rider Eric Palante was found dead during Stage Five.
As if technical and physical skills weren’t enough, riders must also do their own navigating, scrolling through the route instructions on a console above the handlebars.

I was following the Dakar in person through its first two stages, from the starting point of Rosario, the third-largest city in Argentina, to Mendoza, in the wine country at the base of the Andes Mountains. Flying out the next morning, I waited in the security line with a rider for KTM, the powerhouse Austrian team, whose right arm was in a sling. “A lot of rocks and stones,” he told me.

Besides Sanz and Romero, Italian Camelia Liparoti was one of forty-seven human rag dolls in the ATV class. Motorcycles somehow made sense when we saw them on the back roads and trails, but ATVs—or quads, as they’re called here—look as though they want to pitch the person onto an Andean peak. Liparoti, on a Yamaha, held thirteenth in class as the Dakar resumed for stage seven, having averaged ten-plus hours in the saddle on each of the first six days. More than half the starting field of quads had dropped out. Liparoti finished the Dakar Rally, still thirteenth in class after more than 111 hours of riding.

Formerly known as the Paris-Dakar Rally, this craziness was initiated in 1979 and ran from various points of origin—initially Paris, but also from Valencia, Spain, and once from Cairo, Egypt—before finishing in Dakar, Senegal. It took three weeks—and sometimes a life. Terrorist threats in 2008 caused the rally’s cancellation that year. Coming back the next, it was relabeled the Dakar, and it ran through South America, where it has been a big success.

Besides the quads and abundant motorcycles and cars (and buggies, Jeeps, and pickups bundled in that class), there is a fourth class for the most beastly-looking heavy trucks anyone could imagine. They all run the same course. This involves transit stages over normal highways, but then, in special stages contested against the clock, the “road book” filled with course instructions leads competitors onto secondary byways, across sand dunes, and over narrow trails. The motorcycles have a unique two-day interlude at high altitude in Bolivia.
The finishers receive accolades but no money—this is all for glory—on reaching Valparaíso, Chile, on Sunday, January 17.

No motor race is more demanding, especially for the riders. As if their technical and physical skills weren’t enough, they must also do their own navigating, scrolling through the route instructions on a console above the handlebars. The driver of a car has it comparatively easy, communicating by intercom with the navigation specialist.
During the night, everybody puts up with the noise as mechanics tear down each vehicle and replace key parts, as well as tires, in order to be ready for the next stage.

Adding to the difficulty, there isn’t much sleep for anyone doing the Dakar. A mobile camp is set up at each overnight stopping point. The luckiest competitors and drivers have motorhomes. Others, though, crawl into tents. Everybody puts up with the noise as mechanics tear down each vehicle and replace key parts, as well as tires, in order to be ready for the next stage. Throughout the night, engines are heard revving insanely.
Leading the way each morn, the motorcycles are off again at a ridiculously early hour, well before 5:00 a.m.
Despite all this, my brief exposure made it easy to see how the bug would bite—and not the bizarrely camouflaged grasshopper I almost squashed when climbing into my own tent.

That’s why my hat goes off to Sue Mead. In 2010, after about a decade spent reading the road book as a co-driver, Mead, who was then sixty years old, took the wheel and guided her Ford pickup to a class win within the automotive category, becoming the first American woman to triumph in the Dakar.

We can expect that, as this amazing rally becomes better known in the United States, more American women will follow the tire tracks of Mead, Laia Sanz, and other women who persevere and excel in the Dakar.

title: Minicars Bomb Latest Crash Test
subTitle: How worried should you be? What you need to know about new crash test scores.
promoTeaserSmall: How worried should you be? What you need to know about new crash test scores.
promoTeaser: How worried should you be? What you need to know about new crash test scores.
metaTitle: Minicars Bomb Latest Crash Test - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Minicars Bomb Latest Crash Test: How worried should you be about minicar safety? What you need to know about new crash test scores. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: You see them toddling down the street and think, “How cute!” Minicars like the Chevrolet Spark, the Fiat 500, and the Honda Fit are indeed adorable, plus fuel-efficient and affordable. But how safe are they out on the road next to semis and SUVs?

The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety has just released results of its most modern of crash tests, the “small overlap front” test. This test has only been in use since 2012. It’s intended to show what happens to a car when it hits another vehicle, or a solid object such as a telephone pole, not head on but in an offset crash. The testing crashes the car into a rigid barrier at 40 mph, with 25 percent of the car’s front end making contact.
Here are the results for all the minicars tested, and the detailed chart is below. Note: not one received the top Good rating overall. That's none.

Overall Acceptable

Chevrolet Spark

Overall Marginal

Mazda 2 (right), Kia Rio, Toyota Yaris, Ford Fiesta

Overall Poor

Mitsubishi Mirage, Nissan Versa sedan, Toyota Prius c (right), Hyundai Accent, Fiat 500, Honda Fit

The top-rated car, the Chevrolet Spark, was also named a 2014 Top Safety Pick. It was the only car in the group to earn that coveted moniker. IIHS commented that, in the Spark's crash, "the dummy's movement was fairly well controlled and its injury measures were low," suggesting that the structure in the lower part of the inside passenger compartment held up better than in the other minicars.

The bottom-rated cars were the Honda Fit (right) and the Fiat 500. The Fiat's driver's-side tore "tore open at the hinges," IIHS said, and both cars experienced "seriously compromised...driver space" after the crash. In both cars, the steering column was pushed back toward the driver, and the crash test dummy's head did not remain in contact with the driver's-side air bag after the impact.
As they have done historically, automakers will undoubtedly revise future models so they get better scores on the next round of tests.

The Good News Is...

There's a small silver lining in the test results: Every one of these cars got Good scores on at least some of the injury measures to the crash test dummy, which ameliorates the shock of the overall poor grades. The Spark was rated Good for all four: head and neck, chest and thigh, hip, and lower leg and foot. Even the lowest-ranked Honda Fit got Good scores for dummy upper body injury.

The frightening part is how badly they all did on the Structure rating. The Versa, Prius c, Accent, 500, and Fit all got the lowest score of Poor here, and the structure of every other car—including the Spark—was rated Marginal.

Reality Check

Keep this in mind: Minicars have not suddenly become less safe than they were before. The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration are continuing to raise the bar for what “safe” means. For that I say, Bravo! It’s the mission we are hoping they are on. IIHS even states that the reason it came out with the offset crash test was "to help drive further improvements in frontal crash protection." But despite that perspective, yes, minicars are still likely to be in more trouble in an accident. Almost every cars is safer today than ever before, but size does, in fact matter. The structure of these little cars is not holding up as well as we’d all like when faced with a difficult smashup. If you really want to dive into the testing and what it measures, check out this detailed explanation of all IIHS's frontal crash tests.

The good news for consumers is that the car companies take these test results very, very seriously. As they have done historically, automakers will undoubtedly revise future models so they get better scores on the next round of tests. (For example, IIHS says most vehicles were rated Poor or Marginal when it started running another crash test, the "moderate overlap frontal" crash. Today, the "vast majority" are rated Good.)

And that’s great for the people inside minicars—and the people inside bigger cars who don’t want to hurt them.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: I moved to Detroit last weekend to zero in on the North American International Auto Show’s dinners, parties, television opportunities, and then…two full days of cars and their designers. This year was totally overrun as never before by 5,169 journalists (from sixty countries, including Mongolia and Qatar) battling for a scrap of quote, a minute of an executive’s time, floor space, press kits, and all the cool USBs they could grab. The humanity (oh, the humanity!) was the stuff claustrophobia is made of. And I can’t say enough bad things about video crews from Russia.
But first, a hat.

On Sunday night before the show floor opened, Mercedes-Benz had a huge party at the historic Book Cadillac hotel (GM execs from out of town live upstairs) to unveil the new C-Class sedan and GLA45 AMG, the hotted-up version of its compact crossover. It was a mob scene. M-B takes over a floor of the hotel and has a suitably upscale cocktail and roving dinner party for an SRO crowd, which it entertained with the very funky Detroit Rollers. I throw the word "funk" out there specifically because the wildly stylish keyboard player was none other than Amp Fiddler, of Parliament-Funkadelic, one of my most favorite bands in the whole world.

I had worn my very best and coolest, my voodoo top hat from Barbara Feinman of New York City, and earlier in the evening I spied Mr. Fiddler and his fabulous chapeau at the very moment he spotted mine across the thousands of hatless revelers. We came like zombies toward each other and were trading milliner information before our own names. His hat came from Cha Cha’s House of Ill Repute. Cha Cha and I have already been in touch; stay tuned.

All right then.

Monday began with a technical meltdown that canceled my live appearance on the CBS Morning Show, so I joined the entire JKC staff at Cobo Center, deployed with the wildly ambitious intention of completing a dozen videographed designer walkarounds of the hottest new releases, all the while Tweeting and reporting the news and gossip before it fell to the floor.

I was in charge of the videos, with our resident artist Scott Allen behind the lens and senior editor Molly Jean (our spare Jean) keeping us on schedule. Molly also kept running shot lists for B-roll, took still photography, and even taped the English simultaneous translation of Lexus chief designer Yasuo Kajino's comments on the radical RC F concept as we sidled around the car, trying to stay out of the camera’s way. Freelance videographer Garrett Sammons and design student Joe Boniface followed in our wake, capturing B-roll details.

Executive editor Laura Sky Brown was the live reporter, accompanied by freelance photographer Susan Campbell, and Anna Eby, our friend from last year’s G-7 consumer panel, who couldn’t stay away and took her own notes. She’s a lawyer from Texas, so you know she’s opinionated. Her stories and photos are here and here.

Over the course of Monday and Tuesday, we managed to film more than a dozen videos of the hottest cars at the show, as explained by the most talented and fun designers in the world. They are being edited; the first one, on the Kia Stinger Concept, is up now, and the others will roll out over the course of the next couple of months.
So of course I drove nothing. And I’ve driven nothing since I left on Tuesday.
You know how you're supposed to stop skiing about an hour before the ski lift closes, because that's when all the accidents happen? Right.

You know how you're supposed to stop skiing about an hour before the ski lift closes, because that's when all the accidents happen? Right. At 5:00 p.m., the last day of our press day coverage, I trotted up the Mayan temple that was the tall, shiny white altar to the Nissan Sport Sedan Concept parked at the top, made it up the steps in my clogs...and took a face plant in front of about 100 journalists in the tiers facing the stage.
I flipped on my back like a turtle and saw them all frozen in silence and said, "Please go back to what you were doing. Everything is fine."

An exceptional Nissan PR representative rushed to my side and said: "We have no ice, Jean, but I brought you this cold beer bottle.  You could put that on your ankle." I looked at him and said, "Go find a cold water bottle, and open that beer."

I limped off, pretty sure it was just a bad sprain, but the next day it hurt so bad that I actually went to the doctor. I got an X-ray and, yes, it was broken. In less than a week I was flying to London with Bentley, bringing along videographer Scott Allen. Bentley had arranged for me to meet my millinery god, Philip Treacy, and go through the Isabella Blow exhibit in London. I would then carry on to the Maison & Objet furniture show in Paris, where Bentley designers were showing the Bentley Furniture collection. There was no way I was missing that!

So as you read this, I am stumping around London, meeting Philip Treacy, and then on my way to Paris to bring back a couple of really great videos. There is so much exciting news about Jean Knows Cars that I can't even begin to tell you, but I can't wait for you to see what we will have coming up.
2014 is going to be a year to remember here. Tell your friends to jump on board! This is going to be not just a great year for us, but a wonderful year for you.

title: 2015 Lincoln Navigator
promoTeaserSmall: A modest update, including an EcoBoost V-6, doesn't change the old look and feel of the luxury SUV.
promoTeaser: A modest update, including an EcoBoost V-6, doesn't change the old look and feel of the luxury SUV.
metaDescription: 2015 Lincoln Navigator: A modest update to the luxury SUV. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: The Lincoln Navigator goes EcoBoost: Is that a mixed message? It’s the luxury SUV that has been immortalized in songs by the likes of rap star Young Jeezy and R&B A-lister R Kelly. Has it come home from the party now that it has adopted a 3.5-liter EcoBoost V-6 instead of its old V-8? More to the point, has the recently rebranded Lincoln Motor Company done anything to offend the loyal fans of the luxury barge?

It doesn't look like it. It's a good thing that the 5.4-liter V-8 engine is gone; after all, it has been there since the Navigator was introduced in 1997. The twin-turbocharged EcoBoost V-6 offers an estimated 370 horsepower, up from the 310 that the big SUV had before, plus 430 pound-feet of torque, up from 365. Lincoln says it expects the new Navigator to have best-in-class towing capability when the final numbers are out. So, if you're looking at the utility aspect of the Lincoln Navigator, not to worry.

The 2015 Lincoln Navigator will be officially unveiled at the Chicago Auto Show on February 6 and will go on sale in the fall. Comparisons to the just-redone 2015 Cadillac Escalade, which has been much more effectively modernized and restyled, will be immediate. Holding the line on changes has helped Lincoln keep the cost steady: the big Caddy comes out in the spring, priced just over $71,000, whereas the Navigator is expected to be priced in the mid to upper $50,000s.

Aside from the engine news, the Lincoln has been given a cosmetic update, but not one that changes the basic character of the big luxury vehicle. First and foremost, for the Navigator fans out there, let’s talk about the optional Reserve package with its Ziricote wood trim—you know, the stuff you’d find on a yacht—and twenty-two inch polished aluminum wheels, plus, if you so desire, a set of chromed running boards.

Oh, and the leather. Acres of buttery premium Trevino leather. Color and materials design manager Barb Whalen describes the leather as “incredibly soft, but it has a rugged quality.” It’s absolutely everywhere, especially if you choose the Reserve option package: on all three rows of seats, on the center console, armrests, and shift knob, as well as covering the instrument panel and even the door to the glove box.
Another new touch on the 2015 model: illuminated “welcome mats” under both front doors that greet you when you unlock the Navigator.

On the outside, the Lincoln split-wing grille and revised hood profile make the Navigator match the rest of the Lincoln lineup, but anybody expecting a big difference in its appearance will be disappointed. A power tailgate and a full set of LED lights round out the exterior changes. You can get the 2015 Navigator, as before, in the already generous 207.4-inch wheelbase or the extended-wheelbase version, at 222.3 inches. The overall size and shape of the SUV have not changed.
The chief engineer, Elaine Bannon, says that's how Navigator buyers like it. “We knew what our customers wanted,” she said. “I’m proud that we were able to give our customers so much more.”

Is the 2015 Lincoln Navigator something you will personally own? Probably not, and it’s far from the ecological champion of the year. But a vehicle like this exists for the reason sequined gowns exist: because there is a time and a place for impractical, luxurious, over-the-top things. In the case of the Navigator, it’s not even impractical. After all, it can tow, it can carry, and it has all the passenger space you would need for whatever you’ve got in mind.
You, and seven of your closest sybarite friends.  In the immortal words of Young Jeezy (hey, I’ve got teenagers who own iPods):
“Let ‘em talk, let ‘em hate, watch that Lincoln Navigate”

contributors.bio: I was born a suburban Detroit gal where the preoccupation with cars is practically genetic.  As a young adult I kicked around motor-racing, training to drive while I worked at a Brands Hatch satellite in Miami.  I've been race staff at the Detroit Grand Prix, worked TV coverage of Formula 1, Indy and NASCAR and done the occasional ride and drive program.  Eventually my racing aspirations gave way to a long held interest in filmmaking and I got my B.A. from the University of Michigan's burgeoning film program.  U of M taught me to write and introduced me to my excellent husband.  We spent five adventurous years in Los Angeles in the entertainment and publishing industries before returning to Ann Arbor where our lovely daughter came into the world.  Personally, I expend a good deal of energy on K-12 public education advocacy.  Professionally, I've been a freelance writer for the last ten years specializing in health issues and automotive content from a lifestyle perspective.  There's a lot more to auto life than zero to sixty.

pageElements.text: It seems counterintuitive to shop for a $35,000 car on the basis of how it accommodates one's $50 handbag, but the fact is, a woman’s purse is her essential traveling companion.  Thanks to the automotive trend of cockpit styling, our purses are relegated to the passenger’s seat, the passenger’s lap, or, most often, the floor. Women would rather not have that coveted Coach bag, or even our thrift store find, sitting in winter sludge or kicked by our teenager’s combat boots.

And so my sister, Sandy, and I undertook a noble quest.  Armed with my compact utility bag and her fancier overstuffed purse (clues to who was the tomboy and who was the girly girl as kids), we set out to scour Detroit’s North American International Auto Show in search of the vehicles able to fit a woman and her nylon or leather sidekick comfortably.

Unfortunately, we found the pickings very slim. The perfect car must have dedicated space for the average purse to fit easily. That space has to be adjacent to the driver’s seat, yet not in the way of vehicle operation.
We didn't do a scientific test or get out the measuring tape, and we saw only a selection of cars. Your nominations for really good (or bad) candidates are welcome!

Luxury brands were most disappointing. From Audi to Volvo, they all claim to anticipate your every need but have little purse allowance in their wood-veneered center columns. Frustrated, we set our bags on cup holders or emergency brakes and watched hinged compartments gobble or trap them (I'm talking to you, Mazda CX-9).
We marveled at how even the Range Rover Sport, with separate armrests and a center divide as vast as the Grand Canyon, couldn’t spare a square inch for our wayward bags.

Still we persevered and, making our way around the show floor, we found a few rare vehicles worthy of honors in our highly subjective Golden Clutch Awards. It's important to point out that we didn't do a scientific test or get out the measuring tape, and we saw only a selection of cars and trucks. Your suggestions for really good (or really bad) Golden Clutch candidates would be very welcome!

And the Winner Is: Tesla Model S

You’ve probably heard about this revolutionary plug-in electric five-seat sedan that excels in visual design and mechanical innovation. But did you know it has the most exquisite spot for your purse? A panoramic sunroof sheds loads of light on a slightly futuristic interior. A generous ridged wood-grain storage tray splits the floor between driver’s and passenger’s sides, ideal for any size of bag. Why so roomy? Because a seventeen-inch touchscreen manages all the car’s controls, eliminating the need for a busy center stack. On top of this glorious bag space, Tesla says you can add a Premium Center Console as a “place to rest your phone,” but I already have a place to rest my phone: inside my purse. Now if only I had about $80,000 in that purse to pay for the Tesla.

And the Winner in the Back-to-Reality Category Is: Toyota Highlander

The Highlander SUV has a brilliantly conceived armrest with two garage-style doors that retract fully to reveal a deep compartment wide enough for a sizable purse. It can close completely or stay open for easy access without sacrificing a spot to rest your arm. Starting around $30,000, the Toyota's appealing standard options include voice controls and a rearview camera. Model choices allow for seven or eight passengers, and a Hybrid is available, meaning there is probably a Highlander to suit everyone and their daily baggage.

Close Seconds: Honda Odyssey and Toyota Sienna

Preconceived minivan notions aside, it is cool to slide into a captain’s chair and effortlessly drop your purse into the lovely large cavern between the center stack and the cup holders. Honda’s Odyssey, an unapologetic utilitarian with great visibility, comfort, and decent gas mileage, is ready to handle the road as well as the softball team. A superior hostess, the Odyssey not only keeps your purse handy, but some models even have an in-car cooler and vacuum. Such versatility will put you in the $35,000 range and higher.

The similarly priced Toyota Sienna was wonderfully accommodating of our bags, especially the molded plastic floor tray that safeguards one’s purse from the indignity of sitting directly on the carpet. The Sienna’s interior is a bit more stylized than the Odyssey's, with an asymmetrical dash swooping toward the driver. Add in terrific seat management, including an effortlessly folding third row, and you’ve got a vehicle that will get you and your personal tool kit through anything.

Runners Up, Way Up: GMC Sierra and Cadillac Escalade

We literally climbed up into these two GM behemoths and noticed they boast similar square armrests that house roomy compartments beneath padded hinged tops. The Sierra pickup, starting around $27,000, has a serviceable interior and will haul more than your jean hobo bag with a range of cab and bed configurations. At upward of $70,000, the Escalade (right) is expensive, thirsty, and massive but can transport your Fendi tote, a group of friends, and their golf clubs in ridiculous style.

Honorable Mention: Scion IQ and BMW Z4 sDrive 35is

The tiny two-door Scion IQ (right) was one of the least expensive cars we saw at the auto show, starting around $17,000. Surprisingly, our bags tucked nicely in a space behind the emergency brake.

On the opposite end of the spectrum, the racy BMW Z4 sDrive 35is convertible, which starts above $65,000, seemed built for speed as well as our purses. Not a practical choice for most of us, but with 335 horsepower, you can set your bag on the shelf behind the two Kansas leather seats and let your cares fly out the open top.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

contributors.bio: I am a person who loves to study other people. I like to interview them, learn about their lives, photograph them, and write their stories. The people at Jean Knows Cars noticed me through my project, Humans of Ann Arbor. In that project, I tool around the city of Ann Arbor, introducing myself to anyone who draws my eye. If they are open to it, I take a photo of them and hear a little bit about them. Then I post the photos and stories on Facebook. Humans of Ann Arbor has followers from all over the world who check in on a daily basis to see ordinary people and their extraordinary stories. I have been studying people since I was a little girl in Missouri. Where I grew up, studying people often led you to the cars they loved. My grandpa had a gas station in Claycomo, Missouri, which he opened in the 1950s, and he passed his love of cars and taking care of the people who drove them down to my dad. Dad was a mechanic and a service supervisor all his life. We had a steady barrage of cars coming into our lives…mostly Chevys. To impress my dad, I learned to identify every car I could, and I used to name the cars while we drove down the road. Car culture is big in Missouri. Would you believe that I had friends who were sisters named Nova and Chevelle? If you didn’t grow up the way I did, you might not get the significance of that, but suffice it to say that my people love their cars. The car I adored most was the Chevrolet Corvair my dad gave me when I was in high school. It spent more time in my dad's shop than it did on the road, but in those moments when it was drivable, I knew what it was to love a car. It was a thing of beauty: pale cream with a plaid madras interior. I loved the sound and feel of the engine…it was more like a soft purr than a roar. I can still remember how it smelled and what it was like to drive it with the windows rolled down on a warm day. I've had lots of cars since then, and I loved some of them, too. But the Corvair was my first car love and will always be my favorite. After high school, I drove my car to Springfield, Missouri, to study communications at Missouri State. Later, I drove a different car to Chicago to study photography at Columbia College. I worked in Chicago as a freelance photographer and studio manager for many years before moving to Ann Arbor, where I continue to do freelance photography. I am excited about combining my love of studying people with my interest in cars. I want to explore how cars serve us, how they are intertwined in our lives, and what makes us love them. I can't wait to let you know what I find out.

pageElements.text: I was so happy when Jean Knows Cars asked me to go to the North American International Auto Show and take a look around. Most people go to see the vast array of amazing cars, but as the street photographer and photo blogger who does Humans of Ann Arbor, I went to see the people. For one day I introduced myself to every stranger who caught my eye and asked if I could take their picture and tell their story. Here they are: Humans of the Detroit Auto Show.

Pregnant Woman at Trunk of Cadillac

When I saw her, she was opening the trunk, and closing the trunk, then opening it again, over and over.
Me:  I noticed you are really checking out that trunk.  What’s up with that?  Is a good trunk important to you?

Her: (laughing) Yeah, I work in engineering, and I work on parts like these.

Me: Oh, cool, so you can tell me what to look for in a trunk?
Her:  Well, space for sure, the quality of the opening and closing, and the weight.
Me:  It looks like you are going to be putting lots of stuff in your trunk soon…
Her:  Yes, like strollers and diaper bags.  I’m having my first baby.

Ladies with Wigs and Puppets

They come from a true Detroit family, with family members who are ironworkers, or work for GM and Ford. When I saw them, they were in a 1963 Chevy Greenbrier van that had been turned into a photo booth.

“We’re cousins, and we were the first girls in our family, so it was a big deal.  There are lots of pictures of the two of us together while we were growing up, some where we were trying to pull things away from each other.  Since there are so many pictures of us together, we thought it would be fun to do this.”

Cleaner

“I’ve been working for Mini and Ford. The Minis are a lot easier to keep clean.”

Three Teenagers

Me: Isn’t this a school day?

Them: Yes…But we are on a field trip with our Graphics class!

Car Model with Charger

“The models are all chosen specifically for the car they represent," a company rep said. "We chose her because we wanted someone who looked like they were from the Seventies. She may do five to ten shows this year. I would call her a model because she did receive training on the car and can answer quite a few questions about it, but she hasn’t gotten in depth training at this point. Some of the other people are product specialists. They have received more training. Some specialists are educated and become very knowledgeable, and they may then become narrators and give presentations about the vehicles they represent.”

Two Women, Two Kids

I kept trying to get him to smile.
Me:  On the count of three, say Elmo!  One…two…three…
(silence)
Me:  You don’t like Elmo?  What do you like?
Mom:  He just likes cars.

Woman with Glasses

Her: I work in Engineering at GM.
Me:  What’s it like being a woman in the automotive industry?
Her:  I honestly don’t even think about it.  It’s just not an issue.  Everyone in our department is treated with the same respect.  And we have a female CEO now.
Me:  What advice do you have for young women who might be interested in automotive engineering?
Her:  Study your math and science.  Get a good education, and if you are interested, just go for it!

Couple

Him: We are looking for a car that can pull a trailer for when I retire next year. And we need to pull our two motorcycles.
Me: Cool!  Do you guys ride together a lot?
Her: Oh, yes.
Him:  But I have to ride in front, because she’s a speed demon!
Her:  Well, I drove a school bus for thirty years, so…
Me:  You’re a professional?
Her:  Yes!

Molly Jean of Jean Knows Cars

Molly Jean kept checking to see if an attendant would open this booth up and let people try on these crazy costumes. No one ever came, and she couldn’t hide her disappointment.

UAW Blue Shirt

“Just about everyone in my family is in the UAW. My mother, my sister-in-law, my brother-in-law. But this is the first time I’ve been to the Detroit Auto Show.”

Lady in Red Coat at Red SUV

She’s a lifelong resident of Detroit.
“I love the Big D!”

contributors.bio: I was born a suburban Detroit gal where the preoccupation with cars is practically genetic.  As a young adult I kicked around motor-racing, training to drive while I worked at a Brands Hatch satellite in Miami.  I've been race staff at the Detroit Grand Prix, worked TV coverage of Formula 1, Indy and NASCAR and done the occasional ride and drive program.  Eventually my racing aspirations gave way to a long held interest in filmmaking and I got my B.A. from the University of Michigan's burgeoning film program.  U of M taught me to write and introduced me to my excellent husband.  We spent five adventurous years in Los Angeles in the entertainment and publishing industries before returning to Ann Arbor where our lovely daughter came into the world.  Personally, I expend a good deal of energy on K-12 public education advocacy.  Professionally, I've been a freelance writer for the last ten years specializing in health issues and automotive content from a lifestyle perspective.  There's a lot more to auto life than zero to sixty.

pageElements.text: Each time we buckle in our babies, toddlers, and kids, we parents are putting a world of faith in our children’s car seats. Now the U.S. Department of Transportation's National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, or NHTSA, has proposed expanding car seat testing to include side impacts. That's an important measure since, in children twelve and under, side impacts are responsible for nearly as many fatalities and serious injuries as frontal crashes, according to NHTSA.
in children twelve and under, side impacts are responsible for nearly as many fatalities and serious injuries as frontal crashes, according to NHTSA.

Right now, car seats are submitted to a 30-mph frontal crash simulation. The new test would be, as NHTSA describes it, a simulation of "a full-scale vehicle-to-vehicle side impact" in which a vehicle traveling at 30 mph T-bones the side of a smaller car going 15 mph. Unlike a front or rear impact, in which sometimes several feet of car material lay between occupants and the car or tree it's crashing into, the only barrier in a side impact is the car door or side panel, which can crush dangerously inward. NHTSA is adding a new three-year-old crash test dummy; the agency already has a twelve-month old dummy in its arsenal.

If the new rule is adopted, manufacturers will have three years to modify their products where necessary to meet the improved safety standards. You can weigh in during a ninety-day public comment period available soon via the government’s eRulemaking Portal. Just go to regulations.gov and enter reference number NHTSA-2014-0012 in the big blue search box.

Remember, having the best car seat money can buy is no asset if you aren’t using right.  According to the NHTSA, about 75 percent of children are either not in car seats at all or are riding in seats that are not installed properly. Yes, it can be tough to get older kids to stay in that booster or to get that clip-in base in the right position. Our car didn’t have the LATCH system, which was instituted in 2002, and it seemed only my husband was strong enough to effectively tighten the seatbelt to the car seat.  Since I knew he couldn’t be there every time I needed to move the seat I had to work out my own leverage system to get our daughter’s car seat installed properly.

So, read your car seat manual carefully and instruct any other caregivers installing the seat how to do it correctly. For added reassurance use the NHTSA Child Car Seat Inspection Station Locator, and have your installation skills double-checked. After all, regulations only get us halfway to safety. We parents have to make sure our kids make it the rest of the way.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
I found the Cadillac ATS to be the most refined and beautiful execution of the Cadillac design language, which, up to this point, has been sharp edged and wedge shaped to a fault. There is no question about what you’re looking at when you see a current Cadillac go by, so in that case, the mission has been accomplished. In this ATS Coupe, the wedge is knocked down and smoothed out. It’s very much reminiscent of the sensuous Elmiraj concept that was shown first at the 2013 Pebble Beach Concours d’Elegance and was at this year’s Detroit Auto Show in all its glory.

My immediate response to it was absolutely visceral. I wanted to touch it, I wanted to walk around it, and as chief exterior designer Bob Boniface talked about it, I kept putting my hand on it. If you listen to him on this video, you’ll hear a very lyrical explanation of just why I responded the way I did.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: The cleverly named ConceptCar project is a joint initiative of the Helsinki Metropolia University of Applied Sciences and the bio and forest industry company UPM. The concept car will be shown at the Geneva International Motor Show in March.

What makes this concept car unique from all others is hidden in the materials. Not only will this vehicle be powered by a renewable diesel fuel made from bark, stumps, and branches, the car itself will be made of various bio-based materials. The frame, for instance, uses tree pulp and plywood. The idea behind the project is to show how to use sustainable materials instead of fossil fuels and plastics.

Best of all, this concept car is street legal and is expected to meet European crash standards. In fact, according to the website Good News Finland, the concept went out for road testing last summer, during a rain storm, "to eliminate concerns that a wood car cannot handle exposure to water."

I like the idea of being able to take a concept car out on the road. At a time when our oceans are becoming increasingly polluted and our landfills are overflowing, it is exciting to see an emphasis on green design that is a step forward technologically but keeps one eye on Mother Earth.

title: 10 Cheapest Cars with Active Safety
promoTeaserSmall: What's the price of entry for the newest active safety features? Automobile Magazine  tells us.
promoTeaser: What's the price of entry for the newest active safety features? Automobile Magazine  tells us.
metaTitle: 10 Cheapest Cars with Active Safety - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 10 Cheapest Cars with Active Safety: What's the price of entry for the newest active safety features like lane departure warning, blind spot detection, and forward collision warning? Read the story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
This story comes to us from our brother publication, Automobile Magazine.

The trickle-down theory may be best known for its economic application, but it’s an idea that’s relevant to the automotive sphere as well, especially in regard to safety. Features like antilock brakes, airbags, and stability control first came about in high-end luxury sedans and gradually propagated to more mainstream vehicles before eventually becoming required standard equipment in all cars sold in the United States.

These days, active safety technologies are making their way into more affordable, mainstream cars and are even factored into the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety’s vehicle safety ratings.

We compiled a list of the least expensive new vehicles that are equipped with a basic suite of active safety technologies. Each qualifying car had to be equipped with the following: a blind spot monitor (BSM), a lane departure warning system (LDW), forward collision warning (FCW), and a backup camera. Just as a refresher, we’ll explain what each of these systems do.

- Blind spot monitor (BSM): uses lenses or other sensors to detect if another vehicle has entered in either the left or right blind spot areas. It then displays a visual and/or audio warning to alert the driver of the other vehicle’s presence.

- Forward collision warning (FCW): uses radar, laser, and/or camera sensors to detect an impending collision. From there, systems vary on what action is taken. Some notify the driver with flashing lights and an audio warning, whereas some also ready the seatbelt pretensioners in the case of a crash. Higher-end FCW systems can also engage the brakes to help lessen the impact speed or avoid the collision altogether.

- Lane departure warning (LDW): Cameras are able to detect lane markings and alert the driver if the car is drifting outside the lane without the driver signaling. More complex versions of LDW can also intervene and use the steering to correct the car’s course and keep it in its lane.
- Backup camera: Mounted on the rear of the vehicle, this camera provides an image of the area behind the car on a central display screen on the dashboard.

Pricing for this list was determined by adding up all options and/or trim levels needed to get the aforementioned features. As it turns out, the average price of entry for these features is right around $30,000, undercutting the average new car transaction price, which is now above $31,000. We were also surprised to see that seven out of our ten vehicles come from American automakers.

1. 2014 Buick Verano Convenience Group: $25,795

The 2014 Buick Verano is the least expensive car on our list by a margin of more than $3000. A backup camera is the only one of these features to come standard on the Verano, but buyers of this compact premium sedan only need to step up one trim level from the base model to get the full suite of active safety technologies included on the Convenience Group trim.

2. 2014 Chevrolet Malibu 2LT: $29,105

Another General Motors vehicle comes in as the second cheapest, the 2014 Chevrolet Malibu. A backup camera is standard on the mid-grade 2LT trim, and the three other active safety features come with a reasonably priced $890 Advanced Safety package. This package also requires opting for the $1,000 Leather package and the $1,175 Electronics and Entertainment package, but all in this nicely-equipped Malibu still comes in at a reasonable $29,105.

3. 2014 Mazda 3 s Grand Touring: $29,390

The 2014 Mazda 3 sedan and hatchback have an impressive set of technology features, but FCW and LDW systems only come on the top-trim Grand Touring model in a special $2600 GT Tech package. That makes for an expensive little compact. You do get a lot for the money, though, as we are impressed with the Mazda 3’s upscale interior and best-in-class driving dynamics. If you can’t quite afford this loaded-up 3, the backup camera and BSM system do come as standard on lower-priced trim levels like the i Touring and Grand Touring.

4. 2014 Buick Encore Premium Group: $29,890

Buick’s compact SUV has trim levels that are structured slightly differently than on the Verano sedan. To get FCW and LDW systems, you have to step up to the Encore’s top trim level, called Premium Group. This loads the Encore up with lots of other luxury and convenience features, but it still comes in under $30,000 with front-wheel-drive.

5. 2015 Chrysler 200C: $30,475

Chrysler just introduced the new 200 at the 2014 Detroit auto show, and this mid-size sedan is thoroughly modernized with a more stylish look. The new Chrysler 200 also ups its technology game, with a $1,295 SafetyTec package optional on the 200C that adds not only the required safety systems for this list, but also adaptive cruise control and a parking assist feature. This safety package does require the addition of $795 Premium Lighting Group and the $1395 Navigation and Sound Group, but a Chrysler 200C with these options only just tops $30,000. The Chrysler 200 will go on sale this spring.

6. 2014 Jeep Cherokee Limited: $30,645

Next up is another Chrysler product, the 2014 Jeep Cherokee crossover. To get the option of selecting the $2155 Technology Group package, Cherokee buyers have to step up to the Limited trim level. This package adds the required active safety features, along with adaptive cruise control and parking assist, just like in the Chrysler 200. The Limited comes standard with front-wheel drive and a 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine; adding four-wheel drive adds $2,000, and opting for the 3.2-liter Pentastar V-6 costs $1,495.

7. 2014 Nissan Rogue SL: $30,920

Nissan first got into the idea of affordable active safety features with the Altima sedan that sourced its optional LDW, BSM, and moving object detection all from the same rearview camera. The Altima lacks FCW, which keeps it off this list, but the recently redesigned 2014 Nissan Rogue does have FCW and earns a spot here. A backup camera is standard on all 2014 Rogues, and a $1,990 Premium package available only on the top-trim Rogue SL adds FCW, BSM, and LDW.

8. 2014 Ford Fusion SE 2.0 EcoBoost: $31,700

The 2014 Ford Fusion is available with a whole host of luxury features that drive its price up into the high-$30,000 range, but Ford offers its full set of active safety features in the midrange Fusion SE when equipped with the 2.0-liter EcoBoost four-cylinder engine. Fusion buyers must opt for the $1,200 Driver Assist package to get BSM and LDW, and FCW comes along with the $995 adaptive cruise control. This also requires adding the $2,350 Equipment Group 202A which adds leather, fog lights, and a power passenger’s seat.

9. 2014 Chevrolet Impala 1LT: $31,750

The 2014 Chevrolet Impala is one step up from the Malibu in size and price and offers a similar $890 Advanced Safety package that adds FCW, LDW, and BSM on top of the standard rearview camera on the Impala’s 1LT trim. Adding this package also requires the $940 Convenience package. At this price, the Impala is powered by a 195-hp 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine; to get the optional 305-hp 3.6-liter V-6, buyers have to step up one trim level to the 2LT model.

10. 2014 Mazda 6 Grand Touring: $32,570

Like its Mazda 3 little brother, the 2014 Mazda 6 packages most of its active safety features into the $2,080 GT Technology package available on the highest Grand Touring trim. This adds FCW and LDW to the backup camera and BLIS that come standard on the lower-trim Mazda 6 Touring. Other features like adaptive cruise control and Mazda’s i-ELOOP fuel-saving technology are also included in this package.

Honorable Mention: 2014 Honda Accord Sedan EX-L: $29,060

The 2014 Honda Accord doesn't quite make it onto our list because it does not have a full blind spot monitoring system. We wanted to give it some credit thanks to an interesting substitution, the Honda LaneWatch system. LaneWatch is a camera mounted below the passenger side mirror that projects a video feed to the central display screen showing an expanded view of the car’s right side. While it doesn’t display a visual alert like other blind spot monitors, LaneWatch provides an extended field of vision that helps diminish the car’s blind spot on the right side of the vehicle. All Accords offer a backup camera as standard, LaneWatch comes as standard on all Accords EX and up, and LDW and FCW systems come on the EX-L trim level and up.

contributors.bio:
Sheer serendipity.  That’s how I became a contributor to Jean Knows Cars.  Well into a lovely dinner party, I received a most unlikely suggestion:  “You should write about cars from your perspective – a 4’11” single mother with a ten-year-old minivan who drives around three overactive children and a Bernese Mountain Dog.  Theatre, swimming, hockey, lacrosse, figure skating, field hockey… You love to tell stories. Tell them about cars.”  I suggested that my background possibly lacked necessary expertise – B.A. from Duke in art history and medieval/Renaissance studies; Fellow of the American Academy in Rome; Ph.D. from the University of Michigan in medieval architecture --  nothing about cars there!  My friend persisted, “You may be an art historian, but you are also a hockey mother who can whistle like a trucker, a runner, and a lover of good food, wine and the written word.”

I pondered.  The auto industry and I did have a long, if tangential, history.  I did a stint as an executive secretary to the president of a car dealership and spent fifteen years negotiating a dual identity as an academic and as auto company spouse.  I have always suffered from car envy, particularly acutely when I lived in Europe.  (As envy and lust are amongst the seven deadly sins, I’m in trouble.) Automobiles, functional objects that often shape image, are fundamental elements of today’s society.  This would be another mode of cultural analysis and critique.  Couched in that light, it made perfect sense!

(And, I really can whistle like a trucker, but louder. I may be an art historian, but don’t sit next to me at a hockey rink.)

pageElements.text: Auto insurance generally does not fall into the category of “things about which people worry.” One picks a policy, and then it fades into the background, simply a monthly deduction that appears on your bank statement.  You might read the often copious correspondence you get from your insurer, or, if you’re like me and you let mail stack up, you might not.  Sound familiar?

Complacency is not your friend. Twice in the last three years, I’ve had insurance shockers. The first was right before my divorce was final. In a rare moment, I happened to be going through the mail in a timely manner, only to open a letter sent from our insurance company stating that my soon-to-be ex- husband had canceled our policy. I was no longer insured. Nice. Apparently it did not occur to him to tell me. After uttering a few choice phrases, I did what most of us do: I got on the computer and the phone, compared rates with companies, and went with the lowest offer.
I remember a moment of panic when I thought I had handed the officer the suddenly defunct insurance information. Would he believe my story of my insurance being canceled?

The very next day, I happened to be pulled over, my first time in twenty-five years. I remember a moment of panic when I thought I had handed the officer the suddenly defunct insurance information. Would he believe my story of my insurance being canceled?  Then, as he smiled, apologized for pulling me over, and, with a “put your broken headlight on the top of your list, please,” sent me on my way, I was thanking my lucky stars for having read my mail.

Having sorted out my insurance, I was set forever, right? This past July, when I went to sign my lease for my Fiat 500, I simply called my insurance company, added the Cinquecento, received my proof of insurance via e-mail, and all was in order. Or so I thought.

Four weeks ago, I noticed that my monthly premium appearing on my bank statement did not seem as high as it should be. I went to my stack of piled-up mail, opened my insurance statement, and discovered the Fiat was not on it. I looked at my proof-of-insurance card: expiration August 31, 2013.

I called the insurance company. For reasons neither they nor I understood, they had only insured the car for a month, and they had not even processed the Fiat. For four months, I had been driving my Fiat uninsured, and that included a trip in the snow to Cleveland for a hockey tournament! I mentioned this to a fellow hockey parent, who happens to be a police detective, and his eyes widened and he said, “Oh Catherine, that is bad. Very bad.”
Bad indeed. The phrase “put you under the jail” comes to mind.
In that moment, I learned the value of having a relationship with an agent who personally attends to your matters, rather than a company with an anonymous representative.

In that moment, I learned the value of having a relationship with an insurance agent who personally attends to your matters, rather than an insurance company with an anonymous representative on the phone. I needed an agent.

As it happens, Nathan Lamb, my bank manager at Chase who saw me through the financial machinations of my divorce, had recently left the bank and moved to Farm Bureau Insurance. He missed working directly with clients and relishes helping them shape their financial security. I called Nathan immediately, and as we talked, I realized that auto insurance is part of a much larger picture.  I didn’t have a clear understanding of what it entails, the options available, and the choices we should make.

So on a very snowy January 2 (one reporting lots of auto accidents), Nathan and I sat down over a long coffee. My insurance needs are now addressed. In the next few weeks, I'll be sharing some of the tips he shared with me. Meanwhile, go have a quick look: Is your insurance in order?

pageElements.text: At a recent Bridgestone Racing Academy event, Bridgestone employee Doug Niman went over some basics about the fluids in your car. It’s a good reminder to check your owner’s manual and make sure you are keeping your fluids fresh and changed at the recommended intervals.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/Rb8TW8wrXZo" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

1. Oil

Engine oil is perhaps the most important ingredient in a healthy car: it keeps the engine and all its parts cool, lubricated, and working properly. That’s why it’s essential to stay on top of oil changes. Check your owner’s manual for recommended intervals and oil types for your car. And, while you’re at it, have the oil filter changed whenever you change your oil. Older cars may need their oil levels checked frequently; aim for every time you fill the tank.

As Doug points out, there are newer synthetic and synthetic blend oils in addition to conventional oil types. Synthetic oil is more expensive; a quick search of traditional versus fully synthetic oil shows prices in the $3.99 range for a quart of traditional and $8.99 and up for the synthetic. But synthetics tend to be popular among owners of high-performance cars and people who want to maximize gas mileage.
Feel adventurous and want to do your own oil change? Check out this video.

2. Transmission Fluid

Transmission fluid is a miracle of technology, full of additives that simultaneously protect your transmission against friction, oxidation, and changes in temperature. However, it shouldn't be something you need to top up or add to; if the level gets low, it means there's probably a leak. You can use the dipstick that's provided in the compartment to check your automatic transmission's fluid, but checking the transmission fluid on a manual-transmission vehicle means putting it up on a hoist to look under the car. Suffice it to say, don't let your servicer omit the transmission fluid check at the maintenance interval in your owner's manual.

3. Coolant

Coolant, a.k.a. antifreeze, is the liquid that keeps your car's operating temperature stable. It's designed to have a low freeze point and a high boil point. It's also got additives to keep the cooling system from rusting or corroding. Check your owner's manual for what kind your car is intended to use and the interval at which it's recommended to flush your car's coolant system.

4. Brake Fluid

The important thing to know about brake fluid is that it easily absorbs moisture and can start to break down over time. You can use a test strip, available at auto parts superstores, to check the cleanliness of your car's brake fluid. But stick to the recommended service interval in your owner's manual and have the fluid flushed when the manual suggests.
