contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Moving from Ann Arbor, Michigan, to New York City may seem daunting, but it’s just like any other move. Take everything you own, put it in a car, and drive away. When I made my move three days after Christmas that’s exactly what I did, except that I took considerably less than half of my stuff, because the rumors about tiny New York apartments aren’t just rumors.

The journey started at 9:00 a.m. on the last Saturday of 2013. My dad had kindly volunteered to drive me cross-country in his 2009 Volkswagen CC. Conceived as a four-door coupe version of the Volkswagen Passat, the CC has a low, sloping roofline and doesn’t feel spacious inside. But it’s actually a few inches longer and wider than the Passat, and it’s by far the largest vehicle driven by a member of the White family, so it was our best option.

By folding the rear seats down, we were able to fit my skis, three suitcases, two boxes of books, and a few bags of other belongings behind the front row. My winter boots and several just-washed dresses, nearly forgotten, were thrown on top at the last minute. My father, like so many fathers before him, groaned with each new bag that materialized in the front hall. But when everything was packed in, we still had a small tunnel clear to look out the rear window, and I call that a success.

Traffic was flowing freely on I-80 and the weather was glorious for late December, hovering right around 50 degrees all day. We stopped for lunch at Plyler’s Buffet in Brookville, Pennsylvania. Years ago, my parents identified Plyler’s as the halfway point on trips to my grandmother’s house in upstate New York, and we keep going back because they have scrumptious pies. I hadn’t been there in nearly a decade, but the graham cracker pie was just as good as I remembered it.

After lunch, it was my turn to drive. I’d driven the CC dozens of times before, so I wasn’t surprised by its eager acceleration and smooth ride, but I still enjoyed it. This particular CC uses Volkswagen’s trusty 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine making 200 horsepower. Sure, the 3.6-liter V-6 would have given this large car a little more pep, but it’s by no means necessary, and the smaller engine means smaller gas bills. We filled up in Brookville and didn’t stop again until we made it to Brooklyn.
Our car was surrounded by big SUVs and heavily modded Civic Si's. Each time a lane narrowed, drivers would jockey for position in a potentially dangerous game of chicken.

We’d left Michigan early and, despite a long lunch, should have landed at my new digs by 8:00 p.m. Sadly, that was not to be. Saturday night traffic into the city via the Holland Tunnel slowed us to a crawl for nearly two hours and gave me my first unpleasant taste of New York City's driving culture. Our car was surrounded by big SUVs and heavily modded Civic Si's from New Jersey, and each time a lane narrowed, drivers would jockey for position, playing a potentially dangerous game of chicken. I happily let some of them in but stood my ground against a few who were blatantly disregarding the laws of polite driving. One woman nearly crashed into us before waving with a falsely sweet smile, as if to say, “Suckahs.” “Yeah, I’ve got a finger for her too,” said my dad from the passenger's seat.

Then, suddenly, we were there. It was nearly 10:00 p.m, almost thirteen hours after we’d left home. Two of those hours had been spent driving the last ten miles from New Jersey through lower Manhattan and into Brooklyn. My dad was determined to put a few hours of driving between himself and New York City hotel rates before stopping for the night, so we quickly unloaded my things and said our goodbyes, and then he was off and I was alone in a brand-new city.
Going from having a small fleet of new cars at my disposal to taking a forty-five-minute ride in a dirty subway car anytime I want to go somewhere is a major change.

I’ve had plenty of moments like that in the past five years, but it’s always an adjustment. Going from having a small fleet of brand-new cars at my disposal to taking a forty-five-minute ride in a dirty subway car anytime I want to go somewhere is a major change. In my first week in New York, I’ve seen people vomit on the train, watched a man clean his dentures with his sweatshirt, and been warned that if I stand too close to the edge of the platform someone will push me in just for fun. It’s nothing like driving in a comfortable car alone, but it is part of life in the big city, so I’m trying to embrace it. The next time I see someone holding their own teeth, though, I might lose it.

contributors.bio:
Jean Jennings has been writing about cars and the car business for more than thirty years. She learned about cars at the kitchen table from her father Robert, the late editor of Automotive News. At the age of eighteen, she bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, Jennings went to Chrysler’s test track where she worked as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, she was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine when she was laid off her Chrysler job, and in 1985 she left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr., as its first executive editor. She became Editor-in-Chief in 2000 and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

Jennings has won awards for her feature writing, for her car reviews, and for her monthly Automobile Magazine column “Vile Gossip.” She was the recipient of the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism. Jennings has the unique experience, sensibility, and personality to connect with women and to give them voice in the male-dominated automotive space. She was the subject of a Susan Orlean profile in the New Yorker, has appeared on numerous television news shows, has been on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno, and was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000.

She is currently a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News.

Jennings lives in the Michigan countryside with her husband, Tim, and the entire food chain.

pageElements.text: Ralph Gilles has been an amazing constant at the head of Chrysler design. For a time, he was in charge of Dodge, and he's currently in charge of SRT. It's funny that a designer is actually in charge of a brand as well as design, but certainly his passion for performance serves the company well.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/ohb9YQwSs3o" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

The Chrysler 200 was formerly the Sebring. They renamed it the 200, despite the fact that changes to it were modest, because the Sebring was such an awful car. When Fiat swooped in and saved Chrysler's bacon, they discovered that the company was more bankrupt in terms of product and engineering than they had suspected. There was so much work to be done that, for the first couple of years, all that could be done was cleaning up interiors and dealing with the most egregious problems in the lineup.

But, while Fiat and Chrysler and the United States government were hammering out a deal, the engineers and designers never stopped working. Ralph and his team did a wonderful job keeping Chrysler's great history from crumbling into dust. I particularly appreciated that because I'm part of Chrysler's great history, having worked at the Chrysler proving ground for five years in the mid-1970s.

This Chrysler 200 is nothing like the car it replaces, which is a great thing. The only thing that car had going for it was the fact that Eminem stood in front of it while he made an emotional speech about Detroit in an extra-long ad during Super Bowl XLV in 2011. $2 billion was spent to make this car great: $1 billion on manufacturing and $1 billion on product. It's competing in the fiercest class of all, dominated by the Honda Accord, Toyota Camry, and Ford Fusion—all sales juggernauts—and let's not forget the Nissan Altima and the Mazda 6. Chrysler is bringing everything they have to the party. Ralph Gilles was the only man to give us the walkaround.

title: It's the Blizzerator!
subTitle: I love snow! But I hate scraping it. My review of a tool that promises to get the car clear faster.

metaDescription: It's the Blizzerator! A review of a gadget that promises to get that snow gone more easily. How'd we like it? See the review on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: Timing is everything, and for the Blizzerator and me it was perfect. This triple threat to winter is an ice scraper, snow brush, and squeegee in one. I had a broken ice scraper with a mangled brush on the other end as my only weapon against this Michigan winter. On a few mornings, I had resorted to using a credit card on the ice and a household broom to remove the snow.

The Blizzerator arrived during the snowiest winter in Ann Arbor since 1978. Had it arrived last year, I am not sure I would have even opened the box. The first thing I noticed was the sheer size of it: it is 55 ¾ inches long when fully extended, but even at its shortest it is 44 inches.
After every storm I see some tool driving with the entire back window covered. Recently I saw a car that had only cleared the area directly in front of the driver.

I love winter, and I welcomed the new piece of equipment to help me make quick work of clearing off our vehicles. In my book, you need to remove the snow off your entire car. You should not just uncover a little area so the driver can see out and then allow the defroster to clear the windows as you drive to work. Seriously, after every storm I see some tool driving with their entire back window covered, and recently I saw a car that had only cleared the area directly in front of the driver.

The Brush

The brush has four angles to make it easy to swoop away the snow, but it did take a few attempts to get the angle just right. This particular storm had left a thick layer of ice on the car, with a crispy snow layer on top.The fact that you can adjust the Blizzerator's brush at all is a giant leap for snow removal.

The Squeegee

The squeegee is the key to clearing snow off the top of your vehicle. I personally have neglected to clear the roof of my car before, and when the snow started to melt and I applied the brakes, all the snow from the roof slid down and completely covered the windshield. I would rather not repeat that lesson.

The Scraper

My favorite part, and it was completely unexpected, was the ice scraper. I am 5’7”, but I still cannot reach the center of the windshield, and once I extend my arm I have no leverage to remove any ice. The Blizzerator easily reaches the center, even of our van, and delivers the leverage needed to remove stubborn ice.

Snow-Free Clothes

Best of all they throw in a set of Ginsu knives. Just kidding, but you can actually detach the ice scraper to make it less unwieldy for getting under the wipers, or in order to use it on the side windows. And the hidden bonus is, since you don’t need to stretch over the car, you can perform this all without getting a speck of snow on yourself. In fact, for owners of oversize vehicles, there is a three-foot extension that can be purchased separately.

My husband is seriously frugal, and I asked him if he would plunk down $19.95 to buy the Blizzerator. Drum roll...Yes, he would open up his dusty wallet. The ability to keep clean while clearing off his car made the decision easy. Since most mornings he clears off my car, too, I will chip in for half.

pageElements.text: Super Bowl XLVIII is this Sunday, and whether you’re rooting for Peyton Manning and the Denver Broncos or Russell Wilson and the Seattle Seahawks (or none of the above), everyone can agree that the Super Bowl is home to some of the year’s best commercials, and especially car commercials. These days, you don't even need to wait until the actual game to see them. Here are a few of the most interesting:

1. Volkswagen: Wings

No, Volkswagen’s “Wings” commercial won’t hit you in the same emotional way its acclaimed Super Bowl ad “The Force” did in 2011. Nevertheless, “Wings” is a hilarious take on the line from It’s a Wonderful Life that “Every time a bell rings, an angel gets his wings.” It’s also a great way for the brand to remind viewers that, as one study found, there are more registered Volkswagens with more than 100,000 miles than any other car brand.

2. Kia: The Truth

Almost fifteen years ago, we watched Morpheus offer Neo a choice in the film The Matrix: take the blue pill (“the story ends, you wake up in your bed and believe whatever you want to believe”) or take the red pill (“you stay in Wonderland, and I show you how deep the rabbit hole goes”).

Now Laurence Fishburne is back in his iconic role in Kia’s Super Bowl commercial “The Truth.” In it, Morpheus offers the same basic choice to a young luxury-car-owning couple, with one caveat: take the blue key (“and go back to the luxury you know”) or take the red key (“and you’ll never look at luxury the same way again”).

Cue the all-new Kia K900, the company’s first luxury sedan. Between filmed explosions that might as well be from The Matrix, agents, and bending spoons, Kia does a terrific job of showing us that the K900 really may make us change the way we look at luxury. The only thing this commercial lacks is a cameo from Keanu Reeves.

3. Jaguar: Rendezvous

Jaguar's sixty-second "Rendezvous" is the first appearance of the marque at the Super Bowl, and it's the kickoff to a full ad campaign that rolls out the new F-Type. Sir Ben Kingsley and other ruggedly handsome faces you'll recognize from the movies make appearances as villains, asking the intriguing question, "Did you ever notice how, in Hollywood movies, all the villains are played by Brits?" This is the most cinematically rich ad of the bunch, and it ought to be: It was directed by Tom Hooper, who won an Oscar for directing The King's Speech.

4. Hyundai: Dad’s Sixth Sense

Hyundai will show two commercials at the big game, but the one that stands out to us is “Dad’s Sixth Sense,” an ad for the all-new Genesis luxury sedan. The commercial shows a father consistently jumping in to save his son from potential injury as a toddler all the way up to his teenage years. But there’s only so much a parent can do from the passenger's seat, giving Hyundai the opportunity to show off the Automatic Emergency Braking feature on the 2015 Genesis.

5. Audi: Doberhuahua

If there’s one thing the staff at Jean Knows Cars knows, it's dogs. Despite this, even we have some reservations about the Doberhuahua, an unpleasant blend of Doberman Pinscher and Chihuahua. Even Sarah McLachlan, showing more sense of humor than you might expect, makes an appearance in this cartoonish ad.

Though the all-new Audi A3 doesn’t make an appearance until the forty-five-second mark of this one-minute ad, the humorous setup of “Doberhuahua” is Audi's way of marketing its A3 as a no-compromise compact luxury sedan and taking aim at the competition (Mercedes-Benz CLA-Class)...

6. Chevrolet: Romance

Chevrolet’s “Romance” follows a 2015 Silverado Heavy Duty owner’s journey as he trailers a newly purchased bull back to his ranch. Beginning with a soft piano score and the husky voice of a male narrator, “Romance” seems just like every other truck commercial. That is, until the music picks up, and the soft piano is replaced by the unmistakable sound of “You Sexy Thing” by Hot Chocolate. This commercial reminds you that the Super Bowl is expecting a mainly male audience in a partying mood, but Chevrolet wins points for having also released this father-daughter ad the same week.

Plus: Budweiser: Puppy Love

Budweiser’s Super Bowl ad “Puppy Love” has nothing to do with cars (nor should any alcohol-related ad), but we just had to share it. The commercial follows the friendship of a puppy and a Clydesdale horse whose pesky owners continue to get in the way and try to keep the two apart.

Car Max: Slow Clap

Car Max's "Slow Clap" commercial is just silly. What town does this guy live in? But it gets a mention because Car Max also made a puppy version.

Toyota: Muppets

Toyota calls on the Muppets and actor Terry Crews, a former NFL player, to show off how spacious its Highlander is. Are all those Muppets strapped in?

I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop). Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. pageElements.text: Watching a child make the transition from backseat passenger to brand-new driver can be scary for parents. Putting your teenager in charge of a multi-thousand-pound vehicle may not be the easiest thing you’ve ever done, but it is almost inevitable. And the good news is that even when you’re not in the car with them, you can have a big impact on their driving habits, according to a study released this month by Travelers, the insurance provider. Keep reading for some surprising findings from the study, and tips on how to talk to your kids about safe driving.

1. Be a Good Role Model

Travelers found that teens who reported that their parents were good driving role models were half as likely to have been in an accident as teens whose parents weren’t setting a good example. That’s good news, but it’s also a big responsibility. So when your kids are in the car, make an extra effort to drive safely and courteously–and hands off the cell phone.

2. Start a Conversation. Soon.

In their survey of 2,000 teens and parents, Travelers found that two-thirds of sixteen-year-olds wanted to have a conversation about driving safety with their parents, and half of those kids were waiting for their parents to initiate the conversation. By the time young drivers are eighteen, however, that window of opportunity is nearly closed. Just 29 percent of surveyed eighteen-year-olds were interested in a safe-driving talk with their parents. Don’t shy away from the talk; start a dialogue with your kids before they lose interest.
Be sure that your kids know not only how dangerous it is to drink or text behind the wheel, but feel empowered to refuse rides from peers who aren’t driving safely.

3. Don’t Be Naïve

Travelers found a surprising disconnect in the driving behaviors that parents and teens are concerned about. While the majority of teens–66 percent–were concerned about driving under the influence, just 14 percent of parents thought of it as a major concern. Mobile phone use while driving concerned 56 percent of teenagers but just 35 percent of parents, despite heavy media coverage of the dangers of distracted driving. You may not be worried about these behaviors because you think your teen knows better than to engage in them, but you should include impaired and distracted driving in your safe-driving talk anyway. Be sure that your kids know not only how dangerous it is to drink or text behind the wheel, but that they feel empowered to refuse rides from peers who aren’t driving safely.

4. Make a Driving Contract

Acting as a good driving role model and having a frank, open conversation with your teens about safe driving will go a long way, but they can’t be your last steps. To cement the agreements you and your new driver have made, think about drawing up a driving contract with your teen. Talk about forbidden behaviors, curfews, the number of passengers they’re allowed to carry, and anything else that’s important to you.

5. Have Consequences and Stick to Them

You should also agree on consequences for broken rules, so the contract has some teeth. That way they can’t say you’re being unfair when you take away the keys after a missed curfew. Consider agreeing to abide by some guidelines of your own, so your teen knows you’re not just imposing arbitrary restrictions.
Do you have young drivers in the house? What are your strategies for keeping them safe? Let us know in the comments below.

Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: I continue to not drive anything due to the big walking boot on my right ankle, which was broken at the Detroit Auto Show. Not that I stayed home. No sirree, you can't keep a good woman down! So I spent all of last week clumping from London to Crewe, England, and on through Paris, then back to London with Bentley Motors, purveyors of fine motorcars and now of fine furniture. Fancy that.

The trip began with a visit to the very private atelier of my millinery god, Philip Treacy, known to most Americans for the hats he made for the last royal wedding, thanks to People magazine's extensive coverage. It was a rare moment, brokered by our common friend Richard Charlesworth of Bentley.

It was on to Bentley’s historic headquarters in Crewe, where again I was welcome where few have been invited—the back rooms where veneers are mirror matched by hand, and where large southern German bull hides are scrupulously examined for the slightest flaws (unacceptable!) before a laser cuts pattern pieces dictated by a computer. Bulls are used because they don't have stretch marks.

On Wednesday, we took a high-speed train through the Chunnel to Paris, where we were whisked by chauffeured Bentley to a spectacular meal at the Prince de Galles hotel, from head chef Stéphanie Le Quellec. (Her husband is head chef at the Georges V, next door.)

The next day brought us (by Bentley) to the vast Maison et Objet, the Paris furniture show, to see the new line of Bentley designed and inspired furniture. Scott Allen, our brilliant JKC videographer, was there to record every word along the way. He is right now locked in his room (from the outside) editing several videos from our whirlwind trip abroad. Stay tuned.

It was so cold when we left for Europe that I couldn't imagine how to pack for the balmy 46° temps expected in Paris and London. It was just such a relief to not have to cover every millimeter of skin before I walked outside. Of course, we arrived home to the usual blizzard and more double-digit sub-zero temps.

Yesterday, I bought a figure-eight lace-up ankle brace so I could take the boot off and begin working out again at the gym and continue Pilates. It will be such a relief to do something other than lie on my back with my foot up in the air. Oh, wait! That is Pilates.

I’ve had all four dogs as constant company wherever I go, which is basically from couch to kitchen to bathroom, concentrating all the while not to trip over one or all of them and break my left ankle, too.

It's my birthday weekend ahead, and I'd really planned to be snowshoeing. Oh, well. I guess I'll be no shoeing. I continue to drive nothing (there is a Maserati Quattroporte parked outside my window that will leave long before my ankle brace comes off), and Jean's Driveway remains closed under a very deep layer of snow and ice, with ten more inches expected in the next two days.

But never fear. We have several more designer walkarounds from the Detroit Auto Show coming. We have our videos from our European adventure on the way. And before you know it, we will be on our way to the Westminster Kennel Club's big show at Madison Square Garden!
Love,
Jean

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

title: 2014 Kia Soul !
subTitle: Not as boxy as you think, and just as much fun as you hope.
promoTeaserSmall: Not as boxy as you think, and just as much fun as you hope.
promoTeaser: Not as boxy as you think, and just as much fun as you hope.
metaDescription: 2014 Kia Soul ! The exclamation point  is how I felt about the boxy thing. What did the Peanut Gallery say? Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
2014 Kia Soul Exclaim

Price: $21,095 (base price of this model, including destination)
$26,195 as tested (including destination)
Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 164 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 23 mpg city/31 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Heated power-folding side mirrors
Option I can’t live without: Heated front seats and steering wheel (part of The Whole Shabang package, $2,500)
Notable standard features on this model: Rearview camera, Bluetooth connectivity, leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob, LED taillights
Notable options on this model: Panoramic sunroof with power sunshade, navigation system with eight-inch screen (part of Sun & Sound package, $2,600); heated and ventilated front seats, heated rear seats and steering wheel (part of The Whole Shabang package, $2,500)
You might also be considering: Fiat 500L, Nissan Cube, Scion xB

Are you pro-hamster or anti-hamster? Chances are you aren’t neutral about those ubiquitous commercials that are meant to sell the Kia Soul to the young and hip. For some, the ads might be a sales disqualifier, because not everybody wants to buy a car that reminds people of strutting rodents, or a car that anybody would call “cute.”

That’s not me; I kind of like the cuteness, and I enjoy the ad campaign. Besides, I already know that the Kia Soul is not only for the young and hip: my next-door neighbor owns one, and she is decades past retirement age. So it was with a bit of a smirk that I brought home the virtual identical twin to her Soul, a frog green (Kia calls the color Alien 2) 2014 Kia in the top trim, Exclaim, which is spelled as ! (Other trim levels are Base and Plus, spelled +.) Yes, you heard that right; Kia has trim levels that are a ! and a +, and a color named after a sci-fi movie. Okay, maybe I don't like cuteness that much.

This is the more buff-looking model, which—as the hamster commercials advertise—has lost some of the kind of puffiness you see in the Fiat 500L and the Mini Countryman, in favor of a more angular appearance. The new look started with Kia’s critically acclaimed Track’ster concept (right) and ended with a longer, wider new Soul, yet it's still just as upright and just about as boxy as the original.

Let’s face it, nobody goes shopping for a car like this who isn’t already interested in standing out from the crowd. It’s the extrovert in the small-car lot, not as much of a goody two shoes as a hatchback, not as outdoorsy as a small SUV, and not as mainstream/conformist as a sedan. I almost wasn’t sure I was cool enough to be seen driving one, but then I remembered my next-door neighbor, who’s in the Opera Club and doesn’t care who knows it. (I guess extroverts come in all age groups.)

And anyway, I welcomed the opportunity to find out whether the buff look extends to the driving experience. And so, Polar Vortex or no Polar Vortex, I headed out in the Soul in search of an ! of a drive.

The ! is the top trim level on the 2014 Soul, and it comes, not surprisingly, with the biggest wheels (eighteen inchers) and the biggest engine (a 2.0-liter four-cylinder making 164 horsepower). The base model has sixteen-inch wheels and a 1.6-liter engine making 130 hp. I was glad to have the additional power while driving on heavily snow-covered roads, although having those larger-diameter wheels and tires to plow through the snow means they weren’t as welcome as they would have been on a clear day. Nevertheless, I found the Soul nimble, capable, and stable-feeling. It was quiet inside, navigated the bumps and unevenness of winter roads with aplomb, and generally felt much more expensive and more powerful than it actually is. Since the base model’s fuel economy is nearly the same (24/30 mpg instead of the ! model’s 23/31 mpg), I don’t personally think it’s worth it to lose the 34 horsepower and 33 pound-feet of torque you’re out by getting the lesser model. On the other hand, if you must have a manual transmission, the base model is the only one of the three that has it. I was very comfortable with the six-speed automatic.

The interior has no qualms about looking different. But it’s not different in a tacky way; you’ll be surprised how luxurious it seems for a brand that stuck to the lower end until recently. There’s a rounded theme inside that extends to the oval gearshift base and the dash-mounted speaker. There's an adorable image of the Soul that appears before your eyes when you push the button to start the car. Even the door handles are ovoid in shape. But you'd better hope for less ovoid back-seat passengers; billed as a five-seater, this car would definitely be more fun for four.

Kia’s Uvo telematics system was quick to react and easy to use, there's Pandora radio, and when you get the optional Sun & Sound package ($2,600), you get a big eight-inch touchscreen that satisfyingly commandeers a lot of dashboard real estate. The stereo system is where you know for sure that young drivers are being targeted. Opting for either the Sun & Sound package or the cheaper ($1,400) Audio package gets you an Infinity sound system with a center speaker on the dash that will appeal to your inner hamster, and even the base model has a six-speaker MP3 audio system and a three-month starter subscription to SiriusXM satellite radio.
The interior is different, but not in a tacky way; you’ll be surprised how luxurious it seems for a brand that stuck to the lower end until recently.

But it’s not all upscale sophistication; there are quirks. How about the baffling way the side mirrors fold in automatically when you shut off the car? Possibly appreciated by people who park in really narrow spaces in really crowded urban lots, but I just thought it was weird. There's the "backpack" rear end with Christmas-tree-like vertical LED taillights; I'm not so sure I like that look. But in both cases, you can't deny they help you recognize a Soul as a Soul.

You can get the base Kia Soul with the six-speed manual transmission for $15,695 (including destination). That’s an entry-level price without the entry-level style penalty. More popular, I imagine, will be the midlevel model with the 2.0-liter four-cylinder and the automatic transmission, priced starting at $19,195 (including destination). That’s a budget price without the budget ugliness. But budget for some of the options; you might want that panoramic sunroof (it’s in the pricey $3,000 Primo package), and I don’t know who would not want that big touchscreen.

The 2014 Soul got five stars overall in NHTSA crash testing and the top Good rating in all four categories by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. It stopped short of getting the Top Safety Pick designation for 2014 (although it had it in 2013) because it doesn’t have active safety items for front crash protection such as forward collision warning and autobrake. Otherwise, it gets a clean bill of health for safety, always good to hear about a small car.
It's not just the Soul that has a new look; the whole brand is in transformation, from the luxurious K900 sedan to the GT4 Stinger Concept at the 2014 Detroit Auto Show.

If you don't think the Soul has really changed that much, a quick look at the 2014 Soul (left) compared with its immediate predecessor, the 2013 model (right), will convince you. But it’s not just the Soul that has a new look; the whole brand is in transformation, from the luxurious K900 sedan to the GT4 Stinger Concept that was at Detroit's North American International Auto Show earlier this month. It’s getting to where Kia has completely changed its image. My oldest son used to joke about a commercial that would just say, “Kia. [awkward pause] It’s….a Kia.” That’s because he had too many friends who owned poorly maintained old Kias of the past. This Soul isn’t anywhere in that vicinity. If you don’t believe me, spend a few minutes behind the wheel of one.

The Verdict:

Think of the list of requirements you have when shopping for a new car. If you’re looking for a car that makes you smile whenever you spot it in the driveway, this one could be it. If you’re looking for a small car with a good safety rating? Check. If you want a car under $20,000 that still has a quality feel? This one could do it. But if you want to carry a lot of people or stuff, need a huge amount of power, or have little patience for quirkiness, this might not be the car for you after all. And don’t forget to weigh how much hamster jokes will annoy you (or please you) once you own one of these.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly Jean: The Soul won me over with its combination of quirky and unique styling. The self-folding mirrors make me smile every time, sort of silly but awesome. The interior boasts quality materials and the unique styling continues in the details of the interior. I would choose the gray houndstooth seats, it seems that cars that hover around $20,000 have all black interiors. The diminutive Soul actually feels roomy inside for the driver, and the hatch provides plenty of cargo room. Buyers who wants their car to stand out from the masses need to take the Soul for a spin.

2014 Kia Soul at left, with "backpack" rear end; 2013 Soul at right.
I wasn't sure I liked the 2014 Kia Soul's rear end, but there's no denying it is recognizable.
The 2014 Kia Soul was remarkably agile in the snow.
2014 Kia Soul is pretty svelte, just as the hamsters promised.
Interior of the 2014 Kia Soul is pretty luxurious for a small car, and the ovoid/round theme predominates.
Kia Track'ster concept was the harbinger of the new Soul's look.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

title: BMW Goes Sledding
promoTeaserSmall: BMW's new bobsled for Team USA took bronze at the XXII Olympic Winter Games. Women are next!
promoTeaser: BMW's new bobsled for Team USA took bronze at the XXII Olympic Winter Games. Women are next!
metaDescription: BMW Goes Sledding: BMW's Olympic sponsorship will make things exciting on the bobsled course in Sochi. See the sled on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: The lucky members of the USA’s two-man and two-woman bobsled teams are driving BMWs at the XXII Olympic Winter Games.. The German automaker used its EfficientDynamics technology to redesign the two-man bobsled. Michael Scully from BMW DesignWorks USA headed the project, aimed at making the U.S. team more competitive with a lighter and faster sled. It must have worked! The two-man team of Steven Holcomb and Steve Langton took the bronze medal on February 17 by an extremely invigorating 0.03 second over the next closest sled, that of the Russian team of Alexander Kasjanov and Maxim Belugin.
The BMW sled is sure to be just as much fun to watch when the women's teams compete on Feb. 18 and 19. (Full schedule here.)

BMW has provided Team USA a fleet of six of the new bobsleds. They're made of lightweight carbon fiber similar to that in the BMW i electric concepts. Traditionally, bobsleds have been made of fiberglass. The change has permitted massive weight savings. The two-person teams are helmed by Elana Meyers and Steven Holcomb, who took gold at Vancouver four years ago as head of the four-man team. Here's a brief glance at the team and the sled from NBC.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/HJZtOjseTxk" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
The U.S. team hasn’t won the gold in two-man bobsled since 1936. Interestingly, the last three Olympic gold medals in the sport have gone to...Germany.

Why isn't BMW supplying the German team instead of Team USA? I asked BMW spokeswoman Stacy Morris that question. She pointed out that Team USA is the only national Olympic team that doesn't get government funding and went on to say: "BMW consulted on the design of the German bobsled but didn't design the sled. A German government sport organization designed their sled." If you're looking for an argument for less government...

BMW held a sendoff party last week at its Munich headquarters for more than 100 athletes and functionaries of the U.S. bobsled, skeleton, and speedskating teams. They were treated to “traditional German-themed entertainment” on their way to Sochi and were offered tours of the BMW Welt facility, a shrine to the company’s products and activities next door to HQ. It was festooned with a Team USA banner for the occasion.

The automaker is into the Olympic Games in a serious way: BMW of North America is the Official Mobility Partner of the U.S. Olympic Committee, meaning it’s not just the bobsledders who will be spending some quality time in BMWs this month.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Young people like cars, after all!

There’s been a lot of chatter lately about how young people don’t like cars anymore. Many an article has been written bemoaning the fact that millenials would rather beat their high score on Fruit Ninja than learn to drive stick, and are more likely to spend spare cash on a tablet than a vehicle. As a young person who loves cars, I’ve long been suspicious of this dim view of millenials. And thanks to a study from J.D. Power, now I have some backup.

The firm recently released its report on automotive marketing and media, conducted since 1987, and it was full of good news about the attitudes of young people towards cars. According to the report, drivers age twenty-five and younger have represented a steadily increasing percentage of new car buyers since 2009, and now account for more than six percent of new car purchases.
For many young drivers, their car isn’t just a convenient way to get around but an extension of their personality and an important component of their public image.

Young buyers are also passionate about the cars they purchase. The report showed that for many young drivers, their car isn’t just a convenient way to get around town. It’s viewed as an extension of their personality and an important component of their public image. According to the report, 33 percent of young car buyers “completely agree” that they want their car to stand out from the crowd, compared to just 20 percent of drivers across all age groups. Twenty-seven percent of young drivers answered “completely agree” when asked if they would want to personalize their new cars with options and additional equipment, compared to 20 percent of drivers in all age groups.

It’s not just interest in theoretical cars, either: 29 percent of young car owners say they wash and wax their cars themselves, which is five percent above the national average, and they are willing to pay the price; younger buyers finance cars for an average of sixty-eight months, three months longer than the average.

Those numbers suggest a very different story from the “young people don’t care about cars” narrative we’ve been hearing. And it doesn’t stop with the car’s appearance. Young people are also much more likely to report enjoying driving on challenging roadways, and 41 percent of young car buyers prefer responsive, powerful cars. This is a satisfying rebuttal to the naysayers who are convinced that young people wouldn’t know a good car if it ran them over.

Older buyers still out-purchase the under-twenty-fives, but if J.D. Power’s study is to be believed (and why not?) we youngsters are not as hopeless as carmakers had feared. We are at least as excited about our cars and the role cars play in our lives as older drivers are. And that’s encouraging news.

title: 3 Lists To Help You Survive Winter
promoTitle: 3 Lists To Help You Survive Winter
promoTeaserSmall: What to have in the car so you're ready for anything. Emergency kits: not just for winter anymore!
promoTeaser: What to have in the car so you're ready for anything. Emergency kits: not just for winter anymore!
metaTitle: 3 Lists To Help You Survive Winter - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 3 Lists To Help You Survive Winter. What to have in the car so you're ready for anything. Emergency kits: not just for winter anymore! Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: As a lifelong Northerner, I confess to a little perplexity over the complete standstill in Atlanta last week. But I was nevertheless sympathetic. There’s little that’s as frustrating (or scary) as being stuck in a traffic jam on untreated, ice-covered roads. So I’m not even going to make a single crack about pampered warm-climate drivers who have no clue about how to drive in the snow.

I am, however, going to make a crack about this: I heard a radio interview with a woman who vowed, after spending some thirty hours stuck in her car on the freeway, “I’ve decided I’m going to start keeping a little kit in the car with some snacks and drinks for emergencies.”
Okay, really? Who doesn’t have an emergency kit in the car? Is this really just a Snow Belt thing?

Maybe it’s because of many years spent driving kids places, but I always have emergency supplies in my car. And it's not just a winter thing (although we do have six more weeks of that, according to Punxsutawney Phil). I would go a step further and suggest that you keep an emergency box of supplies in your car year-round.

I would even suggest you store these supplies in various places around the car. What if your trunk freezes shut, or if you get into an accident that makes it impossible to open? Or what if you just don't feel like parking, getting out of the car, and fishing around in the trunk for a granola bar in pouring rain or -14 degree weather?
And don’t let anybody get into the car in weather below freezing without a warm coat, even if they are just carrying it!

For you:

    • Food that isn’t temperature sensitive: energy bars, dried fruit, beef jerky, hard candy like Brach’s or soft candy like Dots, small packets of nuts or raisins.
    • Drinks such as juice or flavored water in pouches or aseptic boxes.
    • At least one large metal or ceramic cup that could be used to melt snow for drinking water.
    • Layers of clothing for every person likely to be in the car. Gloves or mittens, socks, hats, plus changes of footwear and clothes. And don’t let anybody get into the car in weather below freezing without a warm coat!
    • Blankets
    • A first-aid kid: Band-Aids, your favorite over-the-counter pain reliever, antibacterial cleaning squares
    • If you take essential meds, carry a couple days’ supply with you, if you’re not comfortable storing it in the car
    • Paper towels and toilet paper. You don’t want to need to perform ablutions in a remote area, but if you ever have to, you’ll want to have the paper goods to do it cleanly
    • A cell phone charger that works in your car

For safety:

    • Shovel
    • Ice scraper and short-handled broom
    • Flashlight, with batteries stored separately so they don’t corrode or so the flashlight doesn’t get left on and wear them out
    • Candles and strike-anywhere kitchen matches

For your car:

    • Jumper cables
    • Tow rope or chain
    • Windshield washer fluid
    • Cat litter (to put under the wheels in case you get stuck)
    • Emergency reflectors or flares
    • For the truly prepared: a distress (“Help!”) flag and a whistle
it’s good to have what you might need in an emergency. Bridges go out, storms happen, and delays come out of nowhere.

Remember, this list is not just for winter; it’s good to have what you need in your car any time of the year, whether you're going on a long drive or just running errands around town. Bridges go out, storms happen, and delays come out of nowhere. In case you’re ever stuck anywhere for whatever reason, you’ll be glad you have something more than an old gas receipt and an empty fast-food coffee cup on board with you.
Digital Vision/Thinkstock

pageElements.text:
Price: $34,995 (base price of this model, including destination)
$40,640 as tested (including destination)

You might also be considering: Ford C-Max Energi, Nissan Leaf, Toyota Prius

Do you spend a lot of time in the car as a solo commuter, driving under twenty miles to work and back every weekday but tend to go on longer jaunts on weekends and vacations? Having spent several days behind the wheel of a Chevrolet Volt, I’m convinced that person is the ideal owner of this plug-in hybrid.

That’s because the Volt can get you up to thirty-eight miles on electricity alone, running smoothly and silently down the road, keeping the driver feeling very smart and savvy. Hit that zero-charge threshold, and the Volt will automatically switch to gasoline power, or what Chevrolet calls "extended range," with no action from you. The power comes from a 16.5 kWh, T-shaped lithium-ion battery that powers the Volt's electric drive unit. When the battery charge is gone, there's a a gasoline-powered electric generator that kicks in, working with the car's electric motors. The technology is complex, but as a driver, I just need to know that I can drive as far as I want without powering down like a neglected iPhone. Range anxiety: gone!

What it can’t do is fit more than four, thanks to the battery load it's carrying, and those two in the back seat are not going to be comfortable for long distances. That disqualifies it as a family car, in my book and in the books of my long-legged teenagers.

There was a time, not so long ago, when the Chevrolet Volt was the eagerly anticipated electric car of the future. It came out in concept form in early 2007, low-slung and sleek, with wraparound windows that looked like Geordi’s eyewear in Star Trek: The Next Generation. Sexy! So, when I first saw one out on the roads in 2010, I was, frankly, disappointed. The production version looked a lot closer to something designed by committee, and the price that rested at about $40,000 felt like a pretty big penalty for being an early adopter.

But what do I know? Automobile Magazine's design editor, Robert Cumberford, explained the differences between the design of the concept and the production model in this article back in 2009. The more mainstream appearance, he explained, "also gives the car lower drag, more cabin space, and a tighter turning circle."

That all makes sense to me. But, frankly, there is just something a little uncool about the Volt relative to the trendy Nissan Leaf, Toyota Prius, and Ford C-Max that hybrid or EV shoppers would also be looking at. One way to overcome a charm deficit: Chevrolet cut the cost of the car by some $5,000 earlier this model year, which makes the Volt look more interesting in an increasingly crowded hybrid market. The Toyota Prius Plug-In starts at $30,800, and the Ford C-Max Energi starts at $33,745. That price cut still keeps the Volt at $34,995, but it also offers more power, more range, and better fuel economy than its competitors. But what does it feel like to be inside one? I wondered.
On first sight, I gave this Volt credit for looking like the electric car of the future as imagined by the artistic sketches of the 1960s.

On first sight, I gave this Volt credit for looking like the electric car of the future as imagined by the artistic sketches of the 1960s. That tricoat white exterior color is a $995 option, an added cost that I would reject with a snort on most cars, but it helps this sedan turn the corner from dull to dashing. Inside, I immediately bonded with the bright white ceramic trim and the candy-colored data screens in front of my face. Cue Jetsons theme! The rearview camera, one of my must-have features on any vehicle, looked especially good surrounded by the white ceramic. Then there are the digital dash readouts, which can be customized in what Chevrolet calls a Configurable Cluster. Awesome. You can set it up to show you the minimal information: how much electric range is left, for example. Or you can get it to show you full details and specs as shown in this Chevrolet video clip, and obsess over your fuel economy.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/O2paBpQPE3w" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

I couldn't wait to see if I could really get thirty-eight miles out of a charge. Unfortunately, the exterior temperature was hovering around ten degrees, so I went through the electricity a lot faster than that. Chevrolet has a helpful video on YouTube in which an engineer tells you not to heat up the interior beyond basic comfort in the winter, and if possible, leave it in a garage. Too bad, as I grew to enjoy the silent treatment from the Volt, even though I only got about twenty-eight miles before...listen for it...there: the generator kicked in.

But, speaking of power, I was pleasantly surprised how much fun the Volt was to drive. I mean, it is a mid-size sedan that looks like a fleet car. But actually, it was pretty nice on the road and not at all underpowered. It accelerated well, held its own in freeway traffic, and in every way felt "normal." That alone might make an EV conquest out of a buyer who doesn't consider herself adventurous or an early adopter. The Volt's list of safety and convenience features is right up to date, including several reasonably priced safety option packages that include that rearview camera plus traction control, lane departure warning, navigation, and Bose stereo, among other things. It wasn't long before I was completely in the groove of Volt ownership: drive it to the office and plug it in during the day; enjoy getting home and back again the next day without using any gasoline (and without driving any less assertively than usual). The normalcy of the Volt experience was probably the biggest surprise, and biggest selling point, for me.

Electric-drive vehicles still make up a minuscule share of total car sales—3.8 percent in 2013, according to the Electric Drive Transportation Association—and I’m convinced it’s not just because this is new technology; it’s because you can get a comparable traditionally powered car for thousands less, and people don’t (yet) see the benefit to themselves personally. With the prices starting to come down, and more public outlets becoming available so the idea of plugging in your car becomes more acceptable, I'm guessing more and more people will be ready to adopt this kind of vehicle. If you're on the fence, the Volt just might get you the rest of the way there.

The Verdict:

This is not the coolest, latest thing in hybrid vehicles. But it's also not the boring sedan that you might have expected until you get inside. The Volt deserves a lot more respect than I was expecting to give it. It is fun to drive not just because it's, you know, fun to drive, but because you can enjoy geeking out over the gasoline-to-electric ratio and keeping track of your fuel efficiency. You can also enjoy how long you can go without pulling into a gas station. It's got all the safety and technology features you would want on a new sedan, plus it will save you a bunch of money on fuel. According to Chevrolet, the average user fills up the tank once a month and saves $900 a year on fuel costs. The average mpg number for the eighteen Volt owners who post their results on the EPA's Fueleconomy.gov: 150.7 mpg.

Now, if you're going to sit down with an amortization table and figure out whether the fuel savings will equal the extra cost over a "regular" car, you might not get the numbers to crunch, but there's something very satisfying about dipping a toe into the waters of alternative power on a day-to-day basis. And, with the new price reduction, if you get the maximum $7,500 tax credit, you're talking about a starting price around $28,000, just about where you'd be for a traditionally powered sedan.

Give this car a try. I know I could see myself owning one, which is not what I thought I'd say before I overcame my prejudices and climbed in.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly Jean: When the Volt was first introduced at the tail end of 2010, I was totally unimpressed with the plastic used on the interior. But fast-forward to 2014 and I am perfectly happy with the "stormtrooper" white plastic. In fact, I grew to love the ultra-modern center instrument panel. I was also pleasantly surprised by the driving experience. It is definitely not a sports car but it can accelerate quickly, and is a perfectly competent car. If I was buying an electric or a hybrid I would make sure to test drive the Volt, even though still take away points for being an FLC (funny looking car).

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: I love hitting the decade birthdays—twenty, thirty, forty, and so on—because it has always given me a chance to update my “story.” You know what I mean? The story of your life, what you like, what you believe, who done you wrong, all wrapped up in a couple of paragraphs that you present to people you meet? You’d be amazed at how moldy that story can get in ten years!

I have just emerged from a decade of nonstop adventure. Only this week, the progression of adventure slowed to a crawl as my broken right ankle continued to heal and I continued to NOT DRIVE. This gave me an opportunity to drink champagne at the SURPRISE office party, orchestrated by office manager extraordinaire Jackie Guenther. Balloons everywhere! A cake shaped like my Barbara Feinman VooDoo top hat! A lot of old friends from early years of Automobile Magazine and Car and Driver!

Then, traveling and cooking companions from the Poland, Ohio, arm of the large Boniface clan swooped in to fetch me home for a long birthday weekend, marked by snow, snow, and then a whole lot of snow. This killed the planned day of winter sport because the roads were a disaster. Interstate down to one crappy lane of barely moving cars, on-off ramps unplowed, north-south roads blown shut by drifting snow.

But Sunday was brilliant blue, the perfect opportunity to ride in my birthday present, a diesel-engined Kubota RTV with a hydraulic dumping bed, a winch, and a trailer hitch. This is reminiscent of the time I received the black-diamond Carhartt coveralls which fit my husband perfectly. I will be wearing the key on a chain around my neck lest he wear it out. If that’s even possible! We are now a two-Kubota family. They clearly should be advertising in Automobile Magazine and on JeanKnowsCars.com! A write-in campaign might help.

The stalwart Dufeks (parents of one of our G-7 favorites, Jacqueline) showed up at the farm late morning, bearing a big juicy King Cake, FedExed from New Orleans by LSU grad Candi Dufek. No one got the baby Jesus baked in their slice, but we all wore Mardi Gras (and Saints) beads and geared up for the Super Bowl. It wasn’t until they left to get ready for Super Bowl at home that I realized we had a bona fide Honest-to-God Seattle Seahawks hero on the couch. Donnie Dufek was drafted into the original team and played his entire eight-year career there. He was a star special teams player (and the only player to lead the club in special-teams tackles four times), after storming to fame as a Michigan Wolverine. He was captain of both teams. Never mind that he was also drafted while at Michigan by the NHL and the WHA.

Mostly, he’s Donnie, and he talked for an hour without stopping about what makes a team brilliant, why the same teams always hover around the top of the food chain, and why it’s so exciting to watch great teams play. Interesting to me that everything he said was a primer in how to be a great magazine or a great website, which is: it’s all about the team.

And then the Seahawks won. By halftime, our viewing regimen had shifted to bathroom breaks during play, glued to the couch for the ads. Enough has been said about the ads, right? The twelve-year-old boy in me can’t stop laughing about VW’s wing size comparo at the urinal. Bob Dylan was the freakiest, creepiest ad. Cool message, but…Bob Dylan?
I wept, I laughed, I yawned, I ate Doritos.

My actual birthday is today. I walked into the office to find a large black case marked with tape: FRAGILE PHILIP TREACY LONDON FRAGILE punctuated by his signature unicorn. My hat had arrived, my birthday present to myself! Flowers, cars, photos, birthday wishes from all corners of my blessed life—all part of my story for the new decade.

Thank you all for your contribution to Jean Knows Cars. You are kind and considerate to us and to each other. You are helpful and funny and I try to read every single comment on the site, on our Facebook page, on our Instagram feed, and in the Twitterverse, which is where I sometimes get a little out there. Sorry. Or not.
My husband is driving me to and from work while the ankle mends. You can imagine what kind of passenger I was while he was at the wheel of the Maserati Quattroporte.

My husband, Tim, has been spending four hours daily driving me to and from work while the broken right ankle mends enough to flex it. You can imagine what kind of bad passenger I was while he was the one at the wheel of the Maserati Quattroporte. (It was parked safely in the garage all weekend.) He is never mad, always teasing, the rock of our little family. Maybe I can coax him out again to review those Kubotas on a future episode of Jean’s Driveway. They are the only vehicles that can move freely in it these past two months!

Love,
Jean

contributors.bio:
Sheer serendipity.  That’s how I became a contributor to Jean Knows Cars.  Well into a lovely dinner party, I received a most unlikely suggestion:  “You should write about cars from your perspective – a 4’11” single mother with a ten-year-old minivan who drives around three overactive children and a Bernese Mountain Dog.  Theatre, swimming, hockey, lacrosse, figure skating, field hockey… You love to tell stories. Tell them about cars.”  I suggested that my background possibly lacked necessary expertise – B.A. from Duke in art history and medieval/Renaissance studies; Fellow of the American Academy in Rome; Ph.D. from the University of Michigan in medieval architecture --  nothing about cars there!  My friend persisted, “You may be an art historian, but you are also a hockey mother who can whistle like a trucker, a runner, and a lover of good food, wine and the written word.”

I pondered.  The auto industry and I did have a long, if tangential, history.  I did a stint as an executive secretary to the president of a car dealership and spent fifteen years negotiating a dual identity as an academic and as auto company spouse.  I have always suffered from car envy, particularly acutely when I lived in Europe.  (As envy and lust are amongst the seven deadly sins, I’m in trouble.) Automobiles, functional objects that often shape image, are fundamental elements of today’s society.  This would be another mode of cultural analysis and critique.  Couched in that light, it made perfect sense!

(And, I really can whistle like a trucker, but louder. I may be an art historian, but don’t sit next to me at a hockey rink.)

pageElements.text: Most consumers tend to approach auto insurance with an eye to the vehicle insured. What’s the deductible? Would my repairs be covered in the event of an accident? There are, however, four components to insurance. The first two involve the vehicle, of course, but the second two help you by protecting you financially. My agent, Nathan Lamb, whom you may have met in last week's Insurance Checkup Time, explained it all this way. It's important to note that I live in Michigan, one of twelve states with "no fault" laws governing the way auto coverage works. The laws in your state and therefore, the insurance coverage, may be different.

1. Collision Coverage

Collision insurance, as its name implies, covers you if you hit something. If you’re at fault, your rating will be affected, likely making future coverage more expensive. The type of collision coverage you chose will depend on a variety of factors, including the age of the car and your tolerance for risk.

In Michigan, a “no fault” state (offerings vary state by state), there are three types of collision coverage.
    1. Regular collision pays for damage to your car from an accident. Regardless of who is at fault, you are responsible for the deductible.
    2. Broad collision also pays for damage to your car from an accident. It absolves you of paying the deductible if you are not more than 50 percent at fault.
    3. Limited collision coverage says that, if you’re at fault, the policy won't cover you at all; if the other party is at fault, your insurance covers the damage, although you still have to pay the deductible.

2. Comprehensive Coverage

"Comprehensive" insurance covers acts of God, things like hail damage, a tree falling on your car, or a deer trying to jump in for a ride. It will trigger payment of a deductible, as our recent story on a flying-tire incident unfortunately highlighted.
Check your liability. No one likes to think about the Worst Day, but it is, in fact, that day for which you really have insurance coverage.,

3. Property Protection (PPI)

Property protection insurance covers damage to other people's property. Say you blow a tire driving down Main Street, lose control, and hit someone’s front porch. That’s when property damage coverage comes into play. In Michigan, the state minimum is $10,000; most insurers recommend coverage for $1 million.The increase in coverage generally costs only a couple of dollars a month, and, think about it, $10,000 doesn’t cover you for much if you’ve inadvertently done structural damage to the house when you "parked" on the porch.

4. Residual Liability

This coverage, known as Residual Bodily Injury and Property Damage Liability insurance, covers you if you are found responsible or get sued as the result of an accident. In Michigan, the state minimum follows the 20/40 rule; you must have coverage for $20,000 per person and up to $40,000 per accident. Such minimal coverage, however, does not protect you from what Nathan calls “the Worst Day” event. Black ice prevents you from stopping at an intersection and when you slide through, you hit a car with four occupants, causing injury, or God forbid, death. You are at fault; they sue and win a $250,000 judgment per passenger. You are now responsible for $1 million. Under 20/40, which may have seemed the best option because of the minimal monthly premium, you are covered for only $40,000. The other $960,000? Your responsibility, and you could work for rest of your life, with 25 percent of your wages garnished, until you have settled that debt. Check your liability. No one likes to think about the Worst Day, but it is, in fact, that day for which you really have insurance coverage.,

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: We were just talking about the Kia Soul at Jean Knows Cars, and days after our review of the 2014 model, the automaker has rolled out a new version. At the Chicago Auto Show this morning, I saw the worldwide debut of the 2015 Kia Soul EV, an all-electric version.

The Soul EV has lithium-ion polymer battery power, teamed with a 109-horsepower electric motor. That may compare unfavorably with 164 horsepower for the "regular" Soul with its conventional internal-combustion gasoline engine.

But people don't buy most electric vehicles for power. The question you're asking is, what about range? So check this out: the EV offers 114 mpg-e in town and 90 mpg-e on the highway. The estimated range on a charge is a truly impressive 80 to 100 miles. Drivers can also dial in the car's regenerative braking system to recapture up to 12 percent of energy during coasting and braking, which will help optimize that range. I  liked Kia's choice of where to plug it in: right behind the front grille. It will charge in four to five hours using a 240-volt charging station or in 24 hours with standard 120-volt household current. Or you can get it to 80 percent in a half-hour if you use a special 50-kW charger.

The under-floor battery positioning, Kia says, offers "more energy in less space." Legroom in the back seat is cut only 3.1 inches from the reasonably capacious regular Soul, and rear cargo space is down 5.1 cubic feet to 19.1 cubic feet. Indeed, Kia has not budged from its characterization of the Soul as a five-passenger vehicle unlike, for example, the Chevrolet Volt, which seats four because of its battery.

images.caption: Grille looks different because that's where you plug this Kia Soul in.
A promised range of up to 100 miles sounds good. The Kia Soul EV will charge fully in under five hours with a 240-volt charger.
Two-tone color schemes will differentiate the Kia Soul EV from the regular Soul.
2015 Kia Soul EV making its debut at the Chicago Auto Show, February 6, 2014. Photo by Susan Campbell.
Molly Jean and one of the iconic hamsters at the Chicago Auto Show, posing with the 2015 Kia Soul EV. Photo by Susan Campbell.

pageElements.text: As soon as I saw it on the show floor in Chicago, I was a fan of that two-tone paint scheme. Gorgeous! All the Kia EVs will be two-tone: Caribbean Blue with a Clear White roof, Pearl White with an Electronic Blue roof, or Bright Silver with a Clear White roof. That's a way to differentiate it from the gasoline-powered Soul.

Kia marketing chief Michael Sprague said the Soul EV will be competitive against the whole gamut of electric vehicles, from the Fiat 500E to the Ford C-Max to the Nissan Leaf. He didn't name an estimated price for the car, but that will be clear soon. The Soul EV goes on sale in California and Oregon by the fourth quarter of this year. After that, it will roll out in New York, New Jersey, and Maryland.
Top photo and photo of Molly Jean with hamster: Susan Campbell
