pageElements.text:
Nissan rolled out a new version of its entry-level hatchback, the Versa Note, at the Chicago Auto Show today, and here it is. This new 2015 Versa Note SR is a sporty trim level. It's targeted at the twenty-five-to-thirty-five demographic, with an emphasis on young parents who are willing to give up some luxury features for economy but still want good design with a sporty edge. I love it, even though I'm a little past the age category...

This is the second generation of the Versa Note, and this spring when the SR joins the lineup, there will be five trim levels to choose from.

The difference between this and the more workaday five-door Versa Note versions is all in the looks. The Versa Note SR has the same 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine and Nissan Xtronic continuously variable transmission as the standard model. It makes 109 horsepower and gets 31 mpg in town and the magical 40 mpg on the highway.

What distinguishes the SR from the other Versa Note models is a special fascia and blacked-out grille, subtly different headlights, standard fog lights, body-color side spoilers, a rear spoiler, and redone side mirrors with turn signals integrated into them. The rear bumper is pudgier. There’s also a set of sixteen-inch dark-painted aluminum alloy wheels—Nissan product planning manager Eric Vaughen thinks they look like the blades of a Kitano knife—and some SR badging.

Inside, there’s a leather-wrapped steering wheel “inspired” by the 370Z, a piano black instrument panel with chrome knobs, and imitation suede seats with orange dots and contrast stitching. The adorable dot patterns extend to the door inserts. A new center stack and a set of center dials are all new and will be on the other Versa Note models for 2015, too.

The SR will be available with an optional Convenience package that includes my favorite, an adjustable “Divide-N-Hide” floor that lets you make the floor flat when the middle row is folded. There's also a center armrest with cup holders for kids in the car seats, plus a five-inch color display, hands-free text messaging, a rearview monitor, and NissanConnect smartphone integration and apps. The SR will join the current Versa Note lineup in Nissan dealerships this spring.
 
Model year 2015 will be notable for the entire Nissan Versa Note lineup: all versions will get standard Bluetooth connectivity with steering-wheel-mounted controls.
Nissan isn't saying how much the new Versa Note SR will cost, but it shouldn't be far out of the $15,000 neighborhood the regular Versa Note lives in.

metaDescription: Stuck on the Road in Atlanta: Jenny was one of those people you heard about. How she coped when her 30-minute drive took 13 hours. Read her story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text: Jenny Gould, a dance teacher at a private school in Atlanta, Georgia, was released early from work on January 28 due to a freak winter storm. It was 1:30 p.m., and she was about to embark on an unprecedented journey home. A trip that normally takes her thirty minutes ended up taking thirteen hours.
The January 28 storm paralyzed the city of Atlanta. Nearly three inches of snow and ice caused one of the worst traffic jams in history.

“I started off on Interstate 75 North and it was gridlocked. Basically, I would move a tiny bit forward, stop and move a tiny bit forward, then stop and idle for forty-five minutes or so. It was hell!” she recounted.
But this was only the beginning of her hellish journey. Luckily, she had provisions (an orange, a granola bar, and a bottle of water), which she smartly rationed off during the entire fiasco.

After three hours of traffic jams and gridlocks on the Interstate, Gould took an exit to a back road. Her plan to escape the snarl was a bust. She was stuck on that shortcut for the next five hours.  
 
By that time it was dark, the temperature was dropping, and the roads were icing over.

“I kept telling myself to 'keep moving…you can do this,' " she said. “I was praying to God to just get me home. It was terrifying and surreal at the same time. I experienced a gamut of emotions, from fear and anger to intense determination.”

As Gould watched, an otherworldly scenario unfold outside her windshield. “Some people abandoned their cars and started walking, while others were getting stuck and looking lost and confused. It was like being in a zombie movie.”
She took an exit to a back road. Her plan to escape the snarl was a bust. She was stuck on that shortcut for the next five hours.

The teacher adds, “I am so grateful that my mechanic convinced me to buy state of the art Michelin Defender tires last summer.  The combination of those and my Nissan Altima coupe saved my life.” Were the wheels worth the investment?  You bet. While other vehicles were sliding all over the place, Gould’s 2010 Nissan Altima coupe remained solid. (No, this is not a car promotion! It also helped that Gould had lived in New York for many years and knew how to navigate snow and ice.)

To keep calm during the calamity, the dancer listened to talk radio to get storm updates and chatted with friends and family on her phone. It was also a mixed blessing that she wasn’t going it alone. The lines of cars around her provided some comfort.

The Moment of Truth

However, that would all change around 1:30 a.m. “I was faced with a major decision. There was a big hill up ahead, and I watched cars struggling, sliding, and getting stuck. At that point, I could either pull over in a scary industrial area and sleep in my car, or I could keep going.”
The driver decided to brave the incline. Once her Nissan tackled that obstacle, the road became what she described as an open, empty and frozen wasteland of whiteness.
“I was truly on my own as I proceeded over a bridge of sheer ice. The only vehicle on the road was a bus blinking its hazards in front of me. I followed it all the way home,” she said.
The survivor pulled into her driveway at 2:30 a.m. “It took thirteen hours, or the equivalent of a road trip to Dallas, Texas or hey, even Chicago!” she quipped.

The takeaway? Gould feels that a strong will, and remaining mentally and emotionally calm, can get you through anything. Since the debacle, she has packed a survival bag in the trunk of her car. It contains a change of clothes, boots, water, snacks, hand sanitizer, two blankets, two towels, and a first aid kit.
The survivor summed it up, “I am still adding to it, but hey, you never know in this age of unpredictable weather. You need to be ready.”

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text: Attending the U.S. introduction of the 2014 BMW 740 Ld xDrive at the Chicago Auto Show this week made me face the fact that you can’t really go wrong with BMW’s flagship sedan, the 7 Series. It is simply a beautiful piece of machinery. Adding diesel to the mix can only be a good thing!

"In 2009, BMW introduced its first modern diesel, the 335d X5, to the U.S.,” explained David Buchko, BMW Product and Technology Communications, at the introduction. What makes a "modern" diesel? "They're not like the diesels of old; they're clean and they're quiet," he explained.
These days, diesel technology has entered the eco arena, and since the 2009 introduction of the diesel BMW X5, one in five sold in the U.S. has been a diesel model.

BMW's history of producing diesel engines goes back more than three decades, to 1983. The first of these, a 2.4-liter straight-six engine, was available with a turbocharger. It was even sold to a number of American automakers for use in their vehicles. These days, diesel technology has entered the eco arena, and since the 2009 introduction of the X5, one in five sold in the U.S. has been a diesel model.

What's so great about this new diesel-powered BMW? To make you understand, here’s a brief snapshot. The lovely lines of the contoured exterior are painted a glowing metallic, pumped up with nineteen-inch alloy wheels and chrome accents and adorned with mellow LED headlights. The interior is plush with ivory white Nappa leather, with walnut root inlays and accents, including a customized instrument display.

This new model will feature BMW’s 3.0-liter TwinPower Turbo diesel engine, which brings on 255 horsepower and 413 pound-feet of torque. EPA fuel economy estimates and ranges are not yet available, but BMW says that combined mpg should be in the 30s. It was noted that other models equipped with this engine have seen a 25 to 30 percent improvement in fuel efficiency over their gasoline-powered equals.

As expected, the diesel model of the flagship sedan will offer all of the same amenities as its gas brother, including xDrive (BMW’s all-wheel-drive system) and fuel-saving strategies featuring driving dynamics control with Eco mode and auto start/stop.

The BMW 740Ld xDrive will kick off at $83,425 (including destination) when it arrives in U.S. showrooms this spring. Just FYI, that's $4,500 more than the gasoline-powered 2014 BMW 740Li sedan, which starts at $78,925.
For those of you interested in BMW’s advanced diesel but from a lower price point, Buchko noted that BMW will be offering the X3 diesel in 2015.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: The Westminster Dog Show is taking place next week, and Bob the Reluctant Show Dog will be one of the 2,716 dogs who will participate.

Bob has competed at Westminster once before, in 2011. He was not yet three, which was very young for a Chesapeake Bay retriever. He was not quite mature, but he was always spectacular-looking with great proportions. Because there were twenty-seven Chesapeakes competing, the judge separated the dogs and the bitches and looked at each group as it went around the ring separately. Then she had all of them come out together and go around the ring. Then she pulled ten dogs as her finalists. The first six she called were bitches, which immediately made us think that she favored the smaller, more delicate girl dogs. Then she picked the top three Chesapeakes in the country. She then went down the long line of dogs, stopped at Bob, and picked him as her tenth. I’m getting a little choked up just writing this. At the time, though, I burst into tears and cried so hard that I got interviewed.
None of the girls won, and Bob didn’t win. The number-one Chesapeake in the country won.

We think Bob has a decent chance this year because he is at the perfect age (five) and in peak condition, and he loves his handler, Kelly Leonard. It’s a magic bond, and he really enjoys the show ring. Don’t ask me how or why, but he loves it.

We skipped Westminster in 2012, and we missed out on 2013 last year because the entry was late. I was dumbfounded when my husband told me he sent it U.S. Postal Service Next Day and it didn’t arrive in time. (When it absolutely has to get there, you have to use FedEx.) Secretly, I was glad, because it was so hard going to Westminster that first time. You had to stay there all day with your dog, it was super hot, and you couldn’t sit down because there was no room for chairs, so we were leaning around a lot.
Want to meet Bob at Westminster? He'll be at Pier 94, Section A, Row 20 at the Chelsea Piers all day Tuesday (February 11).

This year, it’s completely different. Instead of jamming 2,716 dogs into a cramped under-construction space at Madison Square Garden, they have moved all of the breed competitions to the Chelsea Piers. If you win your breed, you enter the group competition. The group competitions will then happen at Madison Square Garden on Monday and Tuesday. These are what you see on television. When Tuesday’s group competition is finished, they go directly into Best in Show with the winners from all the groups.

This is a bench show, one of very few in the country. That means that the dogs are grouped together by breed in one area, and they have to stay there all day. So you can come in and out as a visitor and count on the fact that if you’re looking for Chesapeakes, you’ll find twenty of them all benched together with, of course, Bob being the most beautiful one of all. We call that being kennel blind.

If you want to come to Westminster and meet Bob in person and get his autograph or get your picture taken with him, he will be in Pier 94, Section A, Row 20. He’ll be hanging out in his cage except for bathroom breaks and on Tuesday, when he and the other nineteen Chesapeakes that are registered for the show will compete in Ring 8 at 12:30 p.m.

We’re going to leave from Ann Arbor on Sunday in a Mercedes-Benz Sprinter van. It’s quite a posse: Tim, handler Kelly, videographer Scott, Bob, and me. That’s right, we’re going there to work, with just a break to see Bob compete and let me weep a little bit. Just kidding. I’ll only be weeping if he wins. Actually, I might be fainting if he wins.

We want to make a little video that brings to you some of the excitement of having a dog in the show. Going to dog shows isn’t really magic. They frequently take place in sporting arenas and hotel conference rooms, where it’s all pretty cut and dried and there’s not a lot of ambiance unless you like the smell of dog pee. But Madison Square Garden was absolutely without a doubt as magic to us two years ago as it looks on television.

title: Aunt Mimi Goes to Land Rover School
subTitle: She tackles the Land Rover Experience off-road, while I watch in admiration.

metaTitle: Aunt Mimi Goes to Land Rover School - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Aunt Mimi Goes to Land Rover School: She tackles Land Rover Off-Road School in North Carolina, while I watch in admiration.

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text: When I called to confirm that I would be attending the Land Rover Driving School at the glamorous Biltmore Estate in Asheville, North Carolina, I was informed that I couldn’t come unless I brought along my eighty-six-year-old Aunt Mimi. After reading about my last driving adventure with Mimi on this website, everyone at Land Rover was eager to meet her.
One call to Mimi confirmed it. She answered without hesitation, “Just tell me the date, time and place. I’m all packed!”

Mimi informed me that she had not driven an off-road vehicle since the 1950s, when she and her husband, Alan, who was in the Air Force, were stationed in Newfoundland. She got around in the snowy conditions in a Triumph Mayflower, a small British four-seater, which was plenty sturdy but nothing compared to a Land Rover.
I thought, “Oh no! How is Mimi ever going to get behind the wheel of a Land Rover on a rough off-road course? She is going to freak!”

I was so wrong. Let me preface this by saying that I have been taking adventures with Land Rover for well over a decade in places as wild as the mountains of Argentina, the dunes of Mongolia’s Gobi Desert, and the canyons of southern Utah. Several years ago, I took the off-road course at the Biltmore. I remember being so scared that my instructor, Greg Nicklaus, told me to calm down and appreciate the Zen of the experience. By serendipity, Nicklaus was the same instructor that Mimi and I had on this trip.
We would be experiencing mangled roads with rocky, knee-deep puddles, mud, ice, tree stumps, steep hills, and unknown obstacles. Mimi’s response was, “I want to go fast!"

But Mimi was not at all frightened. After Nicklaus explained that we would be experiencing mangled roads with rocky, knee deep puddles, mud, ice, tree stumps, steep hills, and other unknown obstacles, Mimi’s response was, “I want to go fast!”

Nicklaus calmly informed her, “Slow and steady is the word here.” He gave us a user-friendly explanation of how to shuffle the wheel (let it slide between your hands) and the terrain response system (one simply turns a knob to suit the terrain: grass/gravel/snow, mud/ruts, sand and rock or auto). He also educated us on using hill descent control: you take your foot off the gas and the brake when descending a hill, and the vehicle takes over.

Mimi exclaimed as she was driving over our first rutted road, “This car practically drives itself!”  Greg reminded her to go easy on the gas, keep her foot off the brake, and center the wheel to prevent us from sashaying. Mimi’s reply, “These tires are like dancing shoes rather than hiking boots—this vehicle is so graceful!”
Our instructor educated us on using hill descent control: you take your foot off the gas and the brake when descending a hill, and the vehicle takes over.
After the hill, there was a series of bumpy ruts and puddles. “Hello baby,” said Mimi, “I’m in mud and there’s no road here!”
“Mimi you're a rock star!”  exclaimed Nicklaus.
She answered, “You mean because I'm going through rocks?”
Yes. In fact, at that point Mimi was driving on two wheels.
To describe what this course looked like, we got out of our car to watch the other students take the rocky path. Nicklaus lowered the suspension so that Mimi could get out easily. She was impressed.
“My friend has an SUV, but we need a ladder to get into it,” she quipped.

And there’s more, I explained as we got back into the Range Rover. “These seats can heat, cool, and massage. And look at all the beautiful wood inlays and soft leathers they use,” I bragged. Mimi cooed,  “This interior is as handsome as a piece of Elizabeth Taylor’s jewelry…it shines!”
As we approached the next butte, Nicklaus said, “We are going to drop down on a hillside to your left.”
Mimi uncharacteristically faltered for a second. “I can’t see what’s below me!”
Nicklaus noted calmly: “There’s nothing to it. Take your foot off the gas and the brake, and let the machine do its job.”

As Mimi slowly lowered the vehicle down into one and a half feet of mud, she smiled. “This is a lot different than driving on a racetrack in an Aston Martin. How fast does this car go on the autobahn?”
Nicklaus replied: "You’re bringing a tear to my eye. You’ve got it! You are in control of this vehicle.”
Mimi’s comeback? “If I had a Range Rover in Atlanta, I could maneuver through all of our traffic with the ease of a gazelle.”

About a week later, Mimi sent me this e-mail: "As I think back on the wonderful weekend in North Carolina, all I can really recall at my senior age is the thrill of driving the Range Rover. Wow!  It was the thrill of my lifetime. The car, although I must say it's much more than a car, was the smoothest feeling of travel I've ever experienced.  Sure, there were bumps and grinds …the logs crossed our paths, the mud holes were knee deep, the creeks crossed were uncharitable, the cliffs climbed were rocky and daring, I never once winced because this Rover was so luxurious and solid-feeling. I felt like I am in the arms of an Atlas or Arnold Schwarzenegger (in his youth, of course.)”

pageElements.text: And then there was the Biltmore. The 8,000-acre estate is the historic home of George W. Vanderbilt. Building started in 1889, in the style of a French Renaissance chateau, and it formally opened on Christmas Eve 1895. Besides taking part in the driving school, we were invited to a private candlelight tour of the estate. The mansion has more than four acres of floor space, including thirty-five bedrooms, forty-three bathrooms, sixty-five fireplaces, an indoor pool, and a bowling alley. Frederick Law Olmstead, who created Central Park in New York City and Elm Park in Worcester, Massachusetts, designed the Biltmore’s vast gardens.

metaDescription: Car Insurance: 4 Reasons NOT to Switch. Should you be hunting online for the cheapest deal? Here are four reasons that is counterproductive. Read them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Sheer serendipity.  That’s how I became a contributor to Jean Knows Cars.  Well into a lovely dinner party, I received a most unlikely suggestion:  “You should write about cars from your perspective – a 4’11” single mother with a ten-year-old minivan who drives around three overactive children and a Bernese Mountain Dog.  Theatre, swimming, hockey, lacrosse, figure skating, field hockey… You love to tell stories. Tell them about cars.”  I suggested that my background possibly lacked necessary expertise – B.A. from Duke in art history and medieval/Renaissance studies; Fellow of the American Academy in Rome; Ph.D. from the University of Michigan in medieval architecture --  nothing about cars there!  My friend persisted, “You may be an art historian, but you are also a hockey mother who can whistle like a trucker, a runner, and a lover of good food, wine and the written word.”

I pondered.  The auto industry and I did have a long, if tangential, history.  I did a stint as an executive secretary to the president of a car dealership and spent fifteen years negotiating a dual identity as an academic and as auto company spouse.  I have always suffered from car envy, particularly acutely when I lived in Europe.  (As envy and lust are amongst the seven deadly sins, I’m in trouble.) Automobiles, functional objects that often shape image, are fundamental elements of today’s society.  This would be another mode of cultural analysis and critique.  Couched in that light, it made perfect sense!

(And, I really can whistle like a trucker, but louder. I may be an art historian, but don’t sit next to me at a hockey rink.)

pageElements.text: Most people assume that car insurance protects a depreciating asset (the vehicle). What it really protects is your family’s financial well-being.  Ideally, you should review your coverage annually. If you have a major life event such as marriage, divorce, inheritance, or job change, that’s also a time to revisit your insurance. Moreover, most people bundle their home insurance with their auto insurance.  Life events have trickle-down effects for home and auto.

In that annual review, should you be jumping ship (or cars for a more appropriate metaphor) to the insurer with the lowest rates? My agent, Nathan Lamb of Farm Bureau Insurance, had a convincing argument that it's not the right thing to do, for these five reasons.

1. A company’s rates vary year to year, depending on the number of claims the company has had. If you stay with the same company for many years, chances are you’ll come out even or better than if you constantly switched. If a company offers to give you a “better rate” just for being you or “to keep you as a valued customer,” warning: it’s a marketing ploy. Insurance rates are filed with the state. Your parameters determine coverage, but special offers do not.

2. When determining your rates, every company looks at your “insurance score,” which is akin to a credit score. Constant changing could affect your insurance score, which also could affect your premiums.

3. Constantly changing prevents you from the benefits of developing a long-time relationship with one agent. If you constantly change, you become a number, and something can fall through the cracks. (For example, when my previous insurance company neglected even to process the insurance on my Fiat.)

4. Agents know things you don't. In the days of online everything, auto insurance is marketed as a widget you buy. We tend to pick our insurance by lowest premium, even though lower prices inevitably mean lower coverage. We’re talking quite the widget, given the issues at stake. Do you really want to figure it all out by looking at the Web?

As a consumer, you are not a licensed agent with the knowledge, training, and continuing education that licensing entails. If you have a good agent, he or she becomes the fourth wheel that drives your financial security. Along with your banker, your lawyer, and your accountant, your insurance agent should be looking at the big picture and at what’s best for you and your family. He or she should be asking you about net worth, what you make per year, and how long you intend to work as the two of you consider your insurance coverage. Those factors, and your stage in life, not “how low do you want your premium,” should be driving your decision.

metaDescription: 2015 Ford Mustang Pinball Game - Ford GT designer Camilo Pardo drew it, and you can play it. New game comes out April 1. Get some tips from the #1 player. It's on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I am a person who loves to study other people. I like to interview them, learn about their lives, photograph them, and write their stories. The people at Jean Knows Cars noticed me through my project, Humans of Ann Arbor. In that project, I tool around the city of Ann Arbor, introducing myself to anyone who draws my eye. If they are open to it, I take a photo of them and hear a little bit about them. Then I post the photos and stories on Facebook. Humans of Ann Arbor has followers from all over the world who check in on a daily basis to see ordinary people and their extraordinary stories. I have been studying people since I was a little girl in Missouri. Where I grew up, studying people often led you to the cars they loved. My grandpa had a gas station in Claycomo, Missouri, which he opened in the 1950s, and he passed his love of cars and taking care of the people who drove them down to my dad. Dad was a mechanic and a service supervisor all his life. We had a steady barrage of cars coming into our lives…mostly Chevys. To impress my dad, I learned to identify every car I could, and I used to name the cars while we drove down the road. Car culture is big in Missouri. Would you believe that I had friends who were sisters named Nova and Chevelle? If you didn’t grow up the way I did, you might not get the significance of that, but suffice it to say that my people love their cars. The car I adored most was the Chevrolet Corvair my dad gave me when I was in high school. It spent more time in my dad's shop than it did on the road, but in those moments when it was drivable, I knew what it was to love a car. It was a thing of beauty: pale cream with a plaid madras interior. I loved the sound and feel of the engine…it was more like a soft purr than a roar. I can still remember how it smelled and what it was like to drive it with the windows rolled down on a warm day. I've had lots of cars since then, and I loved some of them, too. But the Corvair was my first car love and will always be my favorite. After high school, I drove my car to Springfield, Missouri, to study communications at Missouri State. Later, I drove a different car to Chicago to study photography at Columbia College. I worked in Chicago as a freelance photographer and studio manager for many years before moving to Ann Arbor, where I continue to do freelance photography. I am excited about combining my love of studying people with my interest in cars. I want to explore how cars serve us, how they are intertwined in our lives, and what makes us love them. I can't wait to let you know what I find out.

pageElements.text:
Don’t tell my kid, but before the term “screen time” was coined I spent a huge chunk of my
childhood playing video games and pinball in my neighborhood arcade.  It was the pinball
that separated me from most of my lunch money, though.  There was something I loved
about the mechanical whir of the machine paired with bells and flashing lights as the ball
ricocheted its way around.  I don’t get to spend much time in arcades anymore, though, so I
was ecstatic when I came across the Ford Mustang pinball machines at the Chicago Auto Show.

Ford and Stern Pinball teamed up to create a trio of pinball games that celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of the iconic Mustang, and the game is rolling out to the public at the Chicago Auto Show. It goes on sale on April 1, mainly intended for arcades and other public spaces. (But you can pre-order one of your own through Ford's merchandise website; it'll cost $4,995, plus $300 shipping.)

The pinball machine is as shiny and sleek as the car it represents. Instead of bells, the sound of revving Mustang engines punctuates the game play, and in place of levels there are “gears” to work through. Mach 1, Cobra, and Boss Mustangs are all represented as well as, of course, the 2015 Mustang. There are eight scenarios from drag racing to road rallies to police pursuits. At the highest level of achievement, you advance to the Silverball Stampede, a coast-to-coast run set to the music of the past fifty years, from Jan & Dean through Motörhead. Stunt driver/TV host Tanner Foust narrates the action.

It was the absolute luckiest time for me to have found those pinball machines.  Zach Sharpe, who holds the honor of being 2013’s World’s
Greatest Pinball Player, was on hand to demonstrate the game.  Zach reminded me of a
few of the fundamentals, and before long my flipper fingers were warmed up.   If, like me,
you are an aspiring pinball wizard, here are Zach’s tips to up your game:

1. Read the Game

Don’t just drop your quarter in willy-nilly. Pinball machines have basic instructions to get you started. Look at text near the flippers and on the display board before you play. Sometimes pressing the flipper gives you additional information.

2. Follow the Light

Don’t worry, no one has ever died from playing pinball that we know of, so we don’t mean that kind of light. Pinball machines have lights that tell you where to aim the ball. If you watch the display, it will help you know when to go for extra points and multi-ball play. Targets that will earn you points also light up.

3. Get Physical

Move the machine with your body to get the ball to go where you want it to. “Don’t be afraid to get physical,” Zach advised. “The game will let you know when you’ve pushed it too far.” Yep, with a big, fat TILT. I had forgotten about that. Luckily for me, the machine was set on a two-minute unlimited ball setting, or I would have been done in about thirty seconds.

4. Control the Chaos

It may seem like happenstance that the ball goes where it does inside the pinball machine, but experienced players can call a shot and send the ball exactly where they say they will. One way to gain some control is to stop the ball with the flipper. With some practice, you can learn to let the ball start to roll down the flipper, and pick the right moment to flip it to make it go in the direction you want.

5. Flip Independently

“A lot of people make the mistake of using both flippers at exactly the same time,” Zach said. “You have to use them separately to gain control of the ball sometimes.” Giving that a try significantly improved my game.

You might want to keep these tips to yourself, at least until you take a shot at getting the high score at the Chicago Auto Show.  I’ll be practicing myself, and I’ll probably be taking my son.  A lot.  I mean, technically it isn’t screen time, right?
